name: Mr SPEAKER
content: —For some time now, the President and I have been considering the future administrative arrangements for the parliament in the context of increasing demands for services at a time of budgetary restraint. After reviewing comments from the heads of the five parliamentary departments, we have decided to implement a management structure based on the two chamber departments.The functions of the present three joint departments—that is, the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff, the Department of the Parliamentary Library and the Joint House Department—will be merged into the Department of the House of Representatives and the Department of the Senate.This two‐chamber department structure is the best way of achieving a dynamic and responsive organisation which will allow the parliament to make significant savings while improving the services provided to senators, members and committees.The President and I know that we will have the full and professional support of all staff in meeting the objectives of greater efficiency and effectiveness in the parliaments operations.We have asked the departmental heads to provide us by Tuesday, 18 March with an implementation plan for the transition to the new structure. I will advise the House as soon as practicable after that.

name: Mr LEO McLEAY
content: —On indulgence, Mr Speaker, I have to say on behalf of the opposition that we find this not an acceptable way of dealing with this matter. To just announce at 9.30, after half an hours notice to the opposition, that you intend to dramatically change the way the parliamentary departments work here is just not good enough.

name: Mr LEO McLEAY
content: —Members on the other side might say, `No, no, no, but obviously once they have spent more than 12 months in this place they might start to realise that the smartest thing for them to do is not let the ERC decide what will happen in this parliament. Indeed, what they might decide to do—and what I would suggest, Mr Speaker, you might decide to do—is have a little read about what the now government when in opposition said about what were far less dramatic changes that previous Presiding Officers wanted to make in this place.If just by fiat of the Presiding Officers we are going to see the whole nature of the way this parliament has worked for at least the last 50 years change so dramatically, that is not good enough. If your stewardship of the job of being the head of the House of Representatives is to see a short consultation with the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) as the way to do this, I must say to you, Sir, that that is not the way these things have been done in the past and not the way they should be done now. If we are going to change the way this parliament operates, all members on both sides should be taken into your confidence about how that is going to happen.You have come in here and made a short statement about merging the administration of the three service departments. I do not know how you are going to merge it because my recollection of how one needs to do that is maybe we have to have legislation to abolish the three departments because there is legislation that makes it necessary to do that.What is going to happen to the people who run those departments? What is going to happen to the structure of those departments? Is the Joint House Department going to end up going into the Department of the Senate or into the Department of the House of Representatives? Are the Library and Hansard going to go into the House of Representatives or the Senate? What is going to be the outcome for services to members and senators if the Library goes into the Senate? Are the services going to be directed according to the more rapacious manner in which the Senate manages to accrue assets to itself to the detriment of the House of Representatives? Presiding Officers on both sides in this place, and members, have spoken in the past about how it is interesting that the Senate manages to have somewhat the same appropriation as the House of Representatives when there are twice as many people here.

name: Mr LEO McLEAY
content: —More, my colleague says. So, if we are going to have the service departments run by the Senate department, what effect is that going to have on the members of this House?You cannot just come in here and read a short statement at the beginning of a non-broadcast day and say, `That is it. You cannot do that. You might smile and say, `Ive just done it and the governments got the numbers and well do it, but, if you have any due regard for the rights of members here—and you have said on a number of occasions that you see your responsibility as being the person who reflects the rights of members—you need to take members into your confidence.You need to come in here and make a more lengthy statement to this parliament rather than just say, `We are going to absorb the administration of the joint departments. You need to tell us how you are going to do that and you need to at least canvass these ideas before saying—what was it?—it will be in two weeks time. We have not even seen a copy of the statement you have just made. In two weeks time, or something, this is going to happen.In the past when governments and Presiding Officers have looked to get efficiencies out of the parliamentary departments, they have canvassed these things widely. The member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) and I, for instance, put forward a private members bill here some time ago. The government has not even given that time for debate. In the past, Speaker Child brought in legislation to this House which was canvassed, debated widely and then rejected by the Senate. We had widespread debate on that, but all of a sudden now you want to stampede us into agreeing to something in a few weeks time. The short statement you have made here is just a most unacceptable way of dealing with what are going to be the most dramatic changes to the administration of this parliament since the 1930s.It beggars belief that we should be expected to say, `Terrific, go ahead and do it. The opposition believes that there are ways of getting economies of scale out of the parliamentary departments. We said that while in government and we have said that while in opposition. But we think that members on both sides—and members of the government—should not just see this as something that they should be stampeded into.You are the people who will suffer from this. The people who will suffer most from this are members of parliament. Sometimes in debates in this House we have to consider ourselves to be members of parliament, not division cannon fodder for the government or division cannon fodder for the opposition. If being a member of parliament means anything it means having at least some control over what happens in this House and what services are provided to members of this House.Quite frankly, as a member of the House of Representatives, I would not be happy to see the Senate department have absolute control over the manner in which services are provided to members of the House of Representatives. What will happen with the division of responsibilities between the two chambers? What will happen when there are—as you know and as a former Presiding Officer I know—the regular disputes, which do occur, between the two houses? What will happen when the Senate decides, as it normally does, that there is a standard for them and a standard for others? If you divide the assets of the joint departments between the two chamber departments you will find that the appropriation of the Senate will grow fourfold.It also gets down to accountability. The Senate department has a standing Appropriations and Staffing Committee where opposition and government senators sit down with the President and tell the President how the President will spend the money appropriated to the Senate department. Quite frankly, as a member of the House of Representatives, I find it interesting that a group of senators will sit down and decide how they will spend money which in fact will provide services for members of the House of Representatives.Mr Speaker, I did not hear in your paper that you are going to take us into your confidence and set up the same sort of thing for the House of Representatives—I bet you are not. When I was the Speaker I resisted doing that, my colleague the member for Cunningham resisted doing that and former speakers resisted doing that. But we are going to allow senators to decide what will happen to services provided to members.If the break up of the departments is such that Hansard and the Library go to the Senate, what you will see is senators deciding what happens to services that both government and opposition back bench members have to do their jobs. I must say in a cynical fashion that those of us who have been here for more than five minutes—with all due respect to my colleague the member for Canberra (Mr McMullan), who saw the light and left the Senate and came here—know that the Senate will look after itself to the detriment of people here.There are a huge number of issues that we as members of parliament, not as members of the opposition or members of the government, should consider before this is done. Mr Speaker, you have the job of representing us. You are the person in the scheme of things whose job it is, if there is an occasion when the Speaker should be worried as previous speakers were that the Speakers job in the Commons was to talk on behalf of the members of the Commons to the king, to not be stampeded by the ERC but to take us into your confidence about what the government wants to do with the parliamentary departments and seek our concurrence. You need to do that. If you do not do that you will have in fact not fulfilled your responsibilities as the person whose job it is to represent the views of this House.I think if members of parliament in this House find that they do not have some say or some control over the services that are provided, particularly the all important services such as the research service and the Hansard service, and they are going to be run by the Senate department then that is just not acceptable. The whole reason the joint departments arose was so that you got, first, some economies of scale with expanding technology and, second, the Presiding Officers from both chambers were able to have some input into the way those services were delivered.If the President and Mr Evans are going to run some services that are provided here we will not have that input any more. You have not told us what power you will have on behalf of this House to ensure that those services are delivered. These are issues that need to be widely debated. These are issues that members on both sides need to get a full understanding of. They are not issues that we should deal with at half past nine in the morning with a one‐page statement. They are not issues for which we say consultation is a short talk to the Leader of the Opposition one day and the next day come in here and do this.If that is the way you see the job of the Speaker in representing this House to the government then I think you have lost the plot, Mr Speaker. I say that in all seriousness because this will be one of the most important changes in the way this House works to have occurred in the last 50 or 60 years. There may be good and cogent reasons for this to happen. There may be different models from that of just absorbing a couple of acts of parliament—I do not know how you absorb a couple of acts of parliament, but somehow you and the President have found a way to absorb a couple of acts of parliament.This needs far more debate. It at least needs the same debate that we had when previous Presiding Officers considered smaller changes. Mr Speaker, we may not be able to do anything in this House because the government members may be willing to be stampeded into what the government wants to do, but we will certainly have a lot to do and say about this when it gets to the Senate. Mr Speaker, if you and the President want to get some movement on this issue then far more widespread discussion might ensure that there is some movement in the Senate. At present I can say fairly clearly that our point of view is that there will not be any movement. There certainly will not be movement in the next couple of weeks if that is what you think.This is a profound change to the way the House of Representatives and the parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia will work; and because it is such a profound change it is something that you do not do at half past nine on a Wednesday morning on a non‐broadcast day after a short discussion with the Leader of the Opposition. We want far more discussion of this. We have proposals to put to you and the government—if the government is driving this, and I am sure it is—about how this system ought to work. There are models such as the one put forward by previous Presiding Officers. There are models like the New Zealand model with a parliamentary commission where members on both sides sit with the Presiding Officers and have some say in how their house will work.Most certainly, Mr Speaker, you would be letting down this House if you went through with this proposal in the way you have briefly spoken about today. The proposal ensures that members of this House have fewer rights than members of the other house will have. Under this plan that you have put forward here we most certainly will have fewer rights. Neither government nor opposition members will have a chance to say to you what we think about how the services that are provided in this building work, but senators will.I would imagine that one of the first problems Madam President is going to have if she made the same sort of speech in the Senate 15 minutes ago is that the first thing the senators will say is, `Has this been to the Appropriations and Staffing Committee? They seem to think that they ought to be consulted about everything that moves over there. That might be rightly so, but I think it is a bit rich that they will get that say and we will not. Your duty, Mr Speaker, is to ensure that we get that say; to ensure that this House is not stampeded into something in a few weeks time which will be to the detriment of the institution of the House of Representatives. If this goes ahead quickly like this it will be to the detriment of this institution.I have spent 18 years of my life here; I originally came to this place thinking it was pretty stuffy and probably ought to be blown up. Mr Speaker, you have achieved that objective in that short time. What you are going to do is blow it up. If what happens is as you have just said to us, then we are really in a position where members have had no say in what happens to what is the pre‐eminent house of parliament in this country—the House of Representatives. You will hand over control of services to the Senate and if a serious altercation between the houses of parliament occurs this House may not be the pre‐eminent house. Because governments of the day are unlikely to have a majority in the Senate in the foreseeable future—as they have not for the past 20 odd years—there is always the chance that that will happen.The Senate thought about that and, as you are probably aware, Mr Speaker, in recent years have ensured that, if the House of Representatives Presiding Officers ever decided that they wanted to restrict things for the Senate, the Senate had a whole range of things they could do themselves. They had their own printing operation over there long before this House did. They had a self‐contained operation which would ensure that the Senate maintained its independence.Absorbing these things into the chamber departments, as you say, will, I believe, impinge on some of the independence that the House of Representatives has. You might say that I am wrong. You might be right; I might be right. But that certainly is a matter that should be debated and looked at when we know all the facts. A one‐page statement at half past nine on a Wednesday morning allows no one to know the facts. That is not doing your duty on behalf of all of us. I do not say that in a nasty fashion. You have done your job as the Speaker of this House very well. You have been willing to say to the government that you think some things should be done differently. I am not trying to set you up in conflict with the government, but the government should understand this. Indeed the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) had numerous arguments with me and my colleagues who were Presiding Officers in the past about how this House ought to run, and he has been here longer than most of us have—since 1974. Someone who has been here for over 20 years and professes a great love for this institution should indeed take us into his confidence about how he wants to change it.This is a disgraceful way of doing this. I am sure it is not being done deliberately by you but by pressures from elsewhere. You and Madam President should resist these pressures at least long enough for everybody to understand what we are talking about. If the government then wants to come in here and do the opposition and Independents over on a point of view that we have, at least we will know what we are arguing about. At least we will know where you stand. At present we do not know any of this.I would seriously say to you, Mr Speaker, that you should find some way of saying that this was an advisory notice you have given us here this morning and that you as the Speaker will ensure that you will advise members widely and that there will be a debate on this. I know when my colleague the member for Cunningham wanted to change the way the parliamentary departments worked, he circulated members widely; I know when I wanted to, I circulated members widely; I know when Speaker Child wanted to, she circulated members widely. I must admit that at one stage I did think of an ambush, of coming in here earlier and saying, `Ive done it. Even I thought that was a bit rich; so that says something, doesnt it? Mr Speaker, I would hate to think that you have picked up even the worst traits that I ever had. Maybe you have gone up in my estimation—I do not know.I would seriously say to you that you cannot change the way the parliament works by stealth, and I know that you are not wanting to do that. But the reality is you are changing the parliament by stealth and you are doing it without consulting in any meaningful way with members. I do not know, you may have had consultation with the government. But the only consultation that I know of on this side is a short conversation with the Leader of the Opposition and with no-one else. I think you need to do far more than that.I can see that the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr McGauran), who is at the table, has not even seen this statement, and I thought the minister had seen everything—although one probably would not give anything to the National Party because they cannot read unless there are pictures on it.Mr Speaker, I would hope that you might say that what you have just done here now is to bring this to our attention, that you will be circulating us before the end of the week with what these proposals are and that there will be an opportunity for some considerable debate. If the government wants to do this quicker, then you should put this squarely in their court. The Prime Minister can be asked what his view of this is. If his view is that he wants to change the House of Representatives by 9.30 fiat, then we find that fascinating. We had some changes that we thought we ought to make to the constitution about whether Australia becomes a republic or whether you ought to do things like this, and the Prime Minister said, `Weve got to have national, wonderful, incredible debate—and that is right. But if we are going to change the way the House of Representatives in the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia works, then that surely is worth a little bit of debate because in the scheme of things that is just as important.If this House is going to find that all of a sudden its rights and its modus operandi with the other house change dramatically—and this will change it dramatically—then that is something all members should be very much concerned about. If this means that the Senate President will have unfettered power to do certain things which could impinge on the way this House works, then you, sir, have a responsibility to ensure that does not happen.If the role of the Speaker means anything in protecting the rights of members, then you have an obligation to do provide that protection. We all have an obligation of understanding what you want to do and how far we want to participate in that. I found and my colleagues found that the only way that you were ever going to seriously get some change here was if you tried to get everybody into your confidence.I can say to you, Mr Speaker, and you can tell the President that you do not get to change things that easy in the Senate. We might find ourselves in the interesting position this time of taking the speeches that were made by the government and repeating them back to them in that chamber. If it was not right in the past to do this after long and involved consultation, it is certainly not right to do it in an ambush like this.Mr Speaker, I would ask you on behalf of the opposition to reconsider your position. I would ask you to take all members—government and non-government—of this parliament into account in making any of these changes. While we have such a large number of new members on both sides, it is even more important, and incumbent upon you, to ensure that they understand what has happened. This is not something that should happen in response to some decision that the ERC has made.If the government believes that the parliament matters that little, then I think that is a sad commentary on what the government does. If the Prime Minister, who has stood up in this House year in and year out and talked about the importance of this House, thinks that to change all this by ambush is the way to do it, then my view of him as a parliamentarian has significantly changed. The one thing that I have always had for John Howard—I might not have liked the things that he said or did—is a lot of respect for the view that he often took in here as a parliamentarian. If the Prime Minister is a parliamentarian of any regard and if he has any love of the way this House works, then the government should ensure that there is far more discussion and that everybody understands just what we are doing.

name: Mr McGAURAN
content: —My comments will be briefer than the almost 30 minutes taken by the member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay). I consider his comments premature and unfair—premature because we wish to extend to the Speaker the courtesy of awaiting details of the proposal before commenting on its merits. It seems to me, looking at the statement by the Speaker, that the member for Watson is right that the government had no prior notice of this statement. It is not a government conspiracy, as you alluded to at different times, and is certainly not involving the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) least of all. This is a proper initiative by the Speaker.The Speaker concludes by saying that he will `advise the House as soon as practicable. The point is he will involve the House. We have full confidence in the Speakers preparedness to consult. But, on the issue of consultation, always remember that you will never garner a unanimity of view from this chamber—there are so many different points of view as to sitting hours, to the conduct of standing orders and the like. The Speaker, as is rightly the case, has the final decision. Some of those decisions may be hard or otherwise as he seeks to meet his objective, as he says in his statement, of `increasing demands for services at a time of budgetary restraint. The member for Grayndler has been unfair. He has employed—I appreciate that a number of points he made were very fair, reasonable and legitimate—

name: Mr MARTIN
content: —I do not think anybody in this place is frightened of change. Certainly from this side of the parliament, as my colleague the member for Watson (Mr Leo Mcleay) has clearly demonstrated, on previous occasions it has been the Labor Party, when in government, that has sought to bring about some change in the way in which this parliament is managed. Both you, Mr Speaker, and Madam President, as part of the way in which our parliamentary arrangements currently operate, have very important responsibilities in that respect.The member for Watson alluded to the fact that on previous occasions Speaker Child, himself as Mr Speaker, and me as the Speaker in the last parliament endeavoured to bring before this place legislative changes which would bring efficiencies to the way in which the parliament operates. I do not think anyone disputes that that is necessary. I do not think anyone disputes that there is duplication. There are five government departments on the hill that look after the affairs of state with the parliament. Within each of those five departments there are separate human resources areas and separate pay areas—a whole range of areas where there is duplication.Behind driving change under previous Presiding Officers has been the desire to ensure that efficiencies were there, that it delivered some savings but that those savings would go back into ensuring that in no way was the opportunity for members and senators to carry out their responsibilities diminished. I think this is a paramount issue in this debate. The member for Watson has rightly talked about apparent disparities between the Senate and the House of Representatives and fears that he genuinely holds about the Senate driving the House of Representatives.We need to get an unequivocal assurance, Mr Speaker, not only from yourself, as the guardian of all of our concerns here in the premier parliament of Australia, but also from the government on this matter. Make no mistake about it, there is a very clear nexus between the parliamentary departments and the government. What the government wants at the end of the day the government will achieve, because the government allocates the funds for parliamentary departments. The concern we have is to ensure that any efficiencies which you, Mr Speaker, and Madam President drive in getting rational approaches to the delivery of services in this place do not diminish the ability of us as parliamentarians to do our job.There is a lot going on in Australia at the minute, there is a lot going on in the parliament and there is a lot of debate raging at the present time about members of parliament. There is a debate about entitlements and about what we do as members of parliament. It is all well and good out there for public mythology to believe that most of us do not do an honest days work for an honest days pay, that we are all out there with our snouts in the trough and dipping into the public purse. I refute that. Most members of parliament certainly take the opportunity, whenever they are talking to schools or to the public, to refute that. Most members of parliament that I know work, on average, 70 to 80 hours a week. They do a long, hard and arduous task on behalf of their constituents, not for any self‐gratification that they may get. I will always defend members of parliament right across the chambers on that very point.Therefore, I do not want to see any of these issues associated with making efficiencies in the operation of the parliamentary departments being driven by perhaps polling, or perceptions that the government has, that in some way this is going to make members of parliament look different in the eyes of the electorate at large. Our opportunities to work on behalf of our constituents, and more broadly the people of Australia, cannot be diminished in that respect.Also, as a former presiding officer, I know the difficulties that you are faced with in running your department. I know, for example, that in the last election campaign the present government went to the people of Australia promising that there was going to be a $10 million cut imposed on the five parliamentary departments if they were elected to office. They saw some efficiencies that were required there, but they did not know what it meant. They simply said you were going to have to cut back on the amount of money which you expended in those departments.In the case of the Department of the House of Representatives there was a $2 million cut required of them. I have to say, in one of the more selfless tasks I have ever seen, a senior public servant in an SES band was given responsibility by the Clerk of this department to examine how those savings might be achieved. At the end of the day, in a great act of selflessness, he actually recommended that his position be eliminated—and it was, and he left. The department saved an enormous amount just in one SES salary. He also recommended changes which the Clerk had to put in place—at great personal heartburn to himself because, as a departmental head, he had responsibility for ensuring that the services to the department and to the parliament were not undermined to any great extent and, of course, he had a great feeling for the people who worked in the place.The abilities of our parliament here and the House of Representatives committee structure, and so on, had to be examined. So we now see smaller secretariats looking after a couple of parliamentary committees in the one hit. They have had to say, `We cant do extensive examinations of issues because we havent got the staff or the resources, we havent got the travel budgets, and so on, to enable members of parliament to conduct their business as it should be done. This is one of the sad reflections of what happened.We know that the ERC is continuing to look at the process of driving efficiencies across all government departments, and the parliamentary departments, in no way, are going to be left out of that. It is all well and good for my good friend and colleague the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr McGauran) to stand up in here and say that this has all been driven by the President and the Speaker and that the government knew nothing about it.I have to say this, Mr Speaker. You achieved one thing which I never did as the Speaker, my colleague the member for Watson never did, and I do not think Speaker Child or Speaker Jenkins ever did. You actually got, with Madam President, to the ERC to argue a case on behalf of the parliamentary departments. I understand you had that opportunity last Thursday, if my information is correct, and I congratulate you for that. We used to have to rely on the Minister for Finance to go into an ERC and argue for parliamentary departments appropriations. That is not exactly a great recommendation because all Ministers for Finance are looking for cuts, not necessarily looking for support for those particular departments. But you have been there and have been given an opportunity to argue the case on behalf of the members you represent in this chamber. Do not forget, you have been elected, Mr Speaker, to represent the members interests in this place. That is what the Speakers position is all about. You have obviously been there with Madam President and she has put some points of view as far as the Senate is concerned and as far as the other parliamentary departments are concerned.When I put a question to you earlier this week—and you might reflect on this as well—about whether or not you felt you might achieve some more success in some of the discussions that were ongoing about improvements to the parliament and how the services of members and senators and the parliamentary departments more generally could be delivered, I suggested that you might have a little better success with the Senate if any of these changes required legislation. At the time you indicated to me that there was a possibility of some consultative group being established and I put a supplementary question to you about whether the opposition would be involved in that and you indicated that it would be.I thought that was a great suggestion. It took a few people by surprise because I do not think anybody really knew that was on the go. We thought that was great because we thought, on our side at least, that, if the changes that we had tried to make in previous parliaments were going to be achieved, then clearly we would have a role to play and we could have some negotiations and put a point of view. As my friend the member for Watson said, he and I, and those on this side of the parliament, have tried to do much of this in the past but have always got knocked over in the Senate.If you have been able to achieve some radical change in creating just two departments out of five, then clearly you seem to have some indication from government that they are going to support that. It seems to me that that means the senators have been put on board because it was coalition senators who knocked off the last three proposals in this regard.The member for Aston (Mr Nugent) is sitting up the back. He is one of the true believers of parliamentary reform. In the parliament before last, the member for Watson, as Speaker, asked the member for Aston, an opposition member, to chair an inquiry into the way in which we wanted to see some changes brought into the operation of the parliament so that efficiencies could be achieved, parliamentary departments could be collapsed down and some recommendations could be made as to how that might actually work for the betterment of this place.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr Leo McLeay
content: —Consultation.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr MARTIN
content: —Consultation was the hallmark of the report which was brought down. Interestingly, there was a minority report as part of it. That minority report was brought down on behalf of coalition senators and also, I seem to remember, a Democrats senator—who is no longer with us—who were got to by people on the other side of the building. Dare I say that it was the Clerk—I shouldnt, but it probably was—who convinced them that this was the start of all evilness, that this was the start of the evil empire where there was going to be only one parliamentary department and that any influence that he might have in the operation of the parliament may in fact be dissipated if in fact he did not get a say.He convinced the coalition senators about this and, of course, they refused to deal with it over there. At that time, the Leader of the Opposition was weak enough to say, `Well, all right, Im not going to take my own senators on about this. I think it is fair to say that the member for Aston, the member for Watson and I—because it fell on me to implement the recommendations that flowed from the member for Astons report—actually brought a bill before this parliament to effect some of that change. It got through this House with no dramas at all. The government had the numbers and we were right. But it got over to the Senate, and there it lay.My colleague and former President of the Senate at the time, Senator Sibraa, no matter how many discussions he had with Greens senators, Democrats senators, Independent senators and, dare I say, even coalition senators, could not get them to budge to even get it on the Notice Paper for consideration in that chamber at the time. So it lapsed with the passage of time and with the lapsing of the parliament.Then, early last year, I brought in a private members bill which sought to bring about three parliamentary departments from the five, and it sat on the Notice Paper . The government refused to give it priority to be brought on for debate. Yet now, as my colleague the member for Watson has remarked, here we have it on a Wednesday morning. You have come into the parliament and made a one‐page statement about how you believe this matter is to be resolved, that there will be a new structure that will be in place and that, by Tuesday, 18 March, your departmental heads will tell you how you can get the transition to that structure.I would read into that—I hope I am right on this—that that report will come before you saying how the implementation might work in a practical sense. I am not sure of this. I would hope that, at some stage, as has been suggested, that can be addressed. The practi cal mechanism is one element, but we have to consider how it can be achieved when you have acts of parliament, which have established the five parliamentary departments on this hill, that need to be amended to get down to the two departments that you are proposing.As I said, I do not have a great problem with change. I do not think that I will have, necessarily, a great problem with what has been proposed to get two departments. As long as the House of Representatives has certainly equal, if not a little stronger, influence on the way in which this might work in a practical sense, that is going to be fine. Originally, as I said, I put a proposal forward that had a third department, which, with the Department of the Library, the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff and the Joint House Department in one, provided the physical services, parliamentary information and so on.I thought that was a reasonable opportunity, but I am not dissuaded from what is being proposed. I just wonder, in part of the broader consideration of this, whether maybe we need to do what the member for Watson suggested; that is, have a bit more time for reflection and consultation about the methodology of this. We would like to know if legislative change is necessary. I think it probably will be. I think it has to be. You cannot just get rid of statutory departments by saying, `Were going to amalgamate these and just leave it up in the air. You have people such as parliamentary librarians and secretaries of joint house departments and the departments themselves, which are actually created as departments of state, already there.So if you are eliminating those, you must have legislative change to bring that about. We would like to know what that is all about. But, in terms of the broader overarching control of this, the member for Watson alluded to New Zealands parliamentary experience. I would also commend to you the board of management concept in the House of Commons and the House of Lords in the UK. From my recollection of the way that works, it was effective in as much as you had people from both sides of the parliament contributing as part of that. You also had the opportunity for things like some of the existing committees to continue to operate.One of the other practical elements of the implementation of this runs to the committee structure which is in place to oversight the way some of these departments presently work. The Joint House Committee, for example, the Library Committee, and I think there was a PISO committee, too, which was operating for a period, certainly in an advisory sense to the Presiding Officers. We would want to know whether there will still be an opportunity for people of the parliament—that is, the members themselves—to contribute in that sense to the way in which these departmental committees are run.My friend here the member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones), for example, has been a great contributor to the parliamentary Library Committee over a long period. I think on both sides of the parliament it would be recognised that if the opportunity was not taken to use his great ability for contribution in that sense, if that was eliminated as part of this overall structure proposal, that would be a very sad thing for the parliament. The board of management concept in the UK parliament probably still gives us the opportunity to keep those departmental committees going and to provide an opportunity for the members of parliament still to contribute to the way they want their own parliament to run.It is all well and good for our friends in the ERC to talk about bottom‐line figures and how we are going to get cost savings and so on. Given that I have suggested and tried to implement some of these myself, I am not averse to that—I say that to the Leader of the House (Mr Reith). I have talked to him about this in the past and suggested to him that if he wanted to achieve some of these savings the easiest way would have been to bring on my private members bill last year to give it a bit of a run to see how it would go. You would have gone down to three departments and some rationalisation and savings would have been made.But this will go a bit further. Our basic concern, of course, as has been expressed by the member for Watson, is the consultative process involved in this so that the members themselves have ownership of the end product. It is a simple fact of management that if you can get the participants in the process—and the Leader of the House as the Minister for Industrial Relations would know something about this now—to eventually have ownership of the outcome then it is a much easier concept to sell. We would certainly want an opportunity to participate in looking at how the implementation of this is going to work.Mr Speaker, as I and the member for Watson have said, you have achieved something which it would seem we have been unable to do in previous parliaments. That shows a little more of the resolve of the government of the day to give some assistance to that. But what we do not want to see is this being driven by ERC concerns for bottom line figures.As the member for Watson rightly said, it was all well and good for first‐time members of parliament, who were in here earlier after the statement was read, to start to heckle a little bit when we expressed some reservations about this. It is all well and good for those who have been here for five minutes to think, `This is great! Our government is doing something terrific, and all the rest of it. What they should think about is their responsibilities in representing the people of Australia in this place and having the facilities to be able to do that. We do not want to see that diminished. When they are here a bit longer, they will suddenly realise that that is the case.Mr Speaker, you are in the difficult position of trying to find that $2 million savings here in the House of Representatives, let alone in the other departments that you and Madam President have joint responsibility for. But when you get down to nitpicking things like reducing down to one a day the newspaper allocation for backbenchers in this place, then this is cause for concern. My colleague the member for Watson reminds me that, whilst you have taken that decision to reduce our allocation down to one newspaper, the senators get three.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr Barry Jones
content: —Plus the press clippings.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr MARTIN
content: —Yes, as I am reminded by the member for Lalor, the political clippings that come out on a daily basis also go to senators as well. It is a fact of life that information drives us all. The decisions we make are based on receiving appropriate information. One way to do it, whether or not we like the tenor of some of the stories—I will not go into some of the ones in the Illawarra Mercury today—is to go to the information base and you will see that that still provides us with the basis of much of what helps shape our opinions and what we subsequently determine to vote on.I wrap up my contribution, and I am sorry that I have delayed the House a little longer than I had anticipated, by simply making a few points. We think that there is a need for more consultation—I try to say it in very much a bipartisan, apolitical way—for the parliament. We think there is a need for more consultation so that you, Mr Speaker, and Madam President can take the parliament—that is, the House of Representatives and the Senate—into your own confidence on this matter so that we have a fuller understanding of what is intended here.We do not have a philosophical problem about making changes, and we are not opposed to change. My record and the record of the member for Watson stand on this; we have tried to achieve this ourselves. So we are not opposed to it, but we want that consultation process. We want to see what it means for members and senators. We want to ensure that we have that opportunity to make that contribution. We do not, however, want to see you and Madam President being driven by bottom line ERC considerations.The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has always said that he believed the parliament was paramount; he believed the parliament was the chart maker of the destiny of this country. What we do not want to see is some small collection of ministers driven by people concerned with bottom lines and deficits and all the rest of it—although that is very important, and we do not dispute that. But if you are going to make savings by amalgamations of departments, then surely you can still contribute to the governments bottom line deficit reduction strategy and at the same time not continue a slash and burn policy within the parliamentary departments and the other departments.We as members have to be able to service our constituencies. We have to be able to service more broadly the people of Australia. As I have said before, if you look at the history of the way in which parliamentary committees and the House of Representatives have been effective conduits of information to governments and how governments have acted on that, you will see that you do not reduce those resources—you use them more fully.I say to the two ministers who are at the table here today: reports that the member for Lalor has brought down, reports of people like the former Attorney-General Michael Lavarch, when he was chairman of the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee, reports of the committee which I had the great pleasure to chair on Finance, Banking and Public Administration, which the Sergeant‐at‐Arms was secretary to at one stage, and reports of other members in this place have, over time, made a contribution to the government of this country and to improvements in the lifestyles of the people of this country. To eliminate those opportunities, to just snaffle out any of the creativeness that comes from members of parliament operating in those sorts of forums, is short‐sighted—very short‐sighted. We should not be driven by ERC considerations.We would like to think that your statement today is flagging a statement of intent. We on our side would like to think that—
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr Barry Jones
content: —Its the beginning of the process.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr MARTIN
content: —That it is the beginning of the process, that consultation is going to occur with all members of this place. We would like to think that the government will facilitate that. We would like to think that what you have suggested here—that on 18 March you will be given an opportunity to receive from departmental heads an implementation plan on how this might work—will form the second tranche of this consultation process.We would like to think that you will bring it to the parliament and do what was suggested in your statement to me in answer to a question: form a committee with people from both sides—I am sure that you will get cooperation from our side of the parliament—to look at what has been proposed so that the objectives of both achieving efficiencies in the way this place operates and eliminating duplication are accomplished at the same time as not having a negative impact on the way in which members and senators can perform their rightful, elected duties to the people of Australia.If you can achieve that tripartite objective, then you have done well. We will give you full support on that, but we want that consultation. The member for Aston (Mr Nugent) can give you a bit of advice if you call him in. He has been involved in this. He is about to give you some advice when I sit down. I welcome that contribution as well.It is important that we do not lose sight of the paramount importance of this chamber. The member for Watson said that it is the most important chamber of all parliaments in Australia. He is dead right—it is. We have a duty and you, Mr Speaker, have a duty as the head of this chamber and as the head of your department to ensure that that supremacy, that paramount nature of this parliament, is upheld at every opportunity. We want further consultation. It is our right as members of parliament to have that further consultation, and we hope it occurs.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr NUGENT
content: —I would like to say to the previous speaker that, given the testimonial he afforded me during his comments, I am sure he will accept my statement that I had no prior knowledge that this was coming up this morning. I came out of a committee meeting, went back to my office, looked up at the television screen and said to myself words to the effect of, `What on earth is that all about? I listened a bit and then came down.I do have a significant interest in this particular matter for the sorts of reasons that were alluded to. However, I do have to correct one thing in particular that the previous speaker mentioned: I do not think, when I became chair of that committee three or four or five years ago, that I was appointed by the member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay), who was then the Speaker. The committee was set up under his tutelage and, certainly, it was set up with a majority of non‐government members. I think I was actually nominated by the then opposition; the opposition whip may have had something to do with that particular activity. But I was chair of that committee. It had a majority of non‐government members, it deliberated for some length of time and it made certain recommendations in terms of mergers of some of the departments. It had a specifically limited brief, which was not as broad as the proposals that I understand you are bringing into the House now. Nevertheless, it certainly came out with a majority recommendation that there should be mergers. There was a minority report from three senators: two from the coalition and one from the Democrats. Subsequently, the matter stalled on its way through, as we have already heard.It seemed to me that, as we went through the assessment of merging the departments, there were a great number of benefits to be achieved through such a merger. At that time we were looking particularly at merging the Department of the Parliamentary Library and the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff—Hansard. We were not looking at the Joint House Department at that stage, although options had been looked at previously. It seemed to me there were considerable advantages in what we were going to do. We identified some specific dollar savings and, at that time, we got an assurance from the then government that those savings would be ploughed back into the parliament for further development of services for senators and members. That, of course, was a major attraction about the process.In terms of supporting the principle of rationalisation or mergers, such as your statement has put before the chamber today, there are a couple of things that need to be said. Obviously, the statement you have provided us with is fairly broad and I will await with great interest the details of how you intend to achieve the objectives you have laid before us. But it seems to me that, in looking at what you are proposing to do, there is a very important question of balance. Historically, the Senate has been the chamber that has jealously guarded its rights, its entitlements and so on. I am sure that I do not need to remind you but, for the record, I will say that I think it is important that the House of Representatives makes sure that, in any new arrangement, it is appropriately structured and supported in any joint arrangement. This is the chamber where governments are formed and this is the chamber the Prime Minister comes from. This chamber needs to ensure that it is adequately and properly supported in every sense of the word. That is something that you will have a heavy responsibility for in terms of the plans that will be brought forward.I am interested to see, Mr Speaker, that you are suggesting the merger of the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff, the Library—and, for the benefit of those in the gallery, the Library is not just a collection of books: it is also a major research service which, in many ways, is a more important function than just the collection of books—and the Joint House Department, which looks after all of the housekeeping and maintenance of the building. The practicalities of merging those and putting them under the control of the two chamber departments, the Senate and the House of Representatives, will present some unique challenges. I await with great interest the clear ingenuity that will obviously be needed to achieve success in that because you are talking about common services being split in some shape or form to provide separate services to senators and to members of the House of Representatives. Whilst I do not see too many problems in terms of the mechanics of splitting some elements, such as the reporting staff and maybe the library, when it comes to matters of security, building maintenance and so on there will be a necessity for some standardisation between the two chambers, probably more in terms of taking away things that the Senate might hold unto itself. It will be an interesting set of negotiations.Having said that, I think it is important that we do, from time to time, look at new struc tures. The structure for this parliament has been in place for many years and there is no doubt in my mind, from the previous exercise that I conducted as the chair of the committee that looked at merging some of those departments, that there are overwhelming reasons to rationalise, merge and restructure some of the departments in this building. A lot of those savings can be made purely and simply by doing away with some of the duplication of functions between departments, by streamlining administration and by not having to get duplicate sets of advice, duplicate sets of information and duplicate sets of consultants to advise different departments on different things. There is a lot of streamlining that will go on which will not only make dollar savings, which is obviously important in the current climate, but will also make efficiency savings and will help the chambers run more effectively.So, in principle, Mr Speaker, I am a great supporter of what you are trying to do. I echo the comments of the previous speaker that both he and the member for Watson, as former occupants of your chair, tried to tread this route. They are to be commended for that; but they were unsuccessful. If you have found a way of going down that route more successfully, that is to your credit. I look forward to the details of the plan.I would just like to make the point on which I think the previous speaker and I—and I am sure most members of this chamber—would have common ground. Although dollar savings are important and although efficiencies are important the paramount thing that you—and I am sure that you are aware of this—and those responsible for implementing the detail of such a plan need to bear in mind is ultimately the service of the members.These days we all understand that being a member of this chamber is a very hard, professional, full‐time job. Increasingly, because of the demands and the public scrutiny, and because of the frequent calls on your time in a whole range of areas, you do need comprehensive support in this place. It is important that the quality and quantity of that support for members is not diminished in any way although, obviously, savings and efficiencies can be made.I conclude, Mr Speaker, by saying that I commend your initiative. I wish you luck in steering the matter through. I know that all members of this chamber would wish to be informed and hopefully participate in some of the further detail. I await the detail with interest and I look forward to the parliament making a major step forward when it is able to achieve efficiencies and rationalisations of this nature.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr McMULLAN
content: —This statement raises a large number of questions, many of which I would like to have the opportunity to traverse today but the Leader of the House (Mr Reith) has requested, not unreasonably, that I constrain my remarks and I will therefore not traverse any of the matters raised so extensively by my colleagues the member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) and the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin). I want to raise essentially new matters having had a few concerns, particularly in my capacity as the member for Canberra.Having had the opportunity to serve both in the Senate and here I can see some of these issues perhaps from a different perspective from some of my colleagues. What concerns me is that while from before I came to the parliament, certainly from the day I arrived, I thought the five‐department structure was absurd, on the face of it, Mr Speaker, I have to say that you seem to have come up with an equally absurd proposal—but I hope when the detail emerges that does not prove to be the case. I am sure you have thought it through and there will be some indication of how what looks on the face of it to be not an adequate alternative will develop to be so. I merely endorse the remarks made by my colleagues about the need for a fuller explanation and an opportunity for consultation.One of the two phrases in the statement that caught my attention and surprised me was the phrase `we have decided rather than `we are putting forward a proposition that or `we would like the House and the Senate to consider the following proposal. But that has been adequately traversed by others. The other phrase is `make significant savings. I have been here for nine years and I have been in public political life for 20 years; and I know what that code means. It means that the over 1,000 people who work in this building are in serious trouble. Their job security is under serious threat. That is what it means.I am concerned that you have announced here today `we have decided and I wonder what consultation there has been with those people who work in this building and with their representatives, the trade unions which represent them in this place. Many of these people live in my electorate and the electorates of my colleagues the member for Namadgi (Ms Ellis) and the member for Fraser (Mr Dargavel)—and also of course the member for Eden Monaro (Mr Nairn).I am sure they would share my concern that we have here a proposition that will dramatically affect immediately not only the security, confidence and optimism but in the very short term perhaps also the jobs of a large number of Australians, not in most cases highly paid. They will go into a labour market here in the ACT in the south‐east New South Wales region that is severely depressed and is correctly described by Access Economics as in recession. So I am very worried about what is proposed and its implications for those people. I am particularly concerned—and not having had the chance to speak to you, Mr Speaker, I do not want to assume this—because, as on the face of it the government did not know about it and the opposition did not know about it, it seems to me highly unlikely that there has been opportunity for consultation with those 1,000 people most directly affected. It is their jobs that are so politely affected by these code words `make significant savings. Everybody knows what it means.It is a serious intent. We do have to take care of the taxpayers money. We cannot simply go on running duplication and having five departments doing what a smaller number can do but these are Australians with the right to have their interests considered when major changes are made that affect their capacity to earn their income and where they face the prospect, if they cannot retain their existing employment, of being thrown onto a labour market already thrust into recession by previous decisions.I have not spoken about the complex questions of the parliamentary implications of this. I feel strongly about it and I would want to participate in the discussion about it. I think the small number of us who have served in both houses can contribute something to that from an interesting perspective. But that has been discussed at length and we are unduly taking time to duplicate it. I simply wanted to add to the concerns properly raised by the three previous speakers my concern about the prospects and consequences of these changes and the process of their implementation for the over 1,000 people who work in this building.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr SPEAKER
content: —I thank the honourable member for Canberra.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr REITH
content: —Whilst I appreciate that this is on indulgence, after discussions with the opposition I think the proposition is that I will close the debate as best I can but that there will be further discussions informally on the matter during the day. I should say that my initial reaction is to say that you have shown a firm direction for some changes to the supportive administrative arrangements for the parliament and I would think there would be a lot of support for your initiative in terms of reforms to those administrative arrangements. I think that was well put by the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) when he made the point that some of these issues have been the subject of a lot of discussion over many years and in a sense you have taken the bull by the horns and come in this morning with a very clear proposed framework for reform to be undertaken.There is, of course, much merit in this particular proposition, but I confine my remarks to the most generalised sense as there have been a number of reform options developed over the years—and I speak ad lib and without an opportunity to prepare in any detail. The House of Commons, I think, went for a sort of megaservice department and two—lower house and upper house—departments, but that was a scheme that did not work. There are other Commonwealth parliaments that provide a steer as to the effectiveness of administrative arrangements, and the one that you have proposed I know from my past reading on this is certainly a viable option and would have much merit to it. Obviously that has been a factor you have taken into account in putting the proposition.I do, however, accept the point which opposition members have made that it is important to provide people with real detail as to what lies behind this proposition because there are some very genuine areas of concern which people will have. The jobs issue, of course, is very important; the service to members is important, and there are other matters that go to the balance between the houses which I suspect will also be the subject of concern—and proper concern at that.It is sometimes difficult, in looking at possible restructures, to know whether you should proceed with a planning stage and not tell people what your end objective is or whether you should tell people what your end objective is and then get the details done in a much more transparent way. You have opted for the up‐front transparent setting of the goal and a process to meet that goal. By having a relatively short timetable, I presume your intention is to minimise uncertainty in the minds of those who might be affected. I think uncertainty for people, particularly when it comes to jobs, is a real problem for people, most understandably, so I think that must lie behind what you have said.I must also say, Mr Speaker, that whilst we did receive a phone call this morning at approximately 9.20 that there would be a statement from you at 9.30, I was not aware of the contents of that statement except in the broadest terms of `something to do with administration. The fact that it was the announcement that it is was not known to me until I had completed my official duties at Government House at a meeting of the Executive Council and walked into this parliament at a quarter past ten or thereabouts.I do think it is important that there be some consultation on this. It is obviously a matter which affects every member. Ultimately these administrative arrangements can go to matters of great constitutional import as to the balance between the houses and the independence of the houses. There will be a lot of interest in this proposal.I do not propose to say any more than that, Mr Speaker, but, to reiterate my point, I do think that reform has been the subject of a lot of discussion over the years but has not really materialised. Certainly, with the President, you have taken a very firm lead. I think that will be generally welcomed, but it will also be important to the process that there be full and thorough consultation on the way in which the matter is now proceeded with.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr SPEAKER
content: —I thank the Leader of the House and all those who have participated in this unexpectedly long debate this morning. I thank you all for your contributions. Much of what has been covered will become clearer subsequent to 18 March. But be aware that the deliberations have been ongoing now for seven or eight months; it is not driven by the ERC.Shortly after we—that is, the President and I—took up our appointments on our election subsequent to the election last year, it became imperative that the basic organisation of the parliament needed to be reviewed. That has been an ongoing process. It has been deliberated on from within the parliament and without the parliament, and we have certainly taken cognisance of what has happened in the parliaments of Great Britain, Canada and New Zealand, among others.So this is, as acknowledged I think by the member for Cunningham and the member for Watson, perhaps the first shot in what will be an ongoing process. As further information comes to hand, there will be ample opportunity for consultation, not only amongst the members and senators themselves, but at all levels of the parliament. I thank you for your contributions.

Speaker: N/A

name: Mr SAWFORD
content: —As far as manufacturing industry is concerned in this country, this is a government without a skerrick of vision and a government without any commitment whatsoever to manufacturing industry. This is a government that sets no positive outcomes for manufacturing industry. Really it is pretty appalling when you sum up the governments total lack of empathy for and response to manufacturing industry. The whole trinity is actually missing. There is no rationale, there is no process, and there are no positive outcomes. The government has gone missing, the minister has gone missing and, particularly, the backbench has gone missing. This is a government that has dumped on manufacturing industry and simply walked away from their responsibilities.What greater evidence could you submit to support those propositions than the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill 1996? This is a government made up of the same mind‐set as the Fraser government which squandered opportunities for economic and employment growth from 1976 to 1983. This is a government that has learned precious little from the history of the past 50 years. A simple examination of any OECD country from the 1950s tells us that the gap between gross national product and employment is pretty much on a par.But today there is a huge gap, when you look at the graphs, between GNP and the levels of employment. Albeit brief, any analysis of the last 50 years clearly shows the following trends in industry. Firstly, capital investment in real terms has quadrupled. Secondly, energy consumption has tripled and manufacturing output has tripled. But the real catch is that employment has only grown by one-third. The developed world has created a chronic and endemic employment problem of around 10 per cent and growing, whatever governments do with their figures.Current economic orthodoxies will not solve the problem. Rather, they entrench unemployment at the unacceptable present levels. Traditional industries such as textiles and iron, steel and metals processing are all declining in employment, whilst electronics, telecommunications, information technology and biotechnology are growing, but not to the extent to take up the labour surplus.We know the microelectronic industry has spawned whole new industries, but it has also, in a very frightening way, reduced the need for labour throughout the world. Throughout the industrialised world we are substituting capital, energy and increased output for human labour which is in surplus. Traditional economic growth is no longer accompanied by a commensurate increase in the number of jobs.When it comes to the manufacturing industry, this government is simply not a player. It cannot cut the mustard; it is just not in the game. This government has forced the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) to opt out of manufacturing industry. This government has forced the minister to basically wash his hands of, and walk away from, manufacturing industry.It is much worse than that. As the shadow minister for has often pointed out in this House, it not just the axing of the bounties contained in this legislation which betrays the manufacturers of this country. There are also cuts in research and development, significant scaling back of the DIFF scheme, huge cuts to the export market development grants scheme, cuts to Austrade and cuts to AusIndustry. All up, that is about a $4 billion belt around the ears for manufacturing industry over the next four years. That cut of around $4 billion by way of industry support over four years is in the Howard governments first budget. No wonder the manufacturers in this country are a little shell‐shocked and under siege from this government.These decisions are driven by an ideological frenzy that fiscal consolidation will solve this nations problems. It will not. Of course it will not. What will happen will be a loss of economic growth, a loss of jobs and a loss of exports. The signals are very clear. The quarry mentality is back. Value added, manufacturing producing jobs earning dollars from exports cannot get a look in.When the coalition was last in government the number of manufacturing jobs in Australia dropped by eight per cent in one year. This happened in their last year in government. Now it will happen in the first four years, their first years in government. In the past the coalition did not understand manufacturing industry, and they do not understand it now.By contrast, under Labor, manufacturing industry exports grew by a whopping 405 per cent. The No. 1 idea of the new governments policy for business and manufacturing is that the government should get out of the way. The government want no role in business or manufacturing and they appointed a can‐do nothing minister to achieve exactly that.The cabinet has frozen out this minister so that he is so perfunctory that his brain seems to be in deep freeze mode. The government wants to eliminate what it calls `business welfare. The Treasurer (Mr Costello) has stood up in this parliament and called those manufacturers who have claimed the R&D tax concession `tax rorters on more than one occasion. In fact, he seems to take special pleasure in the tax rorters claim. Research and development is cut.A survey of 125 large and medium sized companies revealed that, as a direct result of the decision to cut R&D tax concessions, 34 per cent of companies were considering moving their R&D operations offshore, 57 per cent would reduce their research and development, and many more will now import the technology rather than conduct their own research and development. What a recipe for disaster. This bill axes four industry bounties despite promises to the contrary during the election campaign. It terminates the ships, books, machine tools and robotics bounties.A couple of months ago I asked the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) whether he would refer to his cabinet unemployment committee the impact of the abolition of the book bounty on companies like Griffin Press in Adelaide, where 140 full- and part-time workers were given redundancy notices. It has to be said that he basically avoided giving a real answer in stating that the decisions cannot be disaggregated.The book and publishing industry were operating on the understanding that the bounty would continue until the end of 1997. In fact, contracts, which in this industry operate from periods of up to five years, were entered into on that basis. This government has compromised the ability of this industry to make sensible business decisions.Printing and publishing firms estimate that around 50 per cent of the 2,600 jobs in the industry could be at risk and lost. This is an industry that the book bounty encouraged to increase exports by over 200 per cent. Its premature abolition threatens export earnings, 1,300 jobs and 1,300 families. Opportunities for young Australians are diminished and, basically, it is just a kick in the teeth to the printing and the publishing industry.The abolition of the ships bounty just defies commonsense. The government wants to cut the five per cent support for Australian shipbuilders of vessels, nearly all of which are exported. In the eight years since Labor introduced the bounty, the Australian shipbuilding industry has grown dramatically. It is a world leader in high‐speed catamaran production. Production is up by 200 per cent. Exports are up by 150 per cent. Employment is up by 50 per cent. You would have thought that that is a very good recipe for growth, progress and jobs. But the governments response is to give it a belt around the ears. At five per cent support, Australia could more than compete with Norway, with a subsidy of 13.2 per cent, with Denmark, at 13 per cent, and with Italy, up to 25 per cent. But they cannot compete at zero per cent.Has the government taken into account the fact that the so-called OECD agreement to end shipbuilding subsidies by the end of 1998 will not go ahead now because the USA will not sign up to it? Consistency certainly is no hallmark of this government. The government continued to support the ships capital grants scheme by funding $23 million to help companies like Shell and BHP import ships made in Holland, but it will not help Australian shipbuilders. For a saving of a measly $9 million to the budget, the abolition of the ships bounty cost one company $225 million in lost contracts. The company suffers. The employees suffer. The nation suffers.In addition to the abolition of the book and shipbuilding bounties, the government has terminated the machine tools and robotics bounties and will abolish the computer bounty on 1 July next year. That the computer bounty abolition is to be delayed raises some very interesting possibilities. Is it not the case that the minister has considerable interest in companies that claim the computer bounty?But the impact from this legislation is far greater than books, shipbuilding, machine tools, robotics and computers. It sends a chilling reminder to manufacturing industry, the steel industry—and we are setting up a steel committee—the car industry, the pharmaceutical industry, the plastics industry, the automotive supplier industry, and you could go on and on, that this government simply does not seem to give a damn about them. It is going to hang them out to dry and simply let the market rip.The signals are clear from this legislation that not only will existing manufacturing industry be affected—the ones that improved exports by over 400 per cent under Labor and which secured economic and employment growth directly assisting the battling families this government so fraudulently purports to represent—but it has been a complete vacuum, an empty void, as to what the future holds for industry policy. Where is the government providing leadership to the future enhancement of job growth?Take a simple move to solar energy: that would create jobs. The production of solar collectors for space and water heating includes glass or plastic for the covers, copper, aluminium and steel for the frames and absorber plates, and fibreglass, rigid foam or the wool stockpile for the insulation. All of these are established industries, many working below capacity. The occupations include sheet metal workers, carpenters, plumbers, pipe fitters and construction workers, many working in regional areas.Simply raising the goal of the current five to six per cent of homes with solar heating to 25 per cent—and this has been done in a study by the Australia New Zealand Solar Society—would create 25,000 jobs nationwide, without importing anything. Solar potential in this country remains largely unfulfilled. Incentives are required not only for research and development but also for the manufacturing and marketing on a large scale to make it cost efficient. This country has the potential to be the world leader in and a major exporter of manufactured solar thermal technology.Take another area, weatherisation—energy efficient housing. For every $1 million spent in that area, you get 80 jobs. Again, Australia has the potential to be a world leader.What about public infrastructure? In this country you just want to pull your hair out at the idiocy of transport policies from state and federal governments over the last 30 or 40 years. A German study shows that, when you spend $1 billion on road construction, you create around 10,000 to 14,000 jobs. But if you spent that same $1 billion on heavy rail, you get 22,000 jobs—and we are talking about permanent jobs. If you spend it on light rail, you get 23,000 jobs for the same expenditure—around double the jobs you would get for anything on road construction.Every year in Australia the cost—`subsidy is more correct—for road transport is well in excess of $10 billion. In fact, I think it is more like double that. That is $5 billion we spend on the actual road building and maintenance and $5 billion on the result of road trauma, and goodness knows how much on compensation claims and associated legal costs. Little thought appears to be given to the size of this subsidy for road transport. A country rail line loses $20 million or $30 million and everybody goes feral in this country, but they never apply the same rules to the building of roads.Subsidies for light and heavy rail, as we all know, are not so kindly treated. That does not make sense. It is dumb. It is stupid. A balance is required between all forms of transport. Unlike road building, which imports the road making and the road maintenance equipment and the majority of vehicles that travel upon roads, investment development in heavy and light rail could be 100 per cent Australian—materials, design, manufactured, marketed, exported.We live in an area of the world where many cities in South-East Asia have enormous urban transport problems. Enormous potential exists for the export of cost efficient urban transport systems in our region. I think the Hong Kong light rail system was planned and marketed in Melbourne. It is not only Sydney, Brisbane and Adelaide; it is Taipei, Bangkok, Ho Chi Minh City, et cetera.The fundamental role of any economy is to provide jobs. That is the role of government, and governments around the world are just running away from that responsibility. They replace public good with private good.
