name: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
content: —Here is a real chance for the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) to draw the line. We read in the paper from time to time about his so‐called industry policy. We also read in the paper from time to time about his desire to stand side by side with industry to make sure that not only are they capable of growing on the export front, but also capable of increasing job opportunities in Australia.But the problem is that every time there has been a fight in cabinet to date he has thrown the towel in. He has only been forced to make some concessions as a result of a huge community campaign where the impact has been too high for the government to suffer with respect to their potential electoral prospects. That is why, for example, some changes have already occurred with the bounty legislation.I take the view that the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism is not associated, in his heart, with the anti‐jobs group that is running the cabinet at the moment. He does not want to be associated with people such as the Treasurer (Mr Costello) who have no concerns for mainstream Australia. Under it all, he accepts the need for an industry policy. That is what he keeps telling all the industry groups about. That is why he keeps giving them, under the lap, a campaign strategy to take on the Treasurer and his cohorts in cabinet, the anti‐jobs group that dominates cabinet at the moment.We are lucky. Some of the opposition have been able to get hold of that strategy about where the pressure points are and who you have to pressure to achieve a change in government policy to protect industry and to protect jobs. I am saying to the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism today, `Look my friend, look my mate, we are with you, but you have to have a bit of Dutch courage.Maybe we ought to have this debate after lunch, then you can come back in here reinforced with a desire to fight on—to go for the jugular, to stand up for Australian jobs, to stand up for industry and to stand up for Maryborough because you need a helping hand. I think you want to win, but in some ways you have adopted the view, `I am in my last term of parliament. I have proven that I can be a minister again. With all due respects to the minister, it is not just about the perks and lurks of a ministerial officer; it is really about delivering out there for mainstream Australia. What they are concerned about—I am sure their polling is showing this—is a sense of security with respect to jobs and their ability to look after their families. The minister has to take a stand. He has lost all the fights to date on industry policy.What happened to the tax incentive for research and development? Lost that fight. What happened to the export market development grants scheme or the development import finance facility? Threw the towel in again. Stand up and be counted. Support our amendment on the books bounty. Do something about jobs in regional Australia. Do something about our young people. Say to the member for Bendigo, `Look, dont hide in the corner any longer. Come in here, exercise a bit of courage and put your hand up. Cross the floor and vote for your local community; cross the floor and vote for the security of the 25 per cent of jobs that exist in Maryborough; cross the floor and vote for companies which have a proven track record of being able to deliver the goods, deliver exports and deliver jobs. That is what it is about. Dont be part of the anti‐jobs group that is dominating cabinet at the moment. It is not in your heart. You know better. Embrace the amendment. Adopt a bit of Dutch courage. If you want, we will delay the debate until after lunch so that you can come in here reinforced with the desire to fight.The coalitions abolition of the books bounty six months ahead of its expiry date is wrong. It potentially means 15,000 job losses with a particularly severe impact on regional centres. In all seriousness, this is an amendment that ought to be seriously considered. The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism knows it in his own heart. Stand with us. Vote for regional Australia. Vote for jobs and vote for industry that has a future.

name: Mr CREAN
content: —We have already indicated that the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid), if he has a conscience at all and if he has the interests of his constituency at heart, should be voting with us on this Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill. But there is another that should be voting with us, Minister: the member for Kingston (Ms Jeanes). The problem is that jobs have been lost in South Australia as a result of this ridiculous decision of the government to axe the books bounty. Three hundred jobs have been lost at Griffin Press as a result of the decision you took on budget night.It is not just us expressing concern about the ideological drive that is taking you forward in this way, your inability to win an argument in cabinet. You really support us. That is why you are out there having meetings with the textile industry, telling them, `I cannot win an argument in cabinet. Cabinet is full of dries. I am the only wet amongst those dries. He goes along to these meetings and says these things: `I will tell you what to do. We will get a campaign running. I will help you in this campaign because we have really got to do these fellows in Treasury. We have really got to do these ideologues, because I am on your side. But the trouble is that he cannot stand up to the people in cabinet. He cannot win an argument in cabinet so he has to resort to cloak and dagger stuff to try to get support for his positions.Three hundred jobs lost in Griffin Press in Adelaide, and what did the member for Kingston have to say about it? Very interesting if you read the Advertiser of today, which says with regard to the member for Kingston:The Member for Kingston, Ms Sue Jeanes, yesterday urged the Government to be more critical of the advice it received in preparing its second Budget.She said cuts to industry assistance in last years Budget had already hurt the State . . . and any further cuts could destroy the local economy.Economic rationalism is becoming our nations newest form of cancer, she said.. . . . . . . . .N/ABut she said the Governments focus on fixing the economy needed to be balanced by a commitment to spending money on jobs and industry—. . . governments have a very legitimate role to play in supporting industries, and we havent focused on our manufacturing sector enough.That is under todays date. That is the member for Kingston. That is another one of your backbenchers who is not in this chamber today. She is prepared to go to the press and get a headline but she is not prepared to vote for South Australia in this chamber. The member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) will not stand up for the workers in Maryborough and now the member for Kingston wants to get a story in the paper expressing concern but will not support the policies that will help the people in her state.That is why I say that they are hypocritical. They know that what the Labor party is pursuing on these issues is correct. They know that they should be supporting our amendments. They are hoping that pressure can be kept on this government to reverse its decision even further, but they have not got the courage to vote with us in this chamber. They are the people that claim that they vote for and represent constituencies but they are hidebound by the rigidity of their position and not allowed to vote as they really believe that they should.The fact of the matter is that industry policy under this government is in chaos. It is in chaos because the member is incapable of articulating a vision. In fact, listening to him on a lot of things, I think he is incapable of articulating anything. But he is certainly incapable of articulating a vision for manufacturing industry. Not only has he been condemned by every industry group in this country, but he has now got 10 of the top chief executive officers of the country condemning the lack of vision and the lack of support for industry.The fact of the matter is that this decision today that he is putting forward is another nail in the coffin for one of Australias successful manufacturing industries. It is a nail in the coffin for regional development; it is a nail in the coffin for jobs in Maryborough, in Geelong, in Adelaide—and you do not care.The problem is that you have made a commitment to getting jobs but you are introducing policies that will see them disappear. The Labor Party will oppose the amendment that you are putting forward, Minister, because it is the wrong decision. It breaks promises, it is unsoundly based and, most of all, it is anti‐regions and it is anti‐jobs. It will not support the manufacturing industry in this country which has grown so significantly because of the policies that Labor had in place. We oppose the amendments and call on those on the other side who say they share a belief in this view to join us in so opposing. (Time expired)Item 1 omitted.

name: Mr JENKINS
content: —This is the most important part of this amendment because it reduces the period for this bounty back six months. For the paltry sum of $4 million, this government is going to place in jeopardy many jobs in the printing industry and the fact is that there has been no argument put in this debate. No argument has been put by the minister in this consideration in detail stage about any rationale for not keeping the bounty until 31 December 1997. There has been no attempt by the minister to give any full explanation of why that is so. He relies on the joint press release he made with the Treasurer (Mr Costello) but that has no explanation of why the bounty period is to be reduced by six months. Here we have an argument in this chamber over bringing the expiration of the bounty back from 31 December to 30 June 1997. As my colleagues, the members for Hotham (Mr Crean) and Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson), have indicated, what the minister has to understand is the regional consequences of the decision that his government is involved in. We have acknow ledged that perhaps these are decisions that do not rest easy with him, perhaps these are decisions for which he argued a different case and lost but the simple fact is that on the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill—the original bill—the only basis for it was as part of the budgetary strategy of the government for fiscal consolidation.I see the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) in the chamber. Perhaps he has been flushed out by the efforts of the honourable members for Hotham and Batman but perhaps he will take this opportunity to tell us how he is going to defend the workers of Maryborough. It is important in this debate that a member like the member from Bendigo comes before us to defend those workers from Maryborough that are likely to lose their jobs.The thing that we wish to see is the response from the minister on this point. He sat there, babbling away, interjecting, not putting any concrete case to justify either the original decision or the ensuing backflip. Why is the six-month period so important? Obviously it is only important because of the budget bottom line and the $4 million that it is likely to save in the budget. That is just not good enough for the people of Maryborough where the printing industry employs something like 25 per cent of the townships employment force. They need answers from the government about the alternatives. What are the alternatives? Simply put, the overall macro settings that they rely upon have not eventuated into jobs. What the Australian community is looking for is Australian jobs. This is an argument about Australian jobs. What we need to see from the minister today is some indication of what it is that he is arguing in cabinet against those cabinet ministers who are from the dry faction of his party and are very much anti‐job. What the minister needs to understand is that these policy matters are complicated. In the Australian Financial Review of Friday, the Australian Publishers Association put a proposition. The Australian Publishers Associations proposition was based on the fact that the cost to the budget of the governments policy is likely to be $28.6 million over 12 months based on the lower tax revenue and the higher unemployment.Unfortunately, that associations solution is to ask that the tariff on imported paper should be removed at the same time that this bounty is decreased. Which state would be most affected if this tariff was removed? Which state would be the most affected? Tasmania. So, in juggling the regions we are going to trade one region off against another.This is the whole problem. When the Productivity Commission legislation was before us and the opposition said that the Productivity Commission should take into account the regional aspects of policy ideas, the Minister denied that that should be part of the Productivity Commissions considerations. The survival of the regions is dependent on this. (Time expired)

name: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
content: —I am pleased that the member for unemployment—I should say the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid)—has found his way into the chamber! The member for Bendigo has just returned from viewing the art galleries of New York, and yet he has walked away from a promise given to the electorate of Bendigo prior to the last election to construct an art gallery in Bendigo. The people of Bendigo cannot go to New York to look at art galleries. The art gallery that was promised to them by the member for Bendigo is still in never‐never land.The real question is: will the member for Bendigo vote against this bill? Will the member for Bendigo stand up for local jobs? If he does not vote against this bill the simple message to the electorate of Bendigo will be that the member for Bendigo is guilty of destroying local jobs. That is what it is about.It is about whether or not he is prepared to stand up for his electorate. It is about whether or not he is prepared to stand up for local jobs. It is about whether or not he is prepared to stand up for the town of Maryborough. I know he wishes that the town of Maryborough were in Queensland, but it is in his electorate.For the member for Bendigo—and I know he likes to occupy the chair—it was not a great issue moving the Speakers chair from Old Parliament House to this House at a cost of $500,000. I put it to him that to vote with us will effectively mean that an additional $4 million this financial year will be allocated to giving assistance, especially to jobs, in regional Australia.I believe that the member for Bendigo ought to stand with us. I am more concerned with jobs in Maryborough than jobs offshore in Indonesia or the Philippines. That is what we are really talking about. Are we going to have jobs in Maryborough, Bendigo, Ballarat, Townsville, Cairns and Dubbo, or are we going to give jobs to Indonesia and the Philippines? That is what you are voting for today. That is what you will be guilty of if you vote with the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore). What the member for Bendigo has got to think about is whether to vote for jobs for Australians or for jobs offshore.There is only one way he should vote. He should vote against the government. He should cross the floor and stand side by side with the electors of Bendigo. It is important, not just because of the jobs that are part and parcel of the town of Maryborough and the book industry, but the real problem the government has to consider is the multiplier effect that those jobs create in the local region. Jobs in those towns are more important than jobs in Indonesia or the Philippines.The book bounty has a multiplier effect in the economy in the order of 13 times the initial outlay. It is not a cost, it is an investment—13 times the return for the initial outlay. Even the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism would consider that a pretty good investment! We know he is not a bad investment manager. Maybe he ought to think about investing in these plants. I am sure that would give him a bigger return than some of the blind activities he is now conducting in the share market through some of his mates.Unemployment of the order of 10.5 per cent in Bendigo is intolerable. The member for Bendigo ought to stand up and be counted. He ought to be the voice of the town of Maryborough. He ought to be prepared to stand up and say that youth unemployment is a major problem in his electorate. He ought to be prepared to say that he is concerned about the chronic loss of jobs in his electorate. He ought to walk down View Street and say, `I am going to fight, rather than write yet another letter.I understand he has just about run out of stamps. He writes a lot of letters, but he cannot put up his hand when it comes to voting. I am prepared to vote for an additional stamp allowance so that he can write a few more letters, but on this occasion he should put his hand up and vote with his feet rather than run away from his responsibilities! It is all about voting with your feet and standing up for your electorate, not writing letters.The member for Bendigo should be voting for the art gallery in View Street, Bendigo. He should be voting for the book bounty so there are jobs in Maryborough. He should be voting to reduce unemployment, which is over 10 per cent in his electorate at the moment. He should be voting for regional Australia. He should be voting for families. He should not be running away from his responsibilities, as he has consistently done since he was elected to this parliament in 1990.

name: Mr REID
content: —I welcome the opportunity to respond to the challenge from the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson). As a member of the ACTU, the member for Batman was running away at 100 miles an hour when the Whitlam government was abolishing tariffs, and he was remarkably silent on the book bounty when the book bounty legislation came before this House in 1992. There was not one word on behalf of the workers whom he was supposed to represent. When you think back to that 1992 legislation as a result of the Industry Commission report, it was not worth one word in their defence.It is all very well for the member for Batman to raise a whole range of other issues. He raised the Bendigo art gallery. The only person who promised $2 million to the gallery was Mr Paul Keating, the Prime Minister at the time. And what did he do? Did he provide a dollar? Not one lousy dollar did the former Prime Minister provide. Nor did he put it in the budget estimates. When Mr Paul Keating made this promise, he was actually the Prime Minister and in control of the Treasury.I want to get back to the bill because the allegation from the member for Batman is that the book bounty should be retained. I put a proposition to the minister and the minister has agreed to look at it. That is more constructive than the ALP has been. The proposal I put to the minister was put to me by the Australian Publishers Association who believe that there should be a correction on the other side of the ledger that would be related to the tariff on inputs into the industry. The minister has given an undertaking that he will look at that situation and I will be anxiously looking towards what outcomes that provides.I can assure the House that this is sheer hypocrisy on the part of the Labor Party. After all of their years of cutting tariffs one after the other while supposedly looking after the employees in various industries, just remember that 25,000 jobs were lost in the motor industry during that time. And now you come out and try and make some capital out of this.The minister has taken note of the comments I have made on tariffs on inputs. I will be monitoring that situation on behalf of two very important industries in my electorate.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr CREAN
content: —The member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) writes the letters. He is the new Alastair Cooke, Letters from America— not letters from Bendigo, letters to the minister from New York. When the member for Batman was talking about View Street, he got out the old New York street directory because he had been so used to traipsing around there getting used to his new lifestyle that he had forgotten about Maryborough.Let me just come to some of the issues that the member for Bendigo has raised. He talks about the loss of memory and about the fact that I, in this House, supported a resolution to abolish the books bounty. I think that this is what he was inferring, although he never quite stated it because he did not know what he was talking about. In 1992, the Labor government did propose the abolition of the books bounty. But it did not do it and do you know why? The member for Rankin (Mr Beddall) and the member for Hotham were in there saying, `Dont do it, and it was not done. That is why the book bounty exists. I say to the member for Bendigo that if the book bounty had been abolished, why would we be up dealing with it today? The only people seeking to abolish it are the Liberals, aided and abetted by the member for Bendigo.The question of the art gallery in Bendigo is really getting under the guard of the member for Bendigo. You try to say that the former Prime Minister promised the $2 million. He did, but so did you. You went to the press and said, `We need to be able to match this promise. You promised them $2 million. Do you know what? He then got the Treasurer (Mr Costello) out, and the Treasurer said, `We are not going to give you that $2 million but we will fund a feasibility study and we will give you $100,000. This is the Alan Bond solution. This is payment of 5c in the dollar. That is your treatment of the electorate of Bendigo. That is your approach. You promised them $2 million, and you gave them $100,000. You are a disgrace. You are a disgrace to the electorate of Bendigo, because you will not stand up for them.I make this further point. You talked about what Labor did in 1975 and did under the tariff plans that Labor introduced for textiles and clothing. None of the companies that we visited the other day—Empire Rubber, Stafford Ellinson, ADA—would have been in existence had it not been for Labors automotive and textile plans. You go and talk to them. Your problem is that it is a bit expensive to make the long distance phone call from New York, and they will not pick it up, in your case. You are irrelevant because you cannot do anything for Bendigo. You cannot deliver the art gallery. You cannot deliver jobs in Maryborough. You cannot support the ongoing plans for the automotive industry.Go and talk to the component parts manufacturers. Go and talk to BTR—who run Empire Rubber, in case you did not know. Go and talk to Stafford Ellinson. Go and talk to the Australian defence establishments who have introduced state‐of‐the art clothing, who have invested in technology and in the future, and who have actually made a commitment to the region based on the certainty that our tariff plans produced. We understood the importance of reducing tariffs to make us internationally competitive but we also understood the importance of getting companies into overseas markets.In other words, our market is too small in Australia. The market that we have got to participate in is the global market, but you cannot do that by dismantling tariffs unilaterally and giving no support to get into exports. That is what our approach on industry policy is. That is what you have dismantled, and that is what the books bounty has dismantled. That is why jobs are threatened in Maryborough. That is why, unless you back our position—the majority position—in terms of cars, the jobs at Empire Rubber will be threatened; and that is why, if you go down the same crazy route in terms of textiles and clothing, Stafford Ellinson and ADA will be under threat.I ask you, as the member for Bendigo, when are you going to stand up for your constituency? Are you in retirement now? I can see you jumping to your feet. Why did you only take 10 minutes? I have still got a bit more time, and I will have some more. Why did you go to New York when this issue was on? Why did you desert the constituency, and why will you not cross the floor on this amendment? If you have got any commitment to Bendigo, you will vote with us. If you do not, you are only going to betray them.

name: Mr BEDDALL
content: —When I saw this Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill debate listed on the monitor—obviously, it was not meant to be a very long debate—I recalled being invited, as the minister in 1992, by that prominent local citizen from the electorate of Bendigo, Joe Helper, to go down and talk to people about the book bounty. When we went and talked to the people about the book bounty, we saw that the proposal that was before the government at the time would damage local industry.As the minister, I came back and talked to the portfolio minister, John Button, about the proposal and the bounty remained. We had effective local representation going to the minister and the minister seeing the merits of the argument. Now here we are; another minister has a proposition to knock over the book bounty. He should listen to the local people and not knock off this very important bounty.Bounties are important in the way that we build our local industries. The bookbinding industry is important in Australia, particularly to regional Australia, and I know my colleague the member for Bendigo is a very dutiful chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology and I am his deputy chair. name: Mr JENKINS
content: —The honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) has revealed his Reid plan for the book industry which sounds faintly familiar. It is exactly the case being put by the Australian Publishers Association I suspect. I am amused at the Australian Financial Review report of last Friday because it concludes:Government officials reacted cautiously to the submission yesterday. The coalition is considering the implications of its budget decision to abolish the book bounty without any changes to tariffs on imported paper.If that is the case, this debate gives the minister at the table the opportunity to tell the House, and to tell the industry, how long this consideration will take. But the report in the Australian Financial Review goes on further where it says:The APA—that is the Australian Publishers Association—is understood to have support from key coalition backbenchers, several of whom have big printing factories in their regional electorates.I do not know whether it is over flattering to the honourable member for Bendigo to be described as a key coalition backbencher. Perhaps he is not a key coalition backbencher and there are others within the ranks that are supporting the position, but the point is that we have the opportunity in this debate for Minister Moore to tell the House what consideration he has given to this proposition.I remind the minister that the report in the Australian Financial Review , in its brief analysis of the proposition being put by the APA, says that the basis of that submission is that the tariffs on imported paper should be removed. I remind the minister that the report goes on to say that the impact of that will be job losses in Tasmania. The overall effect of the bill that we have before us is to drive Australian jobs offshore; to drive the jobs of those in Maryborough that are working in the print industry offshore to our neighbours in the Asian region. The proposal now being put as a solution to save the jobs of those in Maryborough is to deny the jobs of those in Tasmania. Perhaps there is some forgetfulness in the people that are proposing this, like the honourable member for Bendigo, in that they need to be reminded that, whilst Tasmania might be overseas, Tasmanians jobs are Australian jobs.We have people like the honourable member for Bendigo who represents a regional centre in Victoria. We have the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) who has an interest in the important regional centre of Geelong. I hope that their submissions to government take into account the effects of the policies of this government on the regions. As the honourable member for Rankin (Mr Beddall) indicated, when the proposal was made earlier by a Labor government to remove the book bounty it was consideration of the impact on regional Australia that led to the decision not to go forward with the removal of the bounty. This government seems incapable of understanding that the directions of their policies have to take into account the impact of those policies at the regional level. If one looks at the month to month unemployment figures—and this debate is about jobs, Australian jobs, keeping them in Australia not driving them overseas—the government needs to take into account the regional impacts.We have somebody here from the National Party prattling on about opportunism. There is no opportunism in my position. My interest is the jobs of Australians. That is the paramount consideration.The issue before us in this consideration in detail stage is to ensure that the book bounty continues through to 31 December of this year. At no stage in this debate has there been any justification for removing the bounty after the end of June, because the only justification is the saving of $4 million to the budget bottom line, totally ignoring the impact on employment, especially in regional Australia. (Time expired)

They still tried to force that legislation through this House. They took absolutely no notice of people in the regional areas of Australia. I am pleased to see that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) is coming into the House, because he probably would be aware of the spirited debate at that time.The Labor Party had legislation before the House to abolish all book bounties. There is no escaping that fact. Members of the party went to the central Victorian area, had discussions and then came back with an even harder line on abolishing book bounties. It was the work of the member for Barker (Mr McLachlan) and the member for Bendigo that led to those amendments. It was probably because the then government was getting a tremendous amount of opposition at that time because of what was happening in the regional areas of Australia.They did not do it of their own accord. They came into this chamber with an even harder line than they had had. It is sheer hypocrisy on the part of the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) and the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson) to speak as they have on this particular issue. In particular, the member for Hotham was one of the driving forces behind the original legislation. He was on the frontbench. In other words, he was part of the decision making process supporting what the then government was doing in introducing that legislation which was going to abolish all book bounties.Where was the member for Hotham then? At that time he was a minister—he has admitted that he was a frontbencher—and he was part of the decision making process. Why was he not standing up against the legislation then? He was not supporting the regional areas of Australia then.We are seeing the hypocrisy of both the member for Hotham and the member for Batman who, although he now sits on the frontbench, at that time was involved with the ACTU, and he totally rolled over. He rolled over on this issue. He was not out there defending his workers at that time, and he is in serious bother on this issue. name: Mrs DRAPER
content: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Recognising that economic development will lead to further job creation, what is the government doing to facilitate an increase in major investment projects in Australia? In particular, what initial steps is the government taking to ensure major national projects are not held up by unnecessary departmental delays?
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr HOWARD
content: —Since coming to office, the government has followed a coordinated strategy to encourage major investment projects in this country. We have followed policies which have created fiscal and monetary settings which give confidence, encour agement and hope to major investors in Australia. We have set about the process of reducing the cost of doing business in this country. We have passed, after some obstruction from the Labor Party and, initially, from others in the Senate, the Workplace Relations Act, the provisions of which are progressively coming into operation. They provide a far better, a more beckoning and a more benign climate for major projects in this country. The provisions of that act are far more likely to encourage people to invest in this country than did the old industrial relations regime which the new Workplace Relations Act has replaced.We have also set about reforming elements of infrastructure in this country in electricity, gas, water and telecommunications. We have strongly promoted the national competition policy and, of course, we have foreshadowed essential reforms in the area of waterfront and shipping. Some of those reforms have occurred already and others will be tackled during the course of this year.Importantly so far as regional Australia is concerned, we have acted to create certainty of access in some of the resource industries. We have begun and successfully concluded the negotiation of an agreement in the Gippsland area so far as forests are concerned, we are grappling with the difficulties thrown up by the High Court decision in the Wik case, and we have set about rationalising Commonwealth‐state responsibilities in environmental policy in order to reduce compliance costs. It is very encouraging to note that business investment in this country has grown by no less than 20 per cent during the past year.As foreshadowed in my statement to parliament at the end of last year, I have established a part‐time consultancy position in my office for somebody who will act as a facilitator of major projects. I am delighted to confirm that Mr Bob Mansfield will fill that position. Mr Mansfield is a former Managing Director of Optus, a former Chief Executive with the Fairfax organisation, and he recently carried out a review of the functions and the charter of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. He will serve as a part‐time consultant attached to my office on the basis of estab lished conditions which have applied to part‐time consultants employed by former Prime Ministers. It is anticipated that he will devote, on average, two to three days a week to his new task. His appointment will be for an initial period of 12 months, with scope for extensions if that is the mutual desire of myself and Mr Mansfield.His major task will be to bring about the speedy approval of major nation‐building investment proposals which conform with government policy. For the first time, the federal government of this country will have at the elbow of the Prime Minister somebody with strong business experience with a specific brief to cut through the red tape which so often holds up, delays, frustrates and, in the process, destroys jobs that can be created by the coming into being of major investment projects.Our commitment to improve the climate of operation for small business in this country is undoubted and undiminished. There is also a very major role in the future of Australias economy for the development of major projects attracting large levels of investment, both domestically and from overseas. We need a heightened, more concentrated effort to sweep away the obstruction, the bureaucratic delay, the red tape, the unnecessary obfuscation which is often involved in the process of government approval and determination. I believe Mr Mansfields appointment will strike a very strong blow in that direction.

name: Mr COSTELLO
content: —I thank the honourable member for McMillan for his question. Today, the national accounts showed a 0.5 per cent growth for the December quarter and 3.1 per cent over the course of the year. As I said in the House yesterday, the strong imports were not altogether a bad thing, coming as they did from intermediate and capital goods. In relation to his area, the regions of Australia, he would know that it has been this governments stand in relation to forest and forestry agreement which has given wonderful job opportunities which were denied by our predecessor governments down in his area.He would also know that, over the course of this year, this government will put in place the most exciting environmental development Australia has ever seen—opposed by the Labor Party, I regret to say—and put in place by a government that is concerned about the environment; a $1 billion environmental trust to rebuild the environment of Australia. content: —I thank the honourable member for North Sydney for his question. There have been a number of recent media reports in respect of the sale process for the long-term leases of Brisbane, Melbourne and Perth airports. I am pleased to say that we have received a total of 18 individual, strong, competitive and high quality bids from nine consortia. Each of those bids has been thoroughly reviewed by the asset sales team, which includes BZW—the governments advisers—against a comprehensive set of evaluation criteria based on the governments stated sales and ongoing privatisation objectives.The long-term lease of airports will maximise efficient airport operations and it will facilitate future airport development on a commercial basis. The evaluation criteria for the bids included the price, ownership diversi ty, contribution to regional development, airport management capacity, airport development plans, awareness of environmental issues and consideration of the interests of the stakeholders of these airports, including the customers and local and state governments. name: Mr FORREST
content: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Health and Family Services. Is the minister aware of the announcement by President Clinton that the US government will not be approving funds for research involving human cloning experimentation? Can the minister confirm that human cloning experimentation is currently not permissible in Australia under National Health and Medical Research Council guidelines? Will the government ensure that these guidelines remain in place?
Speaker: N/A

name: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
content: —I thank the honourable member for his question. There has been very substantial interest in newspapers and magazines over recent weeks in this issue after the announcement that, at the Roslin Institute in Scotland, a sheep had been successfully cloned.Cloning is nothing new. It was first achieved in 1952 in tadpoles. But what is new is that it has been successful in higher animals. Two days ago it was announced at the Oregon Primate Research Centre in the United States that a monkey had been successfully cloned and it was on the basis of this that President Clinton announced overnight that federal funding would not be available for research into human cloning. He was responding to a situation that exists in the United States. The situation in Australia is different, as I will outline in a moment.Of course, the problem for society is that the technology of cloning and its experimentation are progressing at a much faster rate than that at which society can contemplate the scientific, social or ethical implications of such experiments. It has been given more urgency because the cloning of a primate is something very significant as it is the species most close to the human race genetically. It is very difficult to contemplate what the long‐term prospects might be.The situation in Australia basically has three points to it. The first is that, under NHMRC guidelines, human experimentation with the aim of producing two or more genetically identical offspring, which is in fact cloning, is prohibited. The NHMRC has the Australian Health Ethics Committee, a subcommittee which has published ethical guidelines on assisted reproductive technology. These were tabled in parliament in November last year.The NHMRC is of the view that such experimentation is unethical. It would not be funded under the National Health and Medical Research Council. The other great body of funding in Australia is the Australian Research Council and they take note of the NHMRC guidelines. The NHMRC also has a statement on human experimentation. Supplementary note 7 has been issued to that. It prohibits gene therapy that has the potential to change the genetic material that can be passed on from one generation to another.Human cloning is governed by state law. The Commonwealth does not have the right to legislate in this area. In Western Australia, South Australia and Victoria it is illegal. However, in the other states and territories what is not covered by the NHMRC or the Australian Research Council would almost certainly be found to be unethical through either hospital or other research institute guidelines. I can assure honourable members that the government is of the view that experimentation on human cloning is beyond the bounds of what are acceptable guidelines. The National Health and Medical Research Council is aware of our view.

name: Ms JEANES
content: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Does Australia support the EU proposals for a 15 per cent reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by the year 2010? What steps is the government taking to ensure Australias economic and environmental interests are protected in climate change negotiations?
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr DOWNER
content: —I thank the honourable member for Kingston for her question. I know she is very concerned about environmental issues and I know she is also concerned about jobs, including for the people of Kingston and the people of Adelaide and South Australia. The government has received advice of the European Unions negotiating target proposal for all OECD countries to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions by 15 per cent compared to the 1990 levels by 2010. The EU intends to submit this proposal to the negotiations currently taking place in Bonn.The House may be aware that the Australian government is arguing for what is described as a differentiation proposal in these climate change negotiations. That is to ensure that there is an equitable sharing of the burden amongst all of the so-called annexe 1 countries, which are in effect the OECD countries. There is no reason why this country should be asked to bear a disproportionate burden in addressing the climate change issue.The European Union proposal contains a differentiation proposal itself. It contains differentiation for individual EU member states but excludes this possibility for the OECD countries. So there are different targets for individual member states—for example, Portugals target allows emissions in 2010 to increase by 40 per cent, Greeces target is to increase by 30 per cent, Spains by 17 per cent and so on.Australia, along with other non-EU OECD countries, is being asked to accept a uniform flat rate reduction of 15 per cent, and that is clearly not going to be acceptable. It is inconsistent for the EU to deny others what they are using as a key element of their own efforts to address climate change.The fact is that a 15 per cent reduction target by 2010 is unrealistic. As we see it, it is little more than a negotiating tactic at this stage by the European Union. It also has to be said that the European Union proposal is frankly unworkable because it does not provide a sound framework for long-term cooperative action to address the climate change issue.

name: Mr SPEAKER
content: — I have received a letter from the honourable member for Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:The consequences for the people of the electorate of Hughes arising from the Governments proposal to build a nuclear waste reprocessing plant at Lucas Heights.I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr MARTYN EVANS
content: —It is good to see some support from members opposite. When I first heard this proposal for a nuclear fuel reprocessing facility at Lucas Heights and the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr McGauran) advance the proposition in an interview on the Face to Face program on Channel Seven some 10 days ago, I at first assumed it was not a real proposal. I assumed, in my good natured way, that the minister had just been reading some press releases, some scientific reports that had come across his desk or perhaps the recent ANSTO annual report and this topic had stuck in his mind and it had just come out as a slip of the tongue during the interview.But then I remembered that this minister has form on this topic. He has prior convictions when it comes to nuclear energy. This is the same minister who in 1993—although he was in opposition back then—proposed nuclear power facilities right across Australia. This is the nuclear powered minister who wanted to support a nuclear industry in Australia.Opposition members interjecting —
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)
content: —Order! The level of conversation in the chamber is far too high. Please be courteous to the honourable gentleman.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr MARTYN EVANS
content: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. Of course this minister, as the then opposition spokesman, was forced to withdraw this proposal in January 1994. In an interview of the day, he went on the record saying that he no longer felt this was an economically viable proposition. Indeed, he rejected the hypothetical proposition which he had been advancing for the electorate. He went on to say:And we—that is, the coalition parties—believe that nuclear enrichment and nuclear powered electricity are alien concepts to Australians and theyre economically unfeasible.Indeed they are alien concepts, as is the concept of nuclear fuel enrichment plants in Australia. This minister has form in this area. This is an alien concept. It was an alien concept in 1994 and it is an alien concept in 1997.What are we referring to when we talk about nuclear fuel reprocessing? Most members are familiar with nuclear power plants. They are familiar with the very safe operation of the Lucas Heights facility over the last 40 years. But most people are not so familiar with nuclear fuel reprocessing.You have to wait some 30 years for the spent fuel rods to cool sufficiently for them to be reprocessed. They are then treated with concentrated nitric acid, forming a very hot liquid and some gaseous components as well. This hot, thermally active and radioactive liquid is then separated into its respective components.Those components are uranium and waste material which is still very radioactive and in liquid form, and there is the potential for a small amount of plutonium to come from this process as well. That plutonium is very significant, and I think honourable members should keep sight of that as we proceed through this discussion.One thing nuclear fuel reprocessing does not do is that it does not reduce the level of radioactivity of the material concerned. At the end of the process, you still have very substantial quantities of radioactive material, although you have it in separate components. Instead of a mixture of nuclear fuel, you now have the uranium, the plutonium and the liquid waste separated out. You do not have any less radioactivity, but you do have a massive increase in the volume of this material. We are now required to deal with massive amounts of liquid radioactive waste, and this is what the minister proposes to locate at Lucas Heights in the middle of suburban Sydney. Minister, this is not a vision for science; this is more an illusion which is going to become a nightmare for the people of Sutherland Shire.In the past, the reasons one might propose for reprocessing have been threefold. First, for the military there was obviously the purpose of extracting the plutonium. I think this is an issue which will come back to haunt this minister.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr Melham
content: —Leave her alone, Wilson. Youre suborning a member of parliament. Give her protection, Mr Deputy Speaker.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
content: —The member for Banks, you will need protection in a moment if you do not keep quiet.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr MARTYN EVANS
content: —This government has joined with the previous government in moving towards the Canberra Commission proposition which will ensure that Australia takes a very strong stand in this world against nuclear proliferation. That is one of the most serious objectives which the previous government had in dealing with the Canberra Commission and on the international stage. The Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) has picked this topic up and continued to proceed with Australias favourable outlook in that regard.What will our friends in the Western world say when we are in possession of plutonium? How does that leave our non-proliferation treaty obligations when, as a result of the ministers reprocessing ambitions, we have significant quantities of plutonium? How will we deal with those quantities—something that we do not want to have to deal with?Secondly, there used to be economic reasons for reprocessing. It used to be necessary to extract the uranium from the reprocessing in order to have uranium to feed back into the nuclear fuel cycle. Uranium, of course, is now quite plentiful. Australia is not short of uranium, if it wishes to supply its reactor, and that is no longer a necessary objective. The third reason is that it does in some small way facilitate disposal because you have separate components with which to deal rather than a homogenous group. But taken in totality in 1997, this is not an adequate reason to proceed with the reprocessing of nuclear fuel in this country.Naturally, if the minister was to proceed with a pilot level plant, it would be a very expensive proposition. Japan is proceeding with one at the moment which will come on-stream some time after 2000. This is a pilot plant for reprocessing fast reactor fuel in Japan. It will cost them something of the order of $1.5 billion. It will be a six-storey building with a two-storey basement, and it is still just a pilot plant. So precisely what is proposed for the Lucas Heights region here? Something of the same order? I sincerely hope not.Nuclear reprocessing is an option in England. The British government has established a number of very major reprocessing facilities in Dounreay and Sellafield that have been in operation for some time. There is a very strong view in the nuclear industry that the only reason those plants are continued, maintained and indeed expanded is because Britain and France—its colleague country in this regard—have already made substantial investments in the nuclear fuel cycle, and they have significant plants which need to be maintained. That is why they are in that business.Other countries, like Germany, which has recently abandoned a proposal to get involved with reprocessing, and the United States, which does not reprocess fuel, have rightly moved away from this technology and towards storage. That ought to be Australias option, not the option of reprocessing fuel for our very modest nuclear reactor at Lucas Heights on Australian soil.As an alternative to a pilot plant, the minister may have in mind—and given his past enthusiasm for the nuclear industry—importing waste from other countries. Indeed, he has commented on this as being part of the fast growing Asian nuclear region. He may want to attack some of his theories in the nuclear club by having Australia be part of this arrangement and import nuclear waste. I think the honourable member for Hughes (Mrs Vale) would need to ask what the hidden agenda is behind the governments plans for an airport at Holsworthy. Is one of those agendas the importation of nuclear fuel through that airport? I sincerely hope not, because that would expose us to even greater risks than the ministers bizarre proposal already does.If you want to see exactly what this kind of reprocessing plant can leave you with after a few years of operation, you can do no worse that look at the United States. One of the main reasons they have now moved away from this technology—if you look at Hanford—is the massive amounts of liquid waste which they have had to deal with and the enormous environmental degradation which that has produced on that site. The United States now has a super‐fund to clean up these kinds of areas. The cost of that is massive to the US economy; the damage to the local environment is enormous; and the technology is far from useful for that country, which is why they have moved away from it.Minister, you have some very hard decisions to make in this area. These decisions have come up on your watch. I know that is tough but that is the reality of politics. You wanted to get into government. Now you are in, you will have to take some of these hard decisions, make some of the hard plans and put in the work that is required to ensure Australia has some sound policies in the future.This reactor is now nearly 40 years old. It is not quite as old as he or I, but the reality is that I suspect the reactor is in not quite such good condition as either of us. The reality is that we need to plan for the future. Minister, instead of coming up with this kind of distracting proposal which focuses public attention on an entirely absurd proposal to reprocess waste at Lucas Heights, why dont you focus public attention instead on the real questions?Australia needs to address the issue of the future of the Lucas Heights reactor and the future of the Lucas Heights site, because the Nuclear Safety Bureau has very clearly said they will not continue to recertify this plant much beyond 2003. ANSTO itself says that it is essential we start making decisions at about now.The reality is that the minister should be putting the effort into determining the future of that site and not into proposing strange new ways of getting ANSTO into the world nuclear club. That is a technology looking for a solution, instead of a reasoned plan for the future of Australias nuclear industry focused on that research reactor. This is where you need some serious vision.We do have an issue about the storage of the fuel rods from Lucas Heights. They continue to mount up. Governments for the last 38 years have known that they would, and the reality is that that has to be dealt with as and when the problem arises. We have now reached a point where that needs further serious consideration.The previous government sent one shipload back for reprocessing, and that will return to Australia in some 25 to 30 years in reprocessed form. The significance is that that site is now reaching a point where in the next two or three years, or sooner, you will need some serious answers to those questions. Not only will you have to look at the issue of the future of the plant, but also whether Australia needs another research reactor and, if it does, whether that should be at Lucas Heights or at some alternative site. Those are the kinds of questions to which the people of Australia, particularly the people of Sutherland Shire, are demanding answers to. They are not looking for new ways of getting us further and deeper into the nuclear cycle or of creating further and deeper environmental problems in that region. They are looking, instead, for long-term answers and serious work to be done on this topic.You must also face the reality that Synroc has had substantial investment in it over the years. I understand that. But if we are going to use a reprocessing plant at Lucas Heights merely as a demonstration technique for Synroc, then I think that is a very wasteful extravagance in terms of federal funding. It is a very dangerous proposition for the people of that area and it is not a suitable way to ensure the continuation of that technology.Normally, I would be the first to join with the minister in support of Australian industry and Australian science through the commitment of government resources. It is unfortunate that his government has not displayed the same commitment to industry when it reduced the research and development grants, when it abolished syndication, when it pulled back funding from ANSTO, AIMS and CSIRO and when it has sought to wipe out industry policy in general, as well as some of that scientific collaboration in research.Normally, I would come out and support the minister if he was proposing to invest federal funds in the development of a technology. But this is not the way to further the development of the Synroc technology. You cannot use the people of Sutherland Shire and Lucas Heights as pawns in a game which is merely for the development of a technology.I support the furtherance of that technology, if it is possible. We have a long-term investment in it—governments of both political colours have that. It deserves a degree of bipartisan support, as does ANSTO in its general activities. That is something you have always had and will have from us on this side of the House. But this is not the kind of proposal which is deserving of bipartisan support. This moves right outside of that area when it puts the citizens of that district at risk.ANSTO have a very strong record of safety. They have a first‐class record of research in the past, and it is very contemptuous of them to put their reputation at risk by this kind of proposal. You do them a great disservice by injuring their public reputation and their position of public trust and confidence in this way. There was no need to involve them in this kind of proposition. It is not a solution you need to propose in order to deal with the nuclear fuel rods from Lucas Heights.Most governments in the world are coming to the conclusion that dry storage is the way to go in the medium‐term future for these kinds of fuel rods. There is no reason why that could not continue in the way that it has. Indeed, the Senate last year, in an all-party report, recommended this kind of method of storage for Australia. It certainly did not recommend—and I am sure that its members would disagree with you now—the reprocessing option for Lucas Heights.This is not a good new industry for Australia, Minister. Focus your attention on the good science which is coming out of Australian industry, on the good science which is coming out of our national science agencies like CSIRO, ANSTO, AIMS and the universities. Do not expose them to this kind of nuclear `cowboyry. Certainly, do not put the people of Hughes and Sutherland Shire at risk through the environmental degradation which this proposal would implement. Guarantee them today that you will not proceed with this.For the sake of those people, for the sake of those families and for the sake of the future of that area, give the guarantee which for the last two weeks you have failed and refused to give in this House and outside of this House. Give them the assurance which they and we seek from you today—that you will abandon this absurd proposal for a reprocessing facility at Lucas Heights in Sydney now.

name: Mr McGAURAN
content: —The member for Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans) must have woken up this morning, seen that Sydney Morning Herald front page story and thought all of his Christmases had come at once. That story had nothing new to reveal, no extra information and no interpretation beyond what I have been saying for several weeks and what most other news organisations in this country have been reporting for several weeks. Let us deal with that first and foremost.There is nothing new in the story in the Sydney Morning Herald . It correctly reports that the government is examining the options available to it for the disposal of the 1,600 spent fuel rods at Lucas Heights. I have been grievously misrepresented by the member when he concluded in his address—leaving aside a number of misrepresentations during his address—by saying that we have decided on a reprocessing plant at Lucas Heights. That is completely wrong.Despite the member for Bonython understandably rejoicing in the event of today and in the attention that it has brought him and the issue, he has three major problems—and he did not overcome any of the problems during his address. The first is that the Labor Party did nothing in government for 13 years to address this problem. We have inherited this. We have come to government, and the advice from ANSTO is that next year the storage facilities at Lucas Heights will be exhausted. The spent fuel rods have to be dealt with. They have to be reprocessed. So you have no credibility. This is opportunism of the worst kind. It is politics at its most base.Instead of seeking a reasoned, sensible and calm debate on this issue, the Labor Party seizes on a front page story dramatically presented with a headline, photos and sketches but which reveals nothing new or different. They come in here and turn up the temperature. During his whole address, the member threw around words like `nuclear power, `nuclear fuel enrichment and `nuclear proliferation, instead of addressing the one issue—that is, how do we dispose of the spent fuel which is an unavoidable by-product of the research reactor?The second problem is that the Labor Party spent, in round figures, $40 million in research into Synroc technology. If I understand them correctly, we are now not entitled to consider that as an option. You tell the Australian taxpayers, firstly, that you spent $40 million over 13 years on a technology that you were never going to use in government—and which never sees the funding, by the way—and, secondly, that we are not entitled to consider it as an option. You tell them that you have wasted $40 million. You will not. Of course we are entitled to consider the Synroc technologies. You would have done in government, I suspect. But from your remarks now, I am not so certain.What has happened to the $40 million? It has just been wasted? It has been worthless technology? Of course we have to consider it. Thirdly, you have no policy yourself on how to dispose of these 1,600 spent fuel rods. I listened very carefully to every word, particularly to see whether or not you would finish up with a declaration of how you would dispose of the 1,600 spent fuel rods. The member for Bonython failed to do that, Mr Deputy Speaker. So what credibility do you have? With what seriousness should we regard your protestations on behalf of the people of Hughes, for whom we have real interest because we want to dispose of the spent fuel rods?It is a ludicrous MPI and, quite frankly, a waste of this parliaments time. The government has said that we can send the spent fuel rods back to the United Kingdom for reprocessing. Do you want that? Should they go back to Dounreay, Scotland? No answer. They can go back to the United States for reprocessing. Do you want that? Should they go back to the United States? No answer. Or we can process them domestically. We will consider them, looking at all of the environment, social and economic considerations.How do we deal with an opposition that can inflame what can be, at times, a sensitive community issue if people in responsible positions do not handle it properly, yet still fail to tell us what they would do with the problem they gave us after total inaction over 13 years? Do not take my word for it. You have been quoting the Sydney Morning Herald . I refer you again, as I did in question time, to a report by Leigh Dayton on 22 August 1994. Did she cane the then Labor government! She said:Australias policy on the disposal of radioactive waste is definitely not a shambles. Far worse—it doesnt even exit.The article goes through your cowardly inaction on this issue. Even though it was drawn to your attention in the media in August 1994, the Labor Party did nothing until it lost government in March 1996. Twenty months later you still had done nothing. The shadow minister puts up this idea that we can leave them there. Correct me if I am wrong, please take a personal explanation, but to the best of my understanding, you said, `Leave them in dry storage. But they are corroding. We cannot leave them indefinitely.That is the opposition we have to deal with. How do we take you seriously? You have no credibility, you put up no alternative and the storage is exhausted in 1998. The government does have to take a decision. You were gracious enough to say there are hard decisions; you were not so gracious as to give us any indication of what those decisions should be. So you are scaremongering. I expect it from the extremist groups and the Democrats on these types of issues most of the time, but not from the Labor Party opposition. I would have expected a lot more.You can exaggerate, you can hype up and terrify people if you really want to on this issue. The fact is that you have a responsibility, particularly as much of this problem is of your making, to assist the government to solve it, or else, if not supporting the final decision that we make, to put up your own alternative. Until then, quite frankly, I—and I do not see how anyone in the community would—cannot take you seriously. You had the gall to lecture me about the need to respect and support ANSTO. The member for Bonython should know that the government has a very strong commitment to ANSTO.We recognise that the spent fuel represents an unavoidable by‐product of the HIFAR research reactor which is used to produce almost all of Australias nuclear medicines. Some 260,000 Australians benefit from the radioisotopes every year. As a major national scientific facility, the reactor also plays an important part in education and research outside of ANSTO with 7,000 hours of research time provided to universities in both Australia and New Zealand on an annual basis. It is one of the worlds largest sources of irradiated silicon used in advanced computer chip production. HIFAR is also used to analyse more than 33,000 samples each year for the minerals and oil exploration industries in Australia.The government is very supportive of this essential facility. In medical, environmental, industrial and research terms, ANSTO serves the nation extremely well. It does not deserve the adverse publicity which the opposition and the minor parties are now visiting upon it. The hypocrisy of anyone, including the member for Bonython, to accuse me or the government of letting down ANSTO is astounding. It is they, the opposition, who are stirring up community feelings on this issue. We will fully, properly and responsibly consider all of the factors that go to make up the different options available to the government for this unavoidable problem. It is not going to go away.Nobody at ANSTO is going to be fooled by this phoney, mealy‐mouthed defence on their part. It is the member for Bonython who should be ashamed and embarrassed to show his face anywhere near the Lucas Heights site. We have full support for ANSTO and what it does. It plays a crucial role in Australia for both health and manufacturing terms. So many thousands of Australians owe their lives to the research carried out at ANSTO.Remember that ANSTO is Australias only producer of radioisotopes which are used in treating and detecting illnesses which include cancer, thyroid disease, heart disease and others. There are over 100 nuclear medicine departments in Australia performing an estimated 300,000 diagnostic tests and 4,000 treatments annually with a combined value approaching $200 million. In an average year, more than 250,000 Australians—I mentioned 260,000 Australians earlier on—will have a nuclear medicine procedure and, on average, one in every two Australians can now expect one in their lifetime.These and other non-invasive procedures have replaced the need for much exploratory surgery to assess a patients condition, significantly reducing discomfort and cost to patients. Use of these tests also reduces the length of hospital stays. Sales of ANSTOs radio pharmaceuticals to the Australian market now exceed $11 million annually. Some $700,000 of ANSTOs radio pharmaceuticals are also exported to South-East Asia, where the market is estimated to be $25 million and growing at more than 10 per cent annually.

name: Mr McGAURAN
content: —The member for Bonython is policy-free on all the issues. He has the temerity to sit there and say, `Its your decision. Of course it is our decision. We will make it. That is why I have always been open and honest and set out the options available to the government.Now we want to know what his policy is, especially how the opposition are going to tell Australian taxpayers that they have spent $40 million over 13 years and the Synroc technology is going to be junked. For any opposition frontbencher to taunt the government by saying, `Youre the government, youre the minister, thats what you get paid for, make the decision, and not have any alternative is hypocritical and cowardly. We will make the decision—make no mistake about that. Events will be forced on us. The storage facilities are exhausted next year, so we will make the decision in the next few months.But you tell us what your policy is. We have to go into all of the detail, make all of the calculations and take into account so many different factors. I am not asking that of you; I am just asking for a one-line policy from you. I will not require you to prepare a Fightback of 600 pages, with all of the supporting documentation, but you just tell us what your bottom line is. What is the member for Bonythons one-sentence destination for the 1,600 spent fuel rods? Until then, you have no place in this debate and you ought to be condemned for the way you are stirring it up for your own purposes.ANSTO of course uses the radioisotopes in a variety of ways to boost productivity, from checking gas and oil pipelines to the development of newer high‐tech materials. In the environmental field, by using radioisotopes, we can trace sewage from ocean outfalls or small leaks from complex systems, such as power stations and heat exchanges. HIFAR is used, as I say, to analyse more than 33,000 samples each year for the minerals and oil exploration industries in Australia. So it is a major scientific facility. It plays a very important part in education and research out of ANSTO.For all these reasons, the government will support the institution. We will solve the problem that we have inherited from Labor and, notwithstanding some of the worst kinds of opportunist politics imaginable by the opposition, we will win the confidence of the local and, indeed, the more widespread community. (Extension of time granted)I will not need long, but I just want to reinforce a couple of points. What did the Labor Party do over 13 years? What were their decisions? None. Instead, it seems that they put their head in the sand and thought the spent fuel rods would go away naturally. The Labor Party refused to make any decision regarding the spent fuel rods.Worse still, they continued to fund, at the rate of millions of dollars a year, the Synroc technology, seemingly—from what the shadow minister now tells us—without any intention of ever using it, without any intention of capitalising on that research which extended from 1980, but most of the money was spent during Labors 13 years. Even now, they will not tell us what their policy is.On all those grounds, the Labor Party and the shadow minister are revealed for what they really are. They are just cheap political opportunists who stand condemned for the way they are stirring up local feeling with total disregard to peoples natural feelings on this issue. The way they throw around the nuclear spectre, next we will be hearing from the shadow minister the imagery of Chernobyl or Three Mile Island. This, instead, is one of the options available to the government, which is reasonably and responsibly considering them before reaching a final decision.For those members who have just come in, let me remind them of a priceless, memorable interjection, never to be forgotten, by the member for Bonython. When I asked him whether he would send the spent fuel rods to Dounreay in the United Kingdom for repro cessing I received no answer. When I asked him whether he would send them to the United States for reprocessing I received no answer. When I asked him whether he would reprocess them domestically I received no answer. His only reply was, `Youre the government, youre the minister, you make the decision.We will make the decision—a decision they avoided studiously at great expense to Australians for 13 years. But you tell us what your policy is. Just tell us in one sentence the destination: United Kingdom, United States or Australia. That is all you have to tell us. Until then, you have no credibility and, until then, you are revealed for the political opportunist you really are.
