name: Mr McCLELLAND
content: —One may well ask what this government is doing to my friend the member for Hughes (Mrs Vale). First, they are giving her an airport. Now they are throwing in a nuclear reprocessing plant. When are they going to throw in a quarantine station or a hospital for contagious diseases, just to take another 20 per cent off the property values of residents in her electorate?The development of such a reprocessing plant is going to have a dramatic effect on not only the residents of Sutherland but also all those in the surrounding areas, including my electorate of Barton and the surrounding electorates of Banks, Watson, Throsby and Werriwa because they would be the routes that all this nuclear material would be shipped and transported through in order to get to Lucas Heights. It is an issue that very much affects that entire region of Sydney.Indeed, the issue affects Australia. The minister has asked, `Why have you spent all this money on developing the Synroc technology? The fact of the matter is that that technology is extremely valuable and is to be used overseas in other reprocessing plants that already exist. But because that investment is being made in that technology, you do not have to dive headlong into the water—indeed, contaminated water—of developing your own nuclear facility at the grubby, literally poisonous end of the nuclear cycle.The minister said that we were being emotive when we used terms such as `nuclear power and `nuclear fuel. I do not know what the subject matter of the debate is if it is not about the by-products of nuclear power and nuclear fuel. Let us talk about radioactive contamination and the effects of radiation as indicated in No time to waste , a report of April 1996. It says:The long term health effects of radiation exposure are manifested by mutation of cells, increased aging capacity of the body, and increased incidence of leukemia, birth defects and cancer.The government asks, `What are we going to do? What they are doing is pre‐empting research and investigation which was under way during the period of the Labor government. One was an investigation into the future of Lucas Heights—my strong view is that it should have no future; it is right now smack bang in a very beautiful residential area—and the second was to identify a site for the future disposal of waste, including an investigation into the characteristics of that site.This government is proposing to dive headlong into the contaminated pool of this reprocessing plant without first of all investigating those issues. In other words, they are trying to inject life into the nuclear reactor at Lucas Heights by giving it another purpose rather than investigating whether its current purpose should be continued—a very live and sensitive issue in the entire region.The minister—with respect, he has fallen victim to the Yes, Minister men; perhaps with experience he will be able to detect where they are coming from—has said that the Sydney Morning Herald is only reporting what he has been saying for the last few weeks. Todays Sydney Morning Herald said:Officials envisage using Australias experimental Synroc technology for immobilising nuclear waste, thereby demonstrating its first commercial use to the burgeoning nuclear power industry in the Asia-Pacific region. After reprocessing, the waste would be buried somewhere in Outback Australia.If that is not saying that the conduit to outback Australia is coming through a reprocessing plant at Lucas Heights, I do not know what is. They are diving into the Asia-Pacific nuclear processing technology area without Australians deciding whether it is an industry that they want at all. I think that if there were a referendum, Australians would say, `Stay right out of this one, just as Europe, Germany and the United States are doing. Without a mandate whatsoever, they are diving straight into this technology—a commercial enterprise for the whole Asia-Pacific region—which collects all their waste and reprocesses it. That waste is going to come in from ships and presumably it will come in through Port Botany, through my electorate and through surrounding electorates. Even if it is not going to bring in supplies from overseas, a reprocessing plant most certainly is going to collect waste from areas all around Australia, such as hospitals and irradiation plants that we used to use for irradiating carpets and food and so forth. In mass quantities, to one big bulk store, it will be coming through all the electorates in that area of Sydney.The government has already demonstrated that it is not prepared to consult with local residents. In March of last year there was the disgraceful incident when the government shipped out spent fuel rods to Dounreay through my electorate of Barton in a clandestine operation between midnight and 2 a.m. without telling people in the electorates.Recently, a British ship was carrying Japanese nuclear waste around our shores and the government did not tell the Australian public that that was occurring. The Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) is reported as saying that it was a security risk for the route to be public knowledge because of the potential for terrorism to sink the ship. That is precisely the response I got from ANSTO to the March shipment issue. ANSTO considers itself above the law because its nuclear science is so sensitive.But in the meantime the residents of all our electorates have to bend over and cop it. They do not have any input whatsoever into what is happening. It is a circumstance where there has been no identification of accountability and no assumption of risk. For instance, who was responsible in that Dounreay shipment—was it ANSTO, the truck driver or the police who were supervising in case of an accident or some terrorist attack? Who would the residents have sued if it had occurred?I point out to the government that you cannot buy insurance for a nuclear disaster. Mercantile Mutual, for example, says that loss, damage or liability as a result of the use, existence or escape of nuclear weapons material or ionising radiation from, or contamination by radioactivity from, any nuclear fuel or nuclear waste from the combustion of nuclear fuel is excluded from their policy.Homes and residents in all our areas are not insured against damage from nuclear material and trucks are going to be coming past them day and night. In the April 1996 report of the Senate Select Committee on the Dangers of Radioactive Waste, entitled No Time To Waste , there is this comment about the compliance with the transport code in respect of the transportation of waste:. . . the [Transport] Code requirements are often not followed simply because of the unavailability of appropriate transport containers, or the lack of understanding of the Code or both.With the code unworkable, nuclear fuel from all over Australia coming through our electorates into Lucas Heights and ANSTO exempted from state law, our residents are again supposed to cop it. Their kids are sleeping at night, and they do not know if there is a truck carrying contaminated material is going past their front yards. That is an outrageous and unnecessary situation.The minister did not have to go anywhere near this area. He could have left it at examining what is going to happen with Lucas Heights and the feasibility of other sites for the disposal of waste. Instead, he has pre‐empted all the inquiries that were taking place, saying: `Let us dive into this new economic opportunity—that is, contaminating Australia. The government is to be condemned for causing the fear that it has. (Time expired)

The member for Bonython (Mr Martyn Evans) has made a complete fool of himself, and so has his mate the member for Barton (Mr McClelland), who had to follow on after having heard the minister make it very clear in his answer to a question at question time that the government has not made any decision. It could not be any clearer than that.I feel sorry for the poor members of the Labor Party who have had to get up and put this MPI. Obviously, the Labor Party were desperate to find something to put up here. They thought about the poor old member for Bonython and thought: `He hasnt really had much, and he put this one up because he could not think of much else. It is very sad. But it reflects the judgment that the Australian people made just over 12 months ago when they put the Labor Party over there because they realised that they were no longer fit for government.That is doubly or trebly true of the former member for Hughes—I will come back to that, because that really was the consequence of what had happened. Thank God, he is no longer here, because of some of the damage he did. If you want to look at what can be damaging for the Australian community and for the people of Hughes in particular, have a look at what the former member was trying to do to this country.Not only is this a sadly misguided MPI but it is also—because of the way the arguments have been presented to the chamber today—one of the most irresponsible in a long time. It is most unfortunate. It does nothing for the credibility of the opposition and very little for the credibility of this chamber to have people coming in here and making such utterly irresponsible and misleading statements.

name: Mr ANDERSON
role: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)
content: —I move:That the bill be now read a second time.This dairy produce levy bill has two purposes. Firstly, this bill, in conjunction with the Australian Animal Health Council (Live‐Stock Industries) Funding Amendment Bill 1997, will establish a statutory levy to fund the dairy industrys contribution to the Australian Animal Health Council Ltd. Secondly, this bill will double the maximum research levy rate specified in the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Act 1986.The Australian Animal Health Council Ltd, or AAHC for short, has been established as Australias peak animal health body. Its mission is to ensure that Australias animal health service system is capable of maintaining acceptable national animal health standards which meet both consumer needs and market requirements in domestic and international markets.AAHC is jointly owned and funded by the Commonwealth, state governments, the Northern Territory government and the peak representative bodies of Australias livestock industries, including the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation. To date, the dairy industrys contribution to AAHC has been met from surplus moneys paid to the Dairy Research and Development Corporation upon cessation of the exotic animal disease program and supplemented by a payment from the Australian Dairy Corporation.The peak industry body, the Australian Dairy Industry Council, has sought the establishment of a levy mechanism as a transparent means of meeting the industrys funding commitment to the AAHC, as currently occurs with Australias other livestock industries. The levy would be imposed in the same manner as other dairy industry levies, that is, on the milk fat and protein content of an individual producers milk supply.The need to increase the maximum research levy rate has arisen because the current operational research levy rate, which partially funds the activities of the Dairy Research and Development Corporation, is very close to the legislated maximum rate. The present situation provides very little scope for further increases and may significantly curtail the ability of the Dairy Research and Development Corporation to respond to the needs of the industry in the near future.I would point out that a doubling of the maximum research levy will not automatically lead to a rise in the actual research levy rate paid by producers. Rather, it will provide scope for the dairy industry to seek government approval for an increase in the actual levy rate, as the need arises. The increase in the maximum research levy rate has the full support of the Australian Dairy Industry Council.The dairy industry has enjoyed significant growth in recent years, with milk production in 1996‐97 expected to pass nine billion litres for the first time on record. Around half of this production will be exported with the value of exports expected to be about $1.8 billion. These amendments will enhance the capacity of the dairy industry to undertake animal health and research and development activities which, in turn, will contribute to further industry growth and improved competitiveness in domestic and international markets. I commend the bill to honourable members and hand over the explanatory memoranda.Debate (on motion by Dr Theophanous ) adjourned.

name: Mr PROSSER
role: Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs)
content: —I move:That the bill be now read a second time.The purpose of this bill is to amend the Excise Tariff Act 1921 (the Tariff Act) to ensure the continuing excisability of all beverages which contain distilled alcohol, including spirits, regardless of their alcohol content.Under item 2 of the schedule to the Tariff Act, `spirituous beverages are subject to duties of excise, which are calculated at a dollar amount per litre of alcohol in each beverage. The term was introduced into the Tariff Act in 1985 with the intention of making excisable any beverage that contained a spirit. Since that time, all such beverages have been treated as excisable regardless of their alcohol content, including beverages whose alcohol content ranges from five per cent to nine per cent, for example, the rum and cola mixer drinks.In November 1994 Carlton and United Breweries, CUB, commenced the manufacture of the product known as `Subzero Alcoholic Soda which had an alcohol content of approximately 5.5 per cent. The Australian Customs Service, the ACS, considered `Subzero excisable under subitem 2(H) of the schedule to the Tariff Act as a spirituous beverage. CUB appealed the decision of the ACS to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the AAT.On 7 June 1996 the AAT determined that the production of `Subzero, with such a low alcohol content by volume, could not be described as spirituous and was therefore not excisable under subitem 2(H). The decision was based on what the AAT considered is commonly regarded as the definition of `spirit in the community, which is a strong alcoholic liquor usually containing not less than 37 per cent alcohol by volume. The ACS is appealing this decision to the Federal Court.Since the AAT decision, CUB has ceased manufacturing `Subzero using alcohol derived by distillation. However, there are several other companies—UDA, Remy Australia, Swift and Moore and Angove—who manufacture beverages of low alcohol content which are based on, for example, brandy or whisky. The ACS has continued to impose excise duty under subitem 2(H) on these beverages as they are considered by the ACS to be spirituous beverages. The payments of excise duty by these other manufacturers are being made under deposit in accordance with section 154 of the Excise Act 1901 on the basis that, since the AAT `Subzero decision, these manufacturers allege that these beverages are no longer excisable.Prior to this decision, there was no dispute with manufacturers of the low alcohol beverages using distilled alcohol as to their excisability nor to their proper classification to subitem 2(H) of the schedule to the Tariff Act.In order to ensure the continuing excisability of all beverages containing distilled alcohol, it is proposed to amend the Tariff Act to:(i) delete all references to `spirituous beverages in the schedule and item 2 (item 1 of schedule 1 refers); and(ii) clarify that excise liability is imposed upon all beverages which contain distilled alcohol (new subitem 2(H), item 2 of schedule 1 refers).The combination of these amendments will remove any connotation as to the strength that an alcoholic beverage must be before it will be excisable. All such beverages will continue to be excisable regardless of their alcohol content and the excise duty will be calculated according to the alcohol content of the beverages.It is also proposed that the amendments will take effect on and from 3 February 1996. The effect of the retrospective commencement date of the amendments will be to extinguish all rights of appeal to the AAT in relation to the excisability of low alcohol beverages and all rights to refunds of excise duty in respect of such beverages. The commencement of the amendments on this date is considered justifiable on the following grounds:(a) As previously referred to, the intention of the term `spirituous beverages was to make excisable any beverage that contained a spirit and there had never been any dispute as to this intention prior to the `Subzero case. It is considered that the amendments are not altering the law with respect to alcoholic beverages as it stood at the time of the `Subzero decision but are merely clarifying what was the status quo. It is therefore considered appropriate that the amendments commence on 3 February 1996 to remove the technical loophole which was uncovered in the Tariff Act by that decision which this amending legislation is now removing.(b) The commencement of the amendments on 3 February 1996 would not require the retrospective recovery of any excise duty from the manufacturers of the alcoholic beverages. The excise duty has continued to be paid by the manufacturers, under deposit, and the 3 February 1996 commencement would protect the government against all claims for recovery of this duty. If the amendments do not commence on 3 February 1996, however, the government might be liable to pay $12.6 million in refunds of excise duty if the Federal Court confirms the AAT decision in favour of CUB. Given that the products manufactured by these companies have been sold duty paid, such a favourable decision to the companies would represent a windfall gain to them, with little chance that it would be returned to the consumers of the product.The proposed amendments, including their financial impact, are outlined in greater detail in the explanatory memorandum. I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.Debate (on motion by Dr Theophanous ) adjourned.

role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)
content: —I move:That the requested amendment be made.This legislation is an important part of quality assurance in a very important developing Australian industry. Our export education industry is now, on some measures, bigger than the wheat industry. It is a $1.9 billion a year industry. It attracts over 50,000 students every year to our country. As one distinguished academic said to me graphically but inelegantly the other day, `Every overseas student on our campus is $100,000 on the hoof for Australia.Mr Latham interjecting —
debateinfo: EDUCATION SERVICES FOR OVERSEAS STUDENTS (REGISTRATION CHARGES) BILL 1996
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr ABBOTT
role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)
content: —It was graphic and descriptive. This legislation is an important part of the quality assurance process. It is a continu ation of the scheme that was introduced by the former government as a result of the unfortunate fact that 15,000 or so overseas students had to be bailed out by the taxpayers after their ELICOS colleges had gone under.The original legislation counted every student equally for the purposes of the registration charge. This amendment specifies that students doing courses 26 weeks or less will only count for half that value for the purposes of the registration charges. It acknowledges the large number of students doing short courses. I suppose the amendment means that the scheme can be rendered analogous to the purchase of motor car insurance: we are not only providing a discount for fleet buyers but also, in a sense, providing a discount for low mileage.The problem with the original piece of legislation was brought to the attention of the government by the industry associations, by the opposition, by the Australian Democrats and by the Greens. As a result, this amendment has gone through the Senate and it has now come before the House. May I say that the process by which this was achieved in the Senate is an example of how a responsible upper house can improve legislation. I commend the amendment to the House.

name: Mr TANNER
content: —Further to the comments of the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham), I would just like to add with respect to the abolition of the accelerated depreciation provisions regarding Australian ships that this is part of a broader attack on Australias maritime industry by this government and it is particularly inappropriate when you consider the availability of accelerated depreciation for a range of other equipment, particularly in the agricultural and mining sectors.There are two key points that I would like to make in this debate on this issue. The first is that, almost without exception, the countries that Australia competes with in the maritime industry support their industries in some form or other with provisions such as accelerated depreciation, tax rebates for their seafarers and other initiatives. This is widespread throughout the world. It is not a level playing field. The situation in this industry is that virtually all of the players substantially subsidise their shipping industries.Australia has little hope of being able to be a significant player in the maritime industry without such supports. The former government put these supports in place, and not at huge cost—significant contributions but not at enormous cost to the budget—and without those supports the Australian shipping industry is likely to dwindle fairly rapidly into virtually nothing. It is something that suits the ideological orientation of this government, which essentially sees transport as nothing more than a cost, that it is a cost to miners and farmers and that it is not an industry of importance in its own right. Yet, in areas like aviation and the maritime industry, transport delivers substantial export dollars, improves our balance of payments situation and, of course, provides skilled and well‐paid jobs for Australians.If this provision is passed by this parliament, it will ensure the further export of Australian jobs and the further incursion of flags of convenience shipping into Australia with all of the threats that that imposes, particularly to our marine environment, and it will ensure that we have a reduction in our overall trading situation.Australia is the fifth biggest maritime nation on earth. In terms of volume carried per kilometre, Australia is the fifth largest market for shipping in the world. A situation where something like 97 per cent of that market is filled by foreign shipping is something that I do not think should be allowed to continue, yet this government clearly wants to see it at 100 per cent.The second point that I would make with respect to this provision is that, when you actually look at the various accelerated depreciation provisions that are available in other sectors, the hypocrisy of the governments position becomes very apparent. When you look at things like bulldozers, crop‐dusters, tractors, a whole range of agricultural equipment—and I am sure the Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan) knows this only too well because of his background—you see that accelerated depreciation of 20 per cent, which is what the former shipping provision was, up to as high as 40 per cent for things like crop‐dusters is almost universal across a wide range of high cost major capital equipment in agricultural and pastoral industries.One of the things this proposal exposes is that this government does not mind subsidies and does not mind a bit of assistance here and there provided it is to their mates. When it is for industries that they do not approve of, when it is for industries that they are ideologically opposed to, they then say, `No, you cannot have any assistance, even when there is a strong case for it because of the nature of the international marketplace where there is widespread assistance amongst our competitors.This is a very stark contrast: a government that is prepared to have accelerated depreciation for the industries where it draws a lot of its political support from but for those where it does not see itself as politically favoured—even though they are just as important to Australias overall economic position—it says, `No, we will get rid of that support. We do not want to have anything to do with it.The Australian community, the Australian maritime industry, the Australian shipbuilding industry and the various industries associated with the provision of maritime services will be the losers. It will not just be the Maritime Union of Australia and the seafarers, which the government hates. It will not just be those people and their jobs that are affected. There will be a range of flow‐on effects as a result of the attacks on the maritime industry, of which this abolition of accelerated depreciation is but one part. Those flow‐on effects will spread right through a variety of industries and a variety of economic opportunities and will ultimately have a negative impact on our balance of payments.

content: —As I outlined in the second reading debate, the Labor Party is opposed to this particular provision. I would like to hear from the government as to whether or not their consultation went beyond the captains of industry and actually got to the shop floor to consult with the average working Australians who will be affected by this change.Item 8 agreed to.Remainder of schedule 3—by leave—taken as a whole, and agreed to.Schedules 4 and 5—by leave—taken together.Amendments (by Mr Miles )—by leave—proposed:(1) Schedule 4, item 2, page 19 (lines 16 to 20), omit the definition of base time , substitute:base time , in relation to a public entity, means:(a) the last moment of a day within the period beginning on 1 July 1985 and ending on 30 June 1986 that is chosen by the entity and is a day the choice of which will result in a determination that gives a reasonable approximation of the natural persons who held underlying interests in the assets of the entity at the last moment of 19 September 1985; content: —Whilst we are dealing with schedules 4 and 5 together and the governments amendments to them, I will try to break up my remarks a little to give the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister (Mr Miles) an opportunity, if he wishes to take it, to respond to some concerns I have with the detail. They are not only my concerns, I might add; they are also those expressed by the Taxation Institute of Australia and the Corporate Taxpayers Association.They have told me that they do not accept the view, when talking about schedule 4, major underlining interests, that the concept of backdating from the date of an unusual trade has always been part of the framework of section 160ZZS or its administration. I did touch on that in my speech in the second reading debate and I referred to an income tax ruling by the commissioner. I have already made that point, but I do not think, in summing up the second reading debate, that it was addressed. The parliamentary secretary may be able to comment on that.Furthermore, the two bodies to which I have already referred are not of a mind to accept that it is appropriate for schedule 4 to specify dates by which underlying ownership analysis should be completed to impose substantial sanction where this does not otherwise occur. They are also very toey about the reservation being provided at the discretion of the Commissioner of Taxation to override the one per cent notional shareholder test. Furthermore, they make the point more than adequately that the definitions of abnormal trading are excessively broad. I might go into that in a little detail, depending on the way this debate goes. The TIA and the Corporate Taxpayers Association support the use of `reasonable approximation testing as at a date proximate to 20 September 1985 and similar flexibility, in their view, should be allowed in respect of subsequent testing dates.Still on schedule 4, perhaps I could refer to the transitional provisions as spelt out in section 160ZZSA. These appear to be circular to say the least. Section 160ZZSA(1)(b) seems to exclude the new regime whenever section 160ZZS(1) has been attracted prior to 20 January 1997. But subsequent provisions appear to proceed on a contrary assumption. For example, section 160ZZSC(4) presupposes that the new regime may apply in cases where a prior public ruling imposed a requirement to test and that the test would have been failed prior to 20 January 1997. The intention appears to have been to exclude the new regime only in cases where there has already been an adverse determination under section 160ZZS and that the taxpayers involved have conceded that it applies. In all other cases, it would appear that it is intended that matters can be dealt with and, if necessary, determined independently by the commissioner under sections 160ZZSC(3) and 160ZZSC(4).The new regime imposes a positive obligation to `make a determination by an examination of its records showing whether majority underlying interests were relevantly held. (Extension of time granted) The drafting presupposes that the determination will yield either a yes or no answer. The reality may well be that such matters remain unclear, notwithstanding all the diligence that can be reasonably required and expected within the period allowed.In those cases, the company may be unable to make any determination. That might be through lack of information or merely uncertainty concerning the effect of the provision. In short, it is inappropriate to assume in such cases that the company should make an adverse determination. The failure to make a determination leads to not inconsequential outcomes for the taxpayer.The purpose or effect of requiring by examination of its records is worthy of some further consideration and clarification. For example, is the intention that the basis for determination be limited to an examination of corporate records and, if so, when? That sort of limitation may well be inappropriate. Is the intention that there be no right or obligation to go beyond records? I would like to quote direct from written information I have from the Taxation Institute of Australia. They say:Where the company fails duly to make a determination within the time allowed, the test is effectively deemed to have been failed at the commencement of the test period. The penalties or consequences which flow from this will often be inappropriate. Thus (for example) if a company fails to make a determination as at 20 January 1997, it is deemed to have acquired the asset on 20 September 1985 for a consideration equal to the market value on that date. That would be entirely inappropriate if the failure arises because the company is unable to make the determination, or fails to do so because it is not aware of an abnormal trading triggering event. It would also lead to entirely inappropriate results if, for example, the test had clearly been satisfied up to December 1985 (and had appreciated in value to that time) but it was unclear whether or not it was satisfied thereafter. The risk of such an outcome could be worse than any risk of application of Sec.160ZZS(1). It is also not in accord with the principle espoused in the Budget Papers which was that the amendments would defer the date at which assets lose their pre‐CGT status from the date when the majority underlying ownership changed to the time when the test of underlying ownership is required to be conducted.The institute goes on:The determination must be made within the `prescribed period which is defined as a period generally of 6 months duration. This period may well prove to be insufficient and unworkable.Where an adverse determination is made at 20 January 1997, the consequences may depend on whether or not the entity was `required before 20 January 1997 under a ruling to apply the tests under Sec.160ZZS . . . (3) and (4). Presumably the rulings to which this refers are IT2530 and IT2361. In cases where such rulings required that a test be made, Subsec.(4) should make it clear that the `abnormal trading or other events triggering the need to test supply the determination time.The institute goes on to demonstrate that the definitions of `abnormal trading have the very real potential to operate in circumstances which rulings 2530 and 2361 would not have been regarded as requiring that the test be made and, as a consequence, it may give rise to considerable uncertainty. (Time expired)

On two things which he raised in regard to the Corporate Taxpayers Association and the Tax Institute of Australia, the government does not agree that there is no change in policy to the old section 160ZZS. In regard to the definition of `abnormal trade, we believe that the CTA issue there is too narrow. Of course, that is a judgment which has to be made in these matters.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr ROCHER
content: —I thank the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister (Mr Miles). I am not sure whether he is aware of the detail of the TIAs concern, but the definition of `abnormal trading does bear looking at. I do not think it is just a matter for judgment; I think it is a matter of equity and perhaps even of this element of the legislation operating as intended. The definition of `abnormal trading, as proposed, might lead to it being contended that the only trading which can qualify as normal trading is trading which occurs on a stock exchange and then only if the volume is within a very narrow range.Should that be the case, the allotment of shares, however small, might be regarded as requiring that a test be made. That gets to the point, which the parliamentary secretary, I am sure, will be interested in, that allotments under employee share plans—also referred to in another schedule in this legislation—or dividend reinvestment plans might trigger these provisions. Allotment of shares, on the basis that it was abnormal, or that they might trigger the provision that it was abnormal, or on the basis that involves five per cent of the shares—although it does not alter the underlying interests at all—is part of the problem.The width of the definitions for abnormal trading, read in conjunction with the consequences of failure to make a determination, make further inappropriate results quite likely. The determination, in fact, might not be made because the company is simply unaware of facts subsequently contended to constitute abnormal trade. That is where you get into problems, once again, with giving the commissioner discretion. The interplay—I noted the assurance of the parliamentary secretary and for which I am grateful—of ITs 2530 and 2361 is presently constituted.The end result is that a failure to make a determination results in a failure of the tests under 160ZZS. I see that that may not be in the mind of the parliamentary secretary and, therefore, the government and is a matter of concern. I do not know if the parliamentary secretary wants to answer that or if I could go on to something slightly relevant, but in the same vein.

name: Mr ROCHER
content: —Where the capital shareholding is less than one per cent, at the end of the day, section 160ZZSQ reserves to the Commissioner of Taxation a discretion to disregard subdivisions providing special rules for holdings of less than one per cent. That strikes me as being totally inappropriate in light of the history—some of which I have touched on—referring to the commissioners rulings under present legislation. The special rules for holdings of less than one per cent are intended to provide the basis on which the rules are saved from being unworkable.They also provide the major criteria on which the new regime can be said to assist corporates. This section, 160ZZSQ, effectively empowers the commissioner to withdraw these features while leaving in place the various aspects of the legislation which have the effect of making changes in policy applied to the section which are adverse to taxpayers. The TIA says, in this context, that the provisions obviate the need to trace through com plying superannuation funds. It would be preferable if these provisions were excluded to foreign superannuation funds and not non-complying funds. (Extension of time granted) This will conclude my remarks under schedule 4, unless the parliamentary secretary in response raises something worthy of further comment.The need for rulings in respect of which such rulings are necessary if the new regime is to have prospects of operating fairly are of interest. For example, there are a number of provisions which provided for the exercise of discretions on the part of the commissioner—some of which I have referred to—and I would refer the parliamentary secretary to sections 160ZZSA3B, 160ZZSC(2) and 160ZZSD(2) in addition to 160ZZSQ. It was previously understood by the TIA that rulings would be made available in relation to the exercise of various discretions as long ago as last December. That understanding was arrived at last December.They seem to be under the impression that the rulings would specifically address matters such as the used dates reasonably approximate to 20 September 1985 and application of the old regime recognising a safe harbour where past events are not captured by the new rules. They and I urge that drafts of these rulings be made available for comment as a matter of priority and preferably while the legislation is still before the parliament, albeit the Senate.

name: Mr LATHAM
content: —In my second reading contribution to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4), I raised the concerns of the Australian Society of CPAs about the capital gains tax rollover relief provisions. The Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister, the member for Braddon (Mr Miles), mentioned that he had addressed some of those concerns in his summing up speech in the Main Committee. I was not able to be in the Main Committee at the time; I took the view, joined by the member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), that this debate was best conducted in the House. However, the member for Braddon has been kind enough to show me a written version of some of the things that he said in the Main Committee.One matter that I would now raise with him is the question of relief quantity in dollar terms. The main point made by the Australian Society of CPAs is that they believe they have been `hoodwinked—that is their word, not mine—and they regard these relief provisions as a sham. To quote their spokesperson, Mr Hayes: `In real terms it offers little.The government has budgeted, as stated in the explanatory memorandum, for full year costs and concessions of the order of $200 million to $215 million per annum. I would ask the parliamentary secretary to clarify, for the benefit of the parliament as well as the small business sector throughout the country, specifically these concerns of the Australian Society of CPAs: is the government still confident that the full relief cost provided for in schedules 4 and 5 amounts to $215 million per annum? If not, what revision can the government provide to the quantity of concession that the parliament is now examining?
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr ROCHER
content: —I am going on to the capital rollover stuff. Do you want to answer that now or would you like me to keep going?
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr Miles
content: —Keep going.

name: Mr ROCHER
content: —Mr Deputy Speaker, with your indulgence, I hope you do not mind us making these informal arrangements. It is easier. My interest in schedule 5 arises out of the length and complexity of the bill. There are 26 pages dealing with the small business capital gains tax rollover concession. I would say that the complexity has in very considerable measure subverted the governments policy intentions in this area.The major reason for the length and complexity of the legislation seems to be a perceived need to quarantine goodwill from the other assets of a taxpayers business—in turn, to prevent small businesses from rolling over a capital gain from the disposal of goodwill into a non‐goodwill replacement asset. This seems to be because there is a fear that operators might try to convert a capital gain—for example, a building development—and shift it into a business with excess goodwill and then claim the partial goodwill exemption for that goodwill.If someone sets out to do that, the general anti-avoidance provisions of part 4A of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 would undoubtedly apply. This is an example of how the provisions have been made unduly complex by the inclusion of unnecessary words. The Taxation Institute of Australia, on this matter, had this to say:The problem is that the Bill now leaves the genuine entrepreneurs with no effective rollover relief. For example, someone who has built up a business from nothing, so that the assets of the business will be predominantly goodwill, and who wants to attempt to turn around a moribund business where the goodwill may be worth very little, will be locked out of the concession.It is unfortunate that with the introduction of the new rollover provision, the opportunity was not taken to align it and the partial goodwill exemption provision. What policy reason can there be for the different thresholds and differing rules about associated businesses.Further, there are a number of conditions limiting the value of proposed rollover to businesses which will ultimately discourage business from seeking to make use of it. Why, for example, must current and prior year losses be first offset?Why indeed. That is not a general requirement for other rollover provisions, and its reason for inclusion in these provisions is obscure to say the least.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr MILES
role: Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister)
content: —I would like to respond to the Australian Society of CPAs comment about being hoodwinked. I think that comment came out on Tuesday, 4 March of this week in an article which responded to the fine print of the so-called CGT rollover relief. Mark Abernethy says:Central to Mr Hayes concern is the exclusionary nature of the CGT relief. On the surface, the relief seemed open to sole traders, partnerships, companies and trusts.But a closer reading of the bill showed the majority of Australias more substantial small businesses would not be eligible.Our response to that is that the provisions that apply are regardless of the structure used to run a small business.For a sole trader in a partnership, the rollover relief is available at the individual level. For a company, the rollover relief is available at the company level. For a trust, the rollover relief is available at the trustee level. This treatment merely reflects the governments announcement that rollover relief will apply to a direct interest in an asset. With regard to partnerships, if one partner buys out another partner in a two‐person partnership, the selling partner can get the rollover relief if the partner buys a new business, either as a partner in a new partnership or as a sole trader.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr LATHAM
content: —The point that has been doubted by the Society of CPAs on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) is whether the government is standing by its $215 million costing. This was also doubted, in very effective terms, by the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) in his second reading contribution earlier in the debate. If the government is standing by that amount—if that is the costing and the amount of relief to be provided—can it also provide a guarantee to the House in terms of the integrity of the tax system?It is my understanding that Treasury officials have advised the government of their concerns about the way in which some of these provisions might be open to abuse and tax minimisation. I believe it is always very important in a debate looking at a new form of tax concession to consider the flip side—a flip side that the average working PAYE taxpayer is always concerned about; that is, that the corporate sector in Australia is not being opened up for the possibility of shonky practice and that the government is standing as guardian of the integrity of the tax system. That is a very important guarantee for the government to provide in this debate, particularly when a number of parliamentarians have been made aware of concerns expressed within the bureaucracy. I would ask the parliamentary secretary if he could clarify those two matters. Does the government stand by the $215 million costing after the amendments that have been carried earlier and the public critique that has been offered by a number of organisations? And, if it is standing by the $215 million, does it also offer a guarantee to the House in terms of the integrity of the Australian taxation system?

role: Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister)
content: —This is a massive boost of $200 million or so to small businesses in Australia. Obviously, we do believe there is integrity in the taxation system. In those sorts of areas governments down through the years have experienced difficulties which were not foreseen at the time. But we have looked at that and we stand by the integrity of the system.Amendments agreed to.Schedules, as amended, agreed to.Remainder of bill—by leave—taken as a whole, and agreed to.Bill, as amended, agreed to.

name: Mr CREAN
content: —This is a continuation of my speech before I was so conveniently interrupted by emergence of question time today. I am pleased to see, Mr Deputy Speaker Reid, that you are in the chair because, before the question time break, we actually had the effect of inducing you into the House. What do we see here now when we are debating the bounties legislation, which is going to see jobs lost in all sorts of regions around the country? Not one government backbencher in the place; not one. The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore), who is at the table, is pointing to himself. He has to be here. The member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) reckons he has had the effect of changing your decision, but where is the member for Kingston (Ms Jeanes)? She has not come in in all of this debate.The member for Bendigo is prepared to come into this chamber and at least stand up for what he thinks he has done—not very effectively—but the member for Kingston is still not here. Let me remind the House of what she said. Yesterday she urged the government to be more critical of the advice it received in preparing its second budget and that cuts to industry assistance in last years budget had already hurt the state. That, indeed they have. This is one of those cuts. This is a cut to the book bounty. It has cost 300 jobs—and the minister laughs at it—at Griffin Press alone because of their inability to plan and their inability to deal with a secure investment environment because this government unilaterally cut the bounty from under their feet.The fact is—and it is important because you are in the chair, Mr Deputy Speaker—that these issues of cutting the bounty were always attempted and put up to us by Treasury. But as a government we resisted them. There were attempts to reduce these measures in the so‐called interests of the level playing field—which does not exist. We all want to get there but we are not there now. What we have is a government proposing unilateral disarmament, flying in the face of what is happening in the rest of the world and expecting our industry to be able to cope. The simple reality is that these firms could compete with overseas countries if those overseas countries did not have support and assistance. That is the truth. They are world competitive. But what they cannot do is compete and get into markets that are restricted to them in those countries.I can remember the circumstances in relation to book publishing where people in this country would lament every time they picked up a new publication which said `Printed in Singapore—printed somewhere else, printed everywhere except Australia. Australians are some of the most avid readers in the world, yet we could not get a book publishing industry in this country until Labor introduced a plan for the book industry. It did so by support through research and development initiatives as well as the book bounty—the bounty to level the playing field, the R&D to get them to invest in state‐of‐the‐art technology.But these are programs that this government has come in and slashed, regardless of the consequences. It believes it has got to pursue the budget bottom line rather than consider the consequences. It has established a Productivity Commission, but it will not give it legislative teeth to have regard to the impact on regional economies or to have regard to what our trading partners are doing when it comes to their level of assistance and support.We say that has to change. The member for Bendigo, who is in the chair, has recognised it has to change. It is just that he is impotent in getting that change. He says he has taken representations to the minister. If you have taken representations and been successful to date, as you claim, Mr Deputy Speaker, take some more submissions—because the industry is telling you. If you go and visit Maryborough, they will tell you they want this decision restored, that they want it to the end of next year—and Labor supports the extra six months.But it is also entitled to an inquiry that has regard to what is happening in the rest of the world, that has regard to how an industry can continue to position itself. If there is any commitment to regional development, to the people of Maryborough and the people of Adelaide who depend on this industry for jobs, support our amendment. I call on the member for Bendigo, when he is out of the chair, and the member for Kingston to come in and vote with us. (Time expired)
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
content: —In addressing the bounty legislation this afternoon I am fearful that tomorrows press in Bendigo will basically have a front page story going to the failure of the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) to vote for local electorate jobs. I am really concerned about this because it is an important issue to have the front page of the local papers in Bendigo tomorrow with a banner across the front `Reid votes against Bendigo electorate jobs. That is what it is really about: will the member for Bendigo vote for local jobs or will he walk away from his responsibilities?The proposition that we are in support of is very simple: the government proposes that the book bounty be abolished from 1 July rather than 20 August. So far as we are concerned, that is six months short of the original expiry date established by the Australian Labor Party. That expiry date was established in consultation with local industry in places such as Maryborough, South Australia and Queensland. It is about saying to those local employers, `If you are prepared to give it a go, then we are prepared to give you a go. We are basically saying that we are prepared to provide the necessary assistance to ensure that you are capable of growing on the export front and as part and parcel of that export growth, capable of providing additional jobs in areas of high need.It is not just places such as Bendigo that we are talking about. We are also talking about Queensland. Let us have a look at some of the high unemployment levels that currently exist in Queensland. I know the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) is not too interested in these facts. As at January 1997 what was unemployment in the north‐west of Queensland? It was 10.6 per cent. In the Rockhampton area it was 11.6 per cent and in Far North Queensland around Cairns it was 8.9 per cent—all above the national average. That is why I put it to the House that it is wrong to abolish these industry bounties, especially for the state of Queensland, the ministers home state. The abolition of these industry bounties will take Australia in the opposite direction from what is needed for its development at the moment. I suggest that, if this legislation is passed, Queensland businesses—and it will be on the head of the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism—will lose nearly $7 million.Mr Prosser interjecting —
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
content: —I know it might be a joke to the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs, better known on the other side of the House as the bagman. We are talking about a loss of $7 million to the state of Queensland for businesses of all sizes, including small businesses.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr Prosser
content: —I think you are the joke.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
content: —The minister for small business might think it is a joke, he might think job growth is a joke, but I think it is about time that the minister for small business, rather than interjecting, faced up to the fact that he is an abject failure with respect to his performance to date. He has not done a thing to try to create an environment for investment and jobs growth in Australia.In Queensland we are talking about a loss of $7 million a year in assistance from the federal government. Do you know what it means for businesses in Queensland? Some 251 Queensland businesses benefited from the industry bounty scheme in the last financial year, not an insignificant number when you are talking about high unemployment—such as in Rockhampton—of the order of 11.6 per cent. These are secondary industries that are needed to further develop that state. They are needed to broaden its industrial base. They are needed in places such as Townsville, Cairns and Rockhampton.I am waiting to see how the member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay), how the member for Leichhardt (Mr Entsch) and how the member for Capricornia (Mr Marek) vote on this amendment. They have a lot to say locally, but when they get to Canberra it is almost as if they have their feet tied together when it comes to standing up for their local electorates. They go missing in action. That is what it is about: they are not prepared to stand and fight for a decent industry policy that assists in creating job opportunities in their local regions.They are the big losers—not only with respect to the bounty legislation but they have already lost on the closure of the CES offices; and they have lost as a result of the increase in HECS payments and with respect to changes in Telstra and the loss of local jobs in the service centres. So I think it is about time they said that enough is enough. The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism has to be stood up and told the hard facts of life—that, as far as we are concerned, jobs are the order of the day. name: Mr MOORE
role: Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism)
content: —by leave—I move government amendments Nos 2 and 3:(2) Schedule 1, item 2, page 3 (line 24), omit 21 May 1997, substitute 1 October 1997.(3) Schedule 1, item 3, page 3 (line 32), omit 21 May 1997, substitute 1 October 1997.These amendments are consequent on the governments decision to extend the termination date of the book bounty. The amendments introduce an absolute end date of 30 September 1997 for book bounty claims, 90 days after the end of the bounty period proposed in the previous amendment. This will ensure that the administration of the scheme is wound up quickly and that the majority of payments for eligible productions are made as soon as possible after the end of the period of the eligible production. I commend the amendments to the House.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr CREAN
content: —It is true that these are consequential amendments. They are consequential on the government betraying the book publishing industry in this country by abolishing a bounty for them, by being forced to reverse that decision, but to only partially proceed down the reversal route. We are saying that the book bounty should be extended by another six months. This government has just voted against that and there are people who should have voted on this side, like the member for Kingston (Ms Jeanes), who still is not in this chamber, who still will not come in and defend her actions. She still will not come in and tell us why she is prepared to go to the Adelaide Advertiser and complain about the cuts to industry programs but will not come into this chamber and stand up for the people of Kingston.We also have the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid), who is still in the chair. He can at least claim that he abstained on the last vote because he was protected by the chair.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. N.B. Reid)
content: —Order! You are casting a reflection on the role that I play in the chamber.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr CREAN
content: —I withdraw the reflection. I simply make the point that you were missing in action in New York last year when it was time for standing up for the book publishing industry. We would hope that you would actually exercise a vote in favour of the people of Maryborough in your electorate, a quarter of the work force of which town depends on this book bounty. It is an industry that did not exist before Labor introduced the book bounty, an industry where, if you ever wanted to read a book in this country, you opened the first page and found that it was printed in some overseas country.The fact of the matter is this was an uncompetitive country and it could not get into the game because all the other countries were supporting their book publishing industry. Labor introduced a two-pronged attack: it said, `Invest in the technology and well give you tax deductions for it. As a government they have wiped out the tax deductions despite the fact they went to the last election promising to keep them. Broken promise, bad policy—two bad hits.But then we also had the book bounty, which we were always being told we had to get rid of. The member for Bendigo made reference to this earlier—that Labor trotted out a plan to get rid of the book bounty itself. It is true that the bureaucrats put that forward, but we opposed it. It did not come and it did not get passed. If it had have been passed, why would we be debating the issue today? So for you to come in and say that we voted down the books bounty back in 1993 is just plain wrong because, if it were true, we would not be debating this issue now.Let us understand that the only people who put book publishing on the map in this country were Labor: Labor through the books bounty, Labor through industry support. Labor has seen the growth of this industry, an industry which has seen a doubling of exports in the space of time in which it has been in place, an industry which previously saw non‐existent jobs growth. There has been 200 per cent export growth over the past 12 years that this plan has been in place under Labor, and it has taken them six months to abolish it, despite the fact they told no-one during the election campaign they would do it.I would have liked to have seen Deputy Speaker Reid out campaigning in Maryborough saying, `Have we got a plan for you when we get into government. We are going to get rid of the books bounty, which is going to wipe out a quarter of the work force in Maryborough. That would have been a great campaign! But he did not say that, of course; he said quite the opposite. He said, `Were going to keep it, and then he comes along and is part of the decision to abolish it. It is a disgrace.We have the member for Kingston shedding crocodile tears in todays Adelaide Advertiser saying, `Cuts to industry assistance in last years budget already hurt the state, but will she be in the House today? She has not attended except to vote, and then she voted the wrong way. She is inconsistent the position she talks about in the press and inconsistent in representing her constituents in this chamber.The facts of the matter are that Labor is the only party that has been prepared to support the book publishing industry in this country and it is the coalition which has come along as the new vandals—wreck the industry, wreck regions and put them at the mercy of the international marketplace where there is no such thing as a level playing field.

name: Mr Crean
content: —I am deeply offended and I ask him to withdraw.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr TUCKEY
content: —I would because I can think of worse things he is.
Speaker: N/A

content: —Order! The honourable member would help the House if he directed his remarks through the chair.

name: Mr Crean
content: —Did you? Has he withdrawn, Mr Deputy Speaker?

name: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
content: —Yes.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr Crean
content: —I did not hear him say that.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr TUCKEY
content: —I withdrew, now you sit down. The reality is that promises were made—and supported by the shadow minister at the table in the election prior to the last one—that there would be no new taxes, but that it was the dreadful coalition that was going to restructure taxation to give the book industry, to give the motor car industry and to give everybody else a tax regime that at that time would have, for instance, taken $700 or $800 out of the manufactured cost of a motor car.They stood up and said, `You dont need anything of that and, whats more, we will give you l-a-w tax cuts without imposing any additional taxation at all. What did you do? You came to office, you cancelled the l-a-w tax cuts and you imposed 6c a litre on distillate fuels and you tell us about decentralisation. What is the worst tax you can put on decentralisation? Fuel tax.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr Crean
content: —Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order, and it relates to relevance. For the purposes of the member for OConnor, this is a debate about the books bounty. He has not yet once mentioned books or the impact of this decision and you should get him to speak to the issue.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER
content: —There is no point of order. I have been listening closely to the member for OConnor. This has been a far ranging contribution, as the member for Hotham and the member for Batman know, but I do invite the member for OConnor to return to the text of the bill.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr TUCKEY
content: —At the very point of interruption, I was making the point about decentralised industry. I kept hearing the shadow minister carrying on about your decentralised electorate, Mr Deputy Speaker, and the electorate of Kingston in South Australia, which is quite distant from all the major markets of Melbourne and Sydney. Quite clearly, book producers and book printers have to transport large quantities of paper to their premises and, of course, redistribute those books and they use road transport.The first thing that the Keating government did was put a special tax on that transport. The man is so dull that he does not think transport affects the efficiency of industries throughout Australia. He is winding his finger around saying it does not matter. The problem is that I think you believe that transport has no effect on Australian industry. It has been said by some of your colleagues on occasions that it represents about one dollar in every seven that Australians are obliged to spend. You put a substantial tax on it after the election where you promised no tax increases at all.Do not come in here with your arguments about consistency. I used to say of the Democrats that you cannot buy them, you can only rent them by the hour. That is the statement that I am going to use about you people in future because the Democrats might be socialists, but at least they have become consistent.

Speaker: N/A

name: Mr TUCKEY
content: —I am delighted to do so. I remind you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the members of the Labor Party are best described these days as having so much integrity that you cannot buy them, you can only rent them by the hour. An hour is probably longer than any one of your current policies would survive. You are outrageous in that regard.The book industry would be much better off without your fuel tax. It would be a lot better off without your $10,000 million interest charge that appeared in the budget and which would allow all sorts of financial assistance to be given in all sorts of areas. That is impossible as the government of today is obliged to address the $80,000 million of additional debt that you added to the budget bottom line. Speaker: N/A

name: Mr CREAN
content: —I thought we were actually going to get something of an explanation from the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore), but as always he is quick to cut the programs and never explain. We now have the com puter bounty. The coalition government made a core promise during the election to retain the computer bounty. This promise was clearly made because it was something that the Labor Party committed to do and committed to keep running until the year 2000.What did they do in their first budget? They broke that promise comprehensively. Now this is one of the areas that has not yet seen a reversal of form. This area plus the machine tools and robots areas have not got any relief or respite yet. Books and ships have, but not enough, and computers and machine tools and robots have not.Where, might we ask, is the consistency in that position? Do you know what the consistency is, Mr Deputy Speaker? There has been a more effective lobbying campaign run to date by the shipbuilders and book publishers in this country than there has been by the computer and machine tools and robots industries. We will still keep pursuing their interests because certainty has been taken from them.Understand that you have a computer industry in this country which has invested massively in research and development, massively in exports, massively in production and we have seen huge growth in all of those areas of activity. For example, in the last five years exports of information technology related products have trebled in this country. That has occurred because there was a certain regime introduced by Labor—a regime that was built around the partnerships for development program and included the computer bounty and the R&D concessions.Under the partnerships for development program there was a requirement for firms entering into the program to commit to levels of growth in production, R&D and exports. All of those targets and commitments have been met until now. Why will they not be met now? Because the government deceived this industry during the last election by promising to retain the bounty. It wiped it out—3½ years in one fell swoop. It also reduced the tax deductibility from 150 per cent to 125 per cent with the minister saying, `You should be thankful because it could have gone to 100 per cent. His defence was, `I have really saved you because the cuts could have been worse.This level of growth would not have occurred had it not been for the plan and the certainty introduced by Labor. The simple fact of the matter is that the manufacturing industry has grown in this country. We have seen huge growth in the exports of certain key industries—the information technology industry being amongst them—but it only happened because there was a plan behind those industries. What does the industry itself have to say about the governments decision? Mr Neville Roach, the Managing Director of Fujitsu, wrote to us saying:Both the present government and its predecessor supported the extension of the computer bounty as recently as 1995. This bipartisan support only came after a long and exhaustive period of consultation between the industry and government. Both recognised that the bounty is not a subsidy but rather a compensation to local manufacturers for additional component cost and they result from other decisions that the government had taken.N/AThis was addressing market failure. This was recognising that, if the industry was to grow, it had to have this market failure addressed. The minister is on record as saying that he recognises the need to intervene where there is market failure. Well, he recognises the need to intervene, but he has cut away the intervention. Some intervention! You recognise the problem, but you are not prepared to address the cure. It is no wonder you have had criticism from this industry.We believe this is also an area that has to be reversed. The government has to return to the commitment they made during the election and support the local information technology industry. We will be persisting with this measure to get that reversal. (Extension of time granted)What we have got is the circumstance in which there is no commitment from the minister to support an industry, though it was his promise, his policy. He went to the last election saying it. No doubt he went to his leader and said, `This is a vital area to secure because there are lots of employees in the manufacturing sector in computers, and weve got to keep them onside. We dont want to frighten anyone during the election cam paign. The minister went and sold the promise. He put it out in public terms in a document and said, `We will keep the computer bounty. Do you deny that, Minister? I know you will not get up and speak in this debate, because your position is indefensible.Mr Moore interjecting —
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr CREAN
content: —The minister says he relies on Keating. This is the person who said, `Were going to lift standards. This is the person who said, `Were going to do it differently to Labor. I tell you what: the commitments we made in terms of industry support were honoured. That is the reason why the manufacturing industry in this country had started to grow and had started to contribute.The minister might be interested in looking at todays national accounts figures because they address the question of production over the last quarter. The manufacturing sector has seen a 2.6 per cent reduction in outputs. That has occurred because of the policies that you put in place as a result of the budget.There is no point saying to the industry, as the member for OConnor (Mr Tuckey) would have us believe, that you have got interest rates down or you have done these other things if in fact you are putting them out of the game. There is no way they will stay in it. If you are undermining these industries by stripping away the mechanisms by which their exports have grown, then what you are doing is really denying this country the opportunity for significant, huge advances.The fact of the matter is that the minister has made a commitment. The only target the government has set, I might add, is a target of 200,000 new jobs in manufacturing. But every time the minister has been asked in this place to tell us what his strategy is to get there, he has not done it. He has not even asked his department to produce a strategy for it. How are you going to achieve it when, in one quarter alone, you have had a decline in manufacturing production by a massive 2.6 per cent? You come into this place and claim that everything is doing well in terms of the national accounts and that growth is on course, but growth is going down and manufacturing production has gone into the negative.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr Moore
content: —It has gone up.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr CREAN
content: —It has not gone up. Have a look at the figures yourself, if you are capable of interpreting them. Manufacturing production has gone down by 2.6 per cent in the last quarter. It is no coincidence that that reduction has occurred against the backdrop of the massive cuts to industry programs.It is no wonder the member for Kingston (Ms Jeanes) is telling you through todays Adelaide Advertiser that the cuts to industry assistance in last years budget have already hurt her state. They have not only hurt that state; they have hurt the nation—and they have hurt it to the tune of a reduction in manufacturing production.How are you going to get jobs if you have got reductions in production in the manufacturing sector? I ask you that. Where do you think these jobs are going to come from? Unless you have the supportive framework and the certainty that encourages industries to invest and to make the commitment to continue to get into those overseas markets, it simply will not materialise.I believe we have a minister in this chamber who is incapable of getting a message through and incapable of winning an argument in his cabinet. He has fallen for the view that he has to deliver budget cuts at any cost, but the costs are horrendous. They are costs to jobs, they are costs to regions and they are costs to exports.Why would you get rid of a program that saw an increase in exports and an increase in jobs? I thought the priority of this government was twofold—to correct the current account deficit and to increase job opportunities. Here you have a program that did both of those things, and they have axed it—but it is not the only area which has been axed.This is another massive betrayal of Australias manufacturing industry. This is a government that pretends to have the interests of industry at heart but will do nothing for them. This is a government that has been condemned by those same industry groups. (Time expired)
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
content: —I, like the member for Hotham (Mr Crean), am concerned about what we regard as a blatant decision by the present government to break what I thought was a fairly fundamental promise made by the current Prime Minister (Mr Howard) prior to the election just on 12 months ago. I refer to the fact that, during the election campaign—and I am sure the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) was consulted; after all, he is the Prime Ministers number cruncher—the coalition matched Labors commitment to retain the computer bounty to the end of the year 2000.I think that was a fairly important commitment. It was made in good faith, and industry took that commitment on board—as did a lot of workers and their families who depended on that commitment for the purposes of their job security and their ability in the end to look after their families.I know the Prime Minister likes to talk from time to time about the question of security—security at work, security at home, security in the community at large. But the problem is that, since the election, the Prime Minister has decided that your word is not your bond. That is what he has decided. With respect to the computer bounty and their undertaking that it shall prevail until the year 2000, your word is no longer your bond.What does the government say is the justification to achieve so-called savings? As the minister said in his second reading speech, the savings are to be achieved through the termination of the computer bounty with effect from 1 July this year. He then goes on to suggest that these bounty schemes have run their course.I suggest to the House that these bounty schemes have not run their course. I will tell you why: the level of unemployment in Australia suggests that they have not run their course. The problem for the government—and it is walking away from its responsibilities—is that not only is unemployment a major problem at the moment, but it is especially a huge problem in regional Australia and is especially a huge problem for the long-term unemployed.In that context, there is a role for government to involve itself in assisting industry; there is a role for government to involve itself in regional Australia; and there is a role for government to involve itself in trying to push and prod industry. The government needs to encourage industry to invest and to create decent job opportunities—real job opportunities—not half-baked suggestions or proposals as brought forward by the Prime Minister just on a week and a half ago with respect to the work for the dole scheme.If there are any real concerns about these issues, I refer the House to the fact that, in seasonally adjusted terms, the numbers of long-term unemployed rose from 229,500 in December to 232,700 in January. The minister wants the House to accept that the schemes have run their course. I do not accept that the schemes have run their course when you have 232,700 people in Australia who are long-term unemployed. It is interesting that there are now 30,100 more long-term unemployed Australians than in May 1996 when the Howard government began cutting decent labour market programs, including Skillshare, throughout the length and breadth of Australia.These schemes have not run their course. Australian industry expects support. The bounty scheme that prevailed in the computer industry encouraged industry to make investments, because a companys ability to make investments depends on a sense of stability and security. It is on that basis that companies are prepared to make medium- to long-term investment decisions.The coalition had a clear commitment prior to the federal election that the computer bounty scheme would exist through to 2000 and on the basis of that commitment they made decisions. They were prepared to put their money up‐front for the purposes of investing in Australia, for the purposes of securing export growth and for the purposes of securing for a large number of Australian families a sense of job security.I think it is high time that the minister stood up to the Prime Minister and said in no uncertain terms, `Where I come from in Queensland, the Liberal Party way is to honour your word. Your word is your bond. A commitment to the Australian electorate to make sure that this scheme existed through to 2000 should prevail. We should not break our word. We should ensure that industry continues to have a sense of security and on that basis they can continue to plan their investment opportunities for the future. (Time expired)Question put:That schedule 1, items 4 and 5, be agreed to.N/AConsideration (on motion by Mr Moore ) adjourned.
