name: Mr LEE
content: —I will try to make this as brief as possible. These are opposition amendments. Basically, these amendments simply seek to provide for automatic indexation of the income thresholds at which the private health insurance tax rebate cuts out. Reading through the Senate Hansard , there was a bit of confusion about whether our amendments were going to index the value of the tax rebate or whether they would index the income threshold at which the rebates cut out. Everyone who has studied this knows that it is about how we index the income limits. That is why the proposed index is average weekly earnings. I will not dwell on that, but that is the point that these amendments go to.I have two questions, Minister, that I will go through very quickly. One was that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary for the Attorney‐General (Senator Ellison) in the Senate said that one of the reasons the amendments could not be accepted was that there is no provision for them in the forward estimates. I would have expected that the forward estimates are based on a certain number of people having private health insurance. I thought in the past we had spoken about a figure of 35.5 per cent. Given that there are now only 33.2 per cent of people who have private health insurance, I would have thought there is a bit of fat in the forward estimates.Unless there is a sudden jump in the number of people with private health insurance on 1 July, there will be a bit of fat in those forward estimates which would allow, perhaps, the funding of this automatic indexation. If I am wrong, I am happy to tap the mat on that. Perhaps we can deal with that question first.
Speaker: N/A

name: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
role: Minister for Health and Family Services)
content: —My understanding is that we are dealing with the best figures we have so far, in the December quarter. We cannot really predict what will happen by the two quarters hence. There is no fat that I am aware of. I am informed that the cost over four years of doing this would be $73 million. While I can see the merit in doing it, what we have attempted to do is simply implement what we promised before the election. Honestly, if I had another $73 million, I would probably be spending it on another area of need in health. I feel we have more than acquitted our undertaking to the Australian community by implementing what we propose to do. I note in passing that similar indexation arrangements were not promised in the Labor Partys election proposal. To the best of my knowledge, there is no fat and I do not have the capacity to make that without offsetting it in the rest of my portfolio—$73 million over four years is a substantial amount to offset.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr LEE
content: —A brief debating point first, Mr Deputy Speaker. If the minister believes that an extra $73 million could be better spent in other areas of the portfolio rather than in providing tax breaks for private health insurance, I am wonder whether he is willing to now accept the oppositions point that perhaps the whole $1.7 billion could have been better spent in paying for extra operations in public and private hospitals or in other areas of private health care. I do not think I will persuade him on that point, but I thought he left me an opening on that.Finally, concerning the second question I spoke about before, at various times we have been trying to find out what the governments intentions are about the thresholds. I think we have been told that, if at some future time the government wanted to increase these income thresholds, it could do so by introducing legislation and amending the act. At one point I think we were told incorrectly in the Senate that this could be done by regulation, but my understanding is that it will require an amendment to the act and so we would be seeking to know from the minister whether the government is planning to change the thresholds. That is a crucial point. Are you planning to change the thresholds that apply to this Private Health Insurance Incentives Bill 1996?
Speaker: N/A

name: Dr WOOLDRIDGE
role: Minister for Health and Family Services)
content: —On the debating point, without carrying it too far, the whole of the $1.7 billion is being spent to implement a core election promise, and we keep our promises. There are no plans to increase the thresholds at this stage. It does not mean we would not do it; it means that we really have, only in the most early stages, started considering the 1997‐98 budget. I do not say at a future date we will not do it but, like Medicare levy thresholds under the previous government, they were not indexed but they were increased from time to time as a policy decision. We have no plans to do that at the moment. That does not mean we will not do it at some stage in the future.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr LEE
content: —The opposition will not force the House to a division on this issue. We had a division when the matter was previously considered by the House. For the record, I once again reaffirm the oppositions support for these amendments and therefore our opposition to the ministers motion that the matters be rejected.Question resolved in the affirmative.

name: Mr KELVIN THOMSON
content: —This schedule relates to the machine tools and robotics bounty, which has been described by the Metal Trades Industry Association as fundamental to the whole manufacturing sector, in that it supplies enabling technologies to most other sectors and is an important source of innovation and skills. As they point out, the decision made in last years budget to terminate the machine tools and robotics bounty will result in the cessation of an extremely successful industry program.The bounty has been instrumental in the growth of a high-technology export oriented industry. It has provided cash flow, and the MTIA say that over the past 10 years the machine tools and robotics industry has produced an export growth rate of 20 per cent per annum. The year before it generated $117 million in sales and $80 million in exports, and it paid $12 million in tax. This year, the MTIA predicts that export sales are likely to be closer to $130 million. By comparison, the cost of the bounty to the government or the taxpayer was only $2 million in 1995‐96. As the MTIA points out, cessation of the bounty will see an immediate reduction in the rate of growth of exports, and they describe that outcome as perverse. And indeed it is. It is counterproductive, because you have a decision taken on the grounds that its objective was eliminating the budget deficit, but you have a reduction in the rate of growth of exports happening here and that will have precisely the opposite effect.The MTIA also point out that the burden of the cutbacks in government spending borne by the machine tools and robotics industry is disproportionate. Not only has this industry had to bear the abolition of the bounty, which is what this schedule is all about, but over the past six months this industry has had to bear the burden of cuts to research and development programs—both the tax concession and the discretionary grants—imposition of a three per cent duty on industry inputs under the tariff concession system, substantial dismantling of export facilitation programs such as the export market development grants scheme and abolition of the development import finance facility, the DIFF. As the MTIA sum up, these new arrangements mean that now Australian producers are not operating on a level playing field but on one that is tilted straight toward our competitors goals where you have machine tools coming into the country duty free while Australian producers importing components are paying a three per cent duty. That is an extraordinary outcome. In the face of the reversal of the budget decisions to abolish the ships bounty and the book bounty, termination of this bounty represents a further slap in the face.This is a matter of particular concern to me because of its importance to manufacturing industry in the Wills electorate. By way of example, as I have mentioned previously, Farley Cutting Systems is a company based in Glenroy. It commenced business back in 1983. Its mission statement is to be a leading world supplier of systems for cutting flat metals and similar materials. It has achieved success both domestically and in penetrating markets abroad with the sale of cutting ma chines into specifically targeted sectors, such as shipbuilding and the heating, ventilation and airconditioning industries. At last count, it had 300 machine installations in more than 20 countries around the world, a staff of 75 people, turnover in excess of $12 million, with exports accounting for approximately 75 per cent of sales. It is actively involved in ongoing research and development activities—including activities with a range of external partners—and is implementing various manufacturing improvement programs to enhance competitiveness.That is a terrific achievement, but underpinning it all is the kind of support Farley Cutting Systems got from this bounty. In 1995‐96, they received $325,000 from the machine tool bounty, $100,000 from export market development grants and $900,000 from the tax concession for research and development. They have been able to claim assistance under the export market development grants from 1984 right through to 1991, and they used that sort of assistance to get into new export markets in Malaysia, China and India. What we have here is abolition of support under the export market development grants and abolition of the research from research and development. But the thing which has really knocked this company around is cancellation of the bounty—$300,000 straight off the bottom line. For that reason, because of the impact this provision has on Farley, I urge the House to oppose it. (Time expired)

name: Mr CREAN
content: —I was actually deferring to the member for Kingston (Ms Jeanes) because I finally do see her in the chamber, other than for voting purposes—

name: Mr CREAN
content: —I might just read the newspaper article again, if I have time. This is another example of the betrayal by this government of manufacturing industry. The machine tools and robotics bounty has seen huge growth in this industry sector. Since the mid‐1980s the Australian machine tools industry has become increasingly internationally competitive. For example, in the last three years we have seen Australian produc tion of bountiable machine tools increase from $95 million to $144 million, with exports more than doubling over the same period. These are not dud programs, these actually work; yet you cut them out—you cut the very base out from under them.Is it any wonder that manufacturing has declined today in the national accounts? There are a few more members of the government backbench here now—it is good to see that we are having some effect in getting them in—and if they read the national accounts figures today, the ones the Treasurer (Mr Costello) was crowing about in this chamber before, they will see that those figures show that production in manufacturing industry in the last quarter has declined by 2.6 per cent. Congratulations on overseeing the demise of the manufacturing sector in this country, Minister!Is it any wonder that the member for Kingston is forced to go into her local newspaper today and condemn the cuts that her government has introduced? She is on the record as saying that cuts to industry assistance in last years budget have already hurt the state. I say to the member, given that she is now in the chamber—she has been embarrassed into coming into this place—`If you believe it, vote with us because we are the only people who are prepared to back these industries. You are prepared to cut loose the automotive industry and the textiles industry. You have already done it with computers. You have done it with the book publishing industry which has seen 300 jobs go in your electorate in the—

content: —Oh, its out of your electorate. So, because it isnt in your electorate, it doesnt matter. You still want to get the headline, but you dont want to give any commitment to them.Ms Jeanes interjecting —

content: —Shes getting me going here, Mr Deputy Speaker, this is outrageous.

content: —It is so unusual too!
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr CREAN
content: —But I do say that, if the member is criticising in the press her own government for the cuts to industry programs, she should at least then come into the House and do something about reversing them. What you have to understand is that, because of the successful campaign that Labor has run, we have reversed decisions on the books and we have done it also in relation to the ships. What we are saying is that, if you have reversed decisions in relation to two of the bounties, why not in the other two, particularly given you made election commitments to honour them?The simple fact is that this is an industry that is providing vital input and state‐of‐the‐art technology to the shipbuilding industry, to the automotive industry and to the textile industry. This is the equipment that laser cuts—a state‐of‐the‐art world leading technology developed in Australia. Why? Because we supported R&D when we were in government. Because we recognised that, if we are going to help them export their product, they have to be assisted in overcoming the barriers to entry that exist with their trading partners, we were prepared to put a package in place to support these industries. The record speaks for itself. We have doubled exports. What we have is a real commitment to jobs and balance of payments correction. I say to the members on the backbench opposite—
Speaker: N/A

content: —Down, down, down!

name: Mr CREAN
content: —It is not down, it is up. These are increases in exports. Why dont you go and visit some of these factories? Mr Deputy Speaker, these people who interject in this House know nothing about this industry. None of them would have been there. Go and ask these industries where they were before this bounty came in and where they have come to; and where they will be as a result of your scrapping of this bounty. The simple reality is that this is an industry where we can carve out a niche market opportunity. It is an industry vital to the shipbuilding industry, the textile industry and the automotive industry. All of those industries are being hit directly. This industry is being hit directly as well, but indirectly it will collapse in on itself. (Time expired)
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr ADAMS
content: —The amendments deal with a matter which is very important to the robotic and machine tooling industries in Australia which needed a bounty to give them the opportunity to grow and get into the world market so they could compete against those in other countries who were also getting advantage and opportunity from their own governments. We have allowed our companies, by using these bounties, to achieve that goal. We have allowed them to grow and to get access into the world markets. This was a deliberate policy of the previous Labor government.This new government has come in and has cut the bounty without really thinking about or working through what sort of impact it would have. The government did not know what impact it would have. It was trying to reach that bottom line on its budget. In doing that, it has slashed away at everything. The consequences of its slashing away at everything have been the cuts in these bounties from shipbuilding to the bookbinding industry to the robotic and machine tools industry.That comes back and reflects directly onto jobs in Australia. In many respects it reflects onto regional Australia and regional jobs which are going. It is a great disappointment that the government has not even given consideration to accepting some of these amendments from our side. The government needs to become a little bit mature in the way it deals with industry policy and to take up something I believe it should take up. It has played around the edges of the shipbuilding industry bounty. It really did not do anything to try to get over its electoral problems as a result of the bad press, so it came up with a changed mechanism which really did nothing for the industry.It has gone down the same track in the bookbinding industry with the bookbinding bounty. So it has not achieved anything. It will not look at the amendments, which I believe are reasonable. It is just doing away with jobs in our country, not encouraging our industry in any way and therefore it shows itself up as the bad government that it is and it shows itself to have bad policy direction in relation to industry policy.Industry policy reflects straight back to the job situation and jobs policy reflects straight back to family policy. I do not think that this government has even thought about that. It has not thought through how one thing links to another in the overall workings of the economy. This government has failed in its industry policy and, in relation to these cuts in the bounties, it has been bad for regional Australia and for working people in Australia. I will be supporting the amendment as put.

name: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)
content: —Before I call the honourable member for Scullin, I know that he needs no reminder that this motion is dealing with items 6 to 9 and that therefore his remarks should be limited and restricted to the subject of the question.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr JENKINS
content: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I will try to ensure that I am speaking about items 6 to 9, which hopefully are about the machine tools and robots industry—because that is what we should be speaking about at this stage.Throughout this debate what the opposition has been seeking from the minister at the table, the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore), is some clear direction about where he sees industry policy going, under the government. There can be no clearer example than this decision with respect to the bounty on machine tools and robots where, by the actions of this bill and these clauses, the bounty will be ceasing 10 months earlier. It ceases on the night of the budget but was supposed to run through to 30 June 1997.Indeed, when the Industry Commission last looked at this industry it recommended that the scheme cease when it was due to end on 30 June 1977. This is something that the industry had been able to factor in. But just for the sake of the fiscal consolidation that the government has claimed was required we see that this bounty has been terminated.This is a very successful industry, and I wish to mention one particular company in the northern suburbs of Melbourne. Mentioned in debate earlier, it is Farley Cutting Systems in the suburb of Glenroy, which was in the electorate of Scullin when I was first elected to this place but was later redistribut ed out. When I had some contact and dealings with this company in the late 1980s, it had commenced only four or five years earlier. It is a truly Australian success story.Here is a business that literally started in somebodys garage. Slowly but surely, the company has been able to build its business up to where it is successfully selling its cutting machines not only to the European market but the Asian market. It has not only relied upon its expertise in putting in place the electronic controllers that control its cutters but also it has been able to be innovative in the way that it exported its product.One of the things it realised was that if it designed its cutting tools in a certain way they would fit into containers that could be airfreighted and that because of its relationship to Tullamarine airport this was an efficient way of sending its goods through to the European market. It was a company that early on saw that it had a great advantage if it had its own sale representatives in the markets.Indeed, in evidence before the Senate committee, Mr Farley, the principal of the company, talked about how it had been able to increase its business in Singapore. Four years ago it had sold something like $400,000 worth of the stuff—that is the way he talks about it. But now after placing somebody in Singapore that amount had increased to $3 million worth of orders.Simply put, what this industry needs is the confidence that it has the support of the government. Today, a media release from the MTIA has the headline `Machine Tools and Robots Industry Receives Unfair Treatment. They believe that they have been singled out, because along with the computer industry they have suffered the full effect of the announcement on budget night.This press release goes on to indicate that the bounty plus other forms of government assistance should be taken into account in the way in which this industry is able to operate in the international market. I quote from the press release:The new arrangements under the TCS—that is, tariff concession system—mean that now Australian producers are not operating in a level playing field but one that is tilted straight toward our competitors goals. Imports of machine tools are coming into the country duty free while Australian producers importing components are paying a 3 per cent duty.The Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism has to address these problems, because they jeopardise Australian jobs by sending those jobs offshore. On behalf of the people who work for companies like Farley, I ask the minister at this consideration in detail stage of this bill to rise to his feet and tell Australian industry how he is going to give them protection, cooperation and assistance to ensure that they can embark upon their successful export schemes and import replacement that they have been able to achieve under the forms of assistance that have been available to them in the past. (Time expired)

name: Mr CREAN
content: —On this machine tools and robots bounty issue, I am very pleased that the members for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) and Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson) have referred to the examples of companies within their electorates that have been very successful as a result of being able to operate within the certain environment that Labor had created with the R&D expenditures and with the machine tools bounty.I, too, have a company in my electorate, Laser Lab. I have visited companies not only in my electorate but also in other electorates. I would suggest that, if the member for Moreton (Mr Hardgrave) thinks this has been a backward going industry, he should go and visit these companies to see what they do. At times I cannot believe the ignorance which people on the other side of this parliament display. They claim to be the party of business, but they have no idea at all of how these programs that have supported industry have created jobs and exports.The fact of the matter is that we have seen huge growth in manufactured exports over the last decade. There was the report the other day that indicated that manufacturing was now 31 per cent of our export income. The Australian Chamber of Manufactures says that there is a possibility of manufacturing exports being the single biggest component—in other words, more than 50 per cent—by the year 2010 if we have an industry strategy. That is the same group that says your government has deserted them, the same group that says that there is no vision for industry and the same group that has condemned the $3.9 billion in cuts in the last budget that has seen manufacturing industries slump in this country.If there is any doubt about the slump, have a look at todays national accounts figures. They show what the impact of the $3.9 billion cut has been. Manufacturing output in the December quarter—one quarter alone—fell by a massive 2.6 per cent. Today the Treasurer (Mr Costello) was trying to claim credit for growth of three per cent over a year and 0.5 per cent in a quarter, but he is presiding over an economy that has seen manufacturing output slump by 2.6 per cent. Cant you see the danger signals?The member for Kingston (Ms Jeanes) sees the danger signals. She is prepared to go out publicly in the newspaper in Adelaide and condemn the government for its cuts to industry—to say that these cuts have really hurt South Australia. They have not only hurt South Australia; they have hurt the nation. If she really believes that they have hurt them, why doesnt she put some pressure on her government to reverse these decisions? Why doesnt she get to the minister at the table, the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore)? He has been got to by the book publishing industry and the ship industry because he has had those industries reverse themselves. It is the computers, machine tools and robotics industries that still require significant assistance. He will not give it to them. He goes to the election saying that they are entitled to it, but he will not give it to them.The other thing that is most disturbing, I must say, about the machine tools and robots bounty is that the Industry Commission, in its draft report on machine tools and robotics, recently recommended that the bounty be retained. What we have is a government that commissions a report and ignores it. I just hope that they show the same approach in ignoring what they have recommended for cars and what we know they will recommend for the TCF industry.This is a government that is not prepared to take account of the realities, is not prepared to reward success, is not prepared to encourage the growth of our manufacturing sector, is not prepared to get behind regional development and is not prepared to support programs that get jobs—jobs for Australians—and correct the balance of payments.The key measure in all of this is export growth and jobs growth. The two most important criteria that you set your standards by—correction of the current account and employment growth—and you wipe a program that achieves it. Do you understand the stupidity of that program? What I am saying to the backbench of this party is: get real in understanding the impact. Get into the ear of the minister, because he will not support the role the Treasurer— (Time expired)

name: Mr MARTIN FERGUSON
content: —I am pleased to stand this evening with the member for Kingston (Ms Jeanes). I think she was right, as reported in the Adelaide Advertiser today, when she said, very clearly, that the coalition was badly advised. I agree that she needs to stand up and be counted. She got the headline in Adelaide today. The question is whether she will get the headline in Adelaide tomorrow for voting with the opposition—for voting with respect to concern about jobs and the need for certainty in industry.I take note of the fact that the member for Kingston is concerned. She has questioned the quality of the Howard governments economic advice and attacked economic rationalism as a cancer on the nation. That reminds me of the type of speech that the member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) would make. He is also concerned, as is the member for Kingston, with the lack of decent economic advice that has been given to the Howard government.The member for Kingston went on to say that she urged the government to be more critical of the advice it received in preparing its second budget. She understands the damage that the decisions of the current government has imposed on Australian industry. She understands that decisions such as the decision to bring forward the date on which the robot bounty will cease to operate is wrong.The Howard government is going the wrong way if it is concerned about the needs of industry and about a degree of security and certainty required in industry on the basis of which investment decisions should be made. Even the Industry Commission itself recommended retaining the bounty until its legislated expiry date of 30 June 1997. We are proposing an amendment to ensure that we give the Industry Commissions recommendation an opportunity of being put in place.I suggest to the House that bounties established under the Labor government were aimed at encouraging investment in industry, aimed at encouraging investment in local manufacturing and aimed at trying to facilitate job growth and exports. More importantly, they have achieved their desired results. That is why, because of those ill‐informed decisions of the last budget, the member for Kingston is correctly reported in the Adelaide Advertiser today as being concerned about the wrong economic direction that the Howard government is taking and about the impost of economic rationalism. It is a cancer on the nation, it is a cancer on the government, and it is time that the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) stood up, stood beside people such as the member for Scullin and the member for Kingston and forced this government to review its decision.I believe, as do many in the House this evening, that this is not about savings; this is about investment in Australias future. The bounties have continued to deliver with respect to the future of Australia. We should leave them in place to ensure that companies which made investment decisions on the basis of this legislative framework are able to retain the full benefits that they were promised before the last election.Consideration interrupted.

name: Mr ALBANESE
content: —I rise tonight to raise the issue of legal aid cuts. I spoke at a rally in Marrickville against these cuts some two weeks ago that was attended by many members of the community and by the Marrickville Legal Centre. Today, most importantly, I lodged a petition with 6,817 signatures to be presented to this House, calling on the government to restore funding.Today there were demonstrations right around this nation. Approximately 2,000 people gathered in Queens Square in Sydney to express their anger and there were similar gatherings in every capital city in this country. This is not an issue that is going to go away. The slashing of the legal aid budget has significant ramifications for our system of law and the opportunity of every citizen to be equal before the law in this country.Speakers at the rallies today included Patrick Fair, the President of the Law Society of New South Wales, David Bennett, the President of the New South Wales Bar Association, Nora Maguire, President of the Combined Pensioners Association, Harry Herbert of the Uniting Church, Angela Chan from the Ethnic Communities Council, Maurie OSullivan, the President of the PSA, and Meredith Burgmann from the New South Wales parliament. I think the diverse backgrounds of these speakers shows the depth of the opposition to these cuts.These cuts represent an attack on the right to fair trial and due process. The capacity of individuals to launch an action against others is also threatened. The cuts to legal aid in New South Wales of over $10 million represent a significant proportion out of the $33 million to be cut nationally because legal aid is not in the form of a tied Commonwealth grant. This is a cynical attempt by the Commonwealth to rewrite over two decades of legal funding policy. We are now being accustomed to this sort of revisionism, and it is traditionally disadvantaged groups that will suffer most, as they always do, when cutbacks occur in the public sector.Legal aid staff and community legal centre staff are already overworked and have been for as long as I can remember. I am not a lawyer, but I do know that our legal system is far from classless already. When you cut legal aid, you put at risk the rights of all the people who rely on those services—the elderly, children, women, the disabled, indigenous people.The Howard government talk about battlers, but do they really know what it is like to not have the money or access to the expertise that could either help them defend a trumped up charge or prosecute an unscrupulous company? The fact is that they do not. Without adequate legal aid funding, the rights of people to defend or prosecute a criminal or civil matter will not only be jeopardised but, in many cases, eliminated.As a case in point, the victory by retirement home tenants last year in the Supreme Court of New South Wales against massive increases in their weekly rental licence fees may not have even got to court, let alone resulted in an overturning of that unscrupulous action. On a more basic level, what about the rights of women who seek community legal centre advice about an abusive spouse or partner? Cut out those community legal centres and you cut out this vital lifeline for victims of abuse.As recently as two weeks ago, we saw the New South Wales state government having to step in and fund a criminal retrial following a hung jury. These are expensive trials and the state government simply cannot step in wherever there is a funding shortfall. The other side of the coin is that we may be jeopardising the physical safety of the community by not being able to fund these retrials.Already we have seen a number of cuts—legal aid in victim compensation matters and legal aid for committals, and caps have been placed on the funding of criminal and family law matters. So you either do not get help or you get help until the money runs out. That is no way to run a legal system in this country in 1997.This is a measure which is essentially about taking away the legal rights of ordinary citizens, and I say to those opposite, particularly those from non-urban areas, that this will have a devastating impact on regional areas in Australia. Approximately 110,000 advices of representation in New South Wales are out side of Sydney. The sort of person in these regional areas who normally seeks representation, who goes through this system, quite often is a woman with children. These cuts are unconscionable and should be opposed. (Time expired)
Speaker: N/A

name: Ms JEANES
content: —It seems that my comments in the House on Monday got the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) more than just a little bit excited earlier today. I would have to say it got me a little bit excited when I heard that he had accused me of talking up my view on the future of the automotive industry at home in Adelaide but not here in Canberra.It also got me a little bit excited when I heard that he wanted me to defend the workers at Griffin Press when he was grizzling in this House about the book bounty. I am always happy to defend workers, but Griffin Press is at least 10 kilometres out of my electorate, so the member for Hotham offers the House just another example of his ignorance on South Australian matters.I would like to expand upon the views that I expressed in this House and that were later reported in the Advertiser after I spoke here on Monday, the very place where he apparently accuses me of not standing up for the industry. The doctrine of economic rationalism commenced its pervasion of the Canberra bureaucracy under the previous Labor government, a government of which the member for Hotham was a minister for some six years, I understand. The member for Hotham entered this parliament in 1990. A year later, Michael Pussey warned that economic rationalists had `invaded the bureaucracy by exposing the extent of the spread of their doctrine through Canberra in his book entitled Economic Rationalism in Canberra .I would like to say just a few words about the economic performance of the previous Labor government, particularly in relation to the automotive industry. The current debate, as everyone knows, has centred on the issue of tariff reduction. The Labor Party in government reduced tariffs in the car industry from 57.5 per cent in 1984 and committed it to a target of zero per cent in 2010—and they called the member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) `Captain Zero. Now they have suddenly become the saviours of the automotive industry by proposing a slow down in the rate of reduction by announcing that they have adopted Ian Webbers position. Thank you very much, but we on this side of the House do not need their help. We will support the industry as we believe fit, by working with the industry.I would like to offer you a bit of advice, seeing that you have adopted Mr Webbers position as your policy. I suggest that you approach Mr Webber and offer him the job as your industry spokesperson. He might give us real opposition on this matter backed up by real arguments, not opportunistically adopted ones.The member for Hotham was the Minister for Employment, Education and Training in a government that spent billions of taxpayers dollars on labour market programs that did not create the jobs to put the people they were training into. They spent $800 million on some programs that had a success rates costing up to an astonishing $140,000 per job obtained.The programs were so expensive that the Labor government had to flog off their crown jewels, like Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank, in order to pay for them when they should have been retiring their debt in order to reduce the strain on interest rates which was one of the many factors that they let kill off the small businesses that could not afford to employ the people they were churning through the member for Hothams training programs.What the member for Hotham and perhaps another member or two on the other side do not like very much is the fact that the member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus), the member for Sturt (Mr Pyne), the member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) and many other members on this side of the House, including myself, are sticking up for our constituents who work in the automotive industry.We are expressing views in support of our car industries, and those opposite do not like it. We are actively participating in the debate to do our best to ensure that the automotive industry in this country not only remains viable but continues to grow through its increasing export activity on the international markets.You would have to be blind not to notice that there are a range of views expressed on this side of the House. Naturally, I believe that my view is the correct one and the one that will ensure the future growth of the industry. Any member who has anything to do with the automotive industry in their electorate who did not get up in this place and outside to promote their vision for the future of the industry would be derelict in their duty if they sat quietly and let the debate go by. I therefore welcome and enjoy the views expressed by the member for Corangamite.Those on the other side of the House can continue with their attempts to seek political mileage out of the range of views that government members legitimately hold, but your attempts at opportunism will fail because we can see through your thinly veiled efforts. The member for Hothams attempts to pick up on our language, to get members like myself to support his amendments when his government had 13 years to address the problems that we are now having to fix, are just a little bit too transparent. You are going to have to do a lot better.I stand by my comments that the doctrine of economic rationalism has too much influence throughout the bureaucracy, and those opposite let it happen. What the people on the other side really do not like is the fact, as I pointed out to the House on Monday, that the one thing that the Industry Commissions draft report has achieved is the pulling together of a very diverse group of people—people like a number of my South Australian colleagues and myself; the South Australian and Victorian Premiers; your traditional supporters, who see that we are genuine in our efforts to save their jobs; the car industry workers and their union representatives; the car companies and component companies. That leaves no place for those opposite, and they do not like it. So stop playing around with the jobs of my automotive industry workers. They will not thank you when your opportunism explodes in their faces. (Time expired)

name: Mr SERCOMBE
content: —The 12th of June is the National Independence Day for the Republic of the Philippines and 12 June 1998 will mark the centenary of national independence for the Philippines. The circumstances surrounding that declaration of independence were that for a number of years the Filipinos rebelled against Spanish colonial rule and on 12 June 1898 they declared national independence. They did this at the time of a war that was being fought between Spain, the colonial country, and the United States. In July 1898, after Filipino independence had been declared, United States forces arrived in the Philippines and Spanish forces surrendered to American forces. There was considerable Filipino resistance to that situation. Nonetheless, the Philippines was ruled until 1946, with a period of Japanese occupation, by the United States. Nonetheless, Filipinos regard 12 June as their National Independence Day.Australia has a strong bilateral relationship with the Philippines. If one looks at some of the indicators, one can see that in 1995-96 merchandise exports from Australia to the Philippines were worth $1.1 billion, which represented a growth of nearly 30 per cent on the previous year. That compares to merchandise imports from the Philippines of only $0.3 billion. Australia has an overwhelming trade advantage.The Philippines is the fourth highest country, coming after PNG, China and Indonesia, in terms of development assistance. There are a range of security arrangements associated with our relationship. There are also in excess of 120,000 people in the Filipino community in Australia. Very notably, they assume Australian citizenship at a very high rate.Next year provides a very real opportunity for Australia to take forward its bilateral relationship with the Philippines in meaningful ways. The Philippines government has established the National Centennial Commis sion, which is planning a great year to showcase Philippines culture, society, technology and economic development. The event will be attended by participants from around the world.One of the key features of the event will be a centennial exhibition which will run from December 1997 to August 1998 at the Clark special economic zone, which is a 60‐hectare site. This presents an ideal opportunity, in my view, for the Australian government to significantly take forward Australias bilateral relationship with Philippines. The Philippine authorities are extending invitations to countries around the world. One of the features at the exhibition is described in their document as follows:Global Island . . . Philippines and the World: 1898 and Beyond . . . participants will address the past, present and future relations of the Philippines with other countries. A thematic approach shall be adopted for this island where friends of the Philippines with close historical and special ties with the country, which have been invited to cooperate to honour the centennial in concrete ways . . .There are obviously a range of demands on Australian foreign policy in promoting bilateral relationships, but the Philippines, as I have indicated, is a very significant trading partner. Large numbers of former Filipinos make their homes in Australia. They have very real and strong connections with Australia.There are opportunities for considerably taking forward our two‐way economic relations. In that respect, it is a bit disappointing that the Minister for Trade (Mr Tim Fischer), in his recent report on trade outlook to this parliament, did not significantly address opportunities and issues with respect to the Philippines. I simply put to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) and the Minister for Trade the outstanding opportunity that the centennial year, 1998, presents and suggest that they instruct their officials as a matter of urgency to ensure that Australia is very much present at that event and very much takes the opportunity of contributing to a closer bilateral relationship.

name: Mr HARDGRAVE
content: —Tonight I would like to raise a serious matter and, as a consequence of this speech, praise not condemn, enhance not detract, the reputation of members of the Australian Defence Force. I would like to address the matter of the death in September 1994 of Private Jacinta Watson at the Greenbank Rifle Range just outside my electorate.Jacinta was a proud member of the ADF reserve and was in her early 20s at the time of her death. She was robbed of her true potential contribution to our country by the accidental discharge of a weapon at Greenbank. Since then, her parents have wanted justice and answers.I want to refer especially to a letter dated 10 June 1996 which was sent by Jacintas mother, Mrs Genia Otuszewski, to the Chief of the General Staff, Lieutenant General John Sanderson. It took General Sanderson four months to reply to the letter from my constituent, Mrs Otuszewski. The reply came on 8 October 1996. I contend that this is a very poor and insensitive treatment of a family—to think that it took four months for the Chief of the General Staff to respond to some legitimate concerns expressed by the family in that letter.Many people have suggested to me that the Department of Defence often employs a standard operating procedure in matters involving the death of personnel—to essentially string out the paperwork until the established three‐year statutory limit has expired. This claim was certainly evidenced by the Senate committee in their inquiry into the Nomad tragedy. They recommended a five‐year statutory period in their findings.General Sanderson outlined in his letter of 8 October a number of reasons for not disciplining the particular army personnel involved, Sergeant R.C. Thorpe. Quite frankly, so many of the reasons seem inadequate to me.A board of inquiry was originally convened following the death of Jacinta Watson. It recommended disciplinary action against Sergeant Thorpe at the time, but that particular recommendation was suspended because charges of a similar nature were laid by the Queensland police against Sergeant Thorpe. He was charged with unlawful killing and the unlawful wounding of another soldier, Corporal Michael James Gardiner.Defence, according to General Sanderson, were going to charge Thorpe in two possible ways—under section 36(2) of the Defence Force Discipline Act 1982, which is `dangerous behaviour causing death by recklessly handling a weapon; or under section 36(3), which is `dangerous behaviour, causing death by negligently handling a weapon. But those charges were never laid.On 4 June 1996, the Queensland Supreme Court found Sergeant Thorpe not guilty of the civil charges. General Sanderson claims section 144 of the Defence Force Discipline Act precludes:. . . trying a member with an offence which is substantially the same as a civil offence of which a person has been acquitted in a civil court.General Sanderson claims his judgment is that certainly would have been the case in the matter involving Jacinta Watsons death so he decided against pursuing any action against Sergeant Thorpe. General Sandersons letter said:My decision aside, I am also aware that Sgt Thorpe is carrying a huge burden which he must live with for the rest of his life.That is certainly true, but I do not think anybody in this place would deny that the family of Jacinta Watson—and, for that matter, all members of the ADF—will carry a tremendous burden out of this unfortunate accident which resulted in her death.Mr Speaker, I am well aware of your distinguished career within the Defence Force, but my contention is this: the reputation of the entire Australian defence forces can suffer from this sort of decision. It seems to me that the person who was in charge when someone was killed and another was hurt should be disciplined in some way—perhaps as a token gesture, but there should be some discipline. Disciplinary action would demonstrate to all service personnel and to the Australian community that the ADF enforces the high standards expected of it. Rank carries responsibility, and even ordinary members of the ADF often carry far greater responsibilities than the general Australian community. Accordingly, such responsibilities justify the exacting of strong and certain penalties if standards are not met.The parents of people who have been killed in the too many accidents involving ADF personnel in recent years are well motivated in their pursuit of answers to their questions. They are understandably proud of their childrens involvement in the ADF and they bear no grudge against the Commonwealth; rather, they just want their fears put to rest. General Sandersons slow response to Jacinta Watsons mother certainly did not help the cause.I submit that it is certainly time for the army in particular to take greater care and to move to analyse the common causes in these various incidents—for example, the training and the attitude of personnel involved—to apply these findings to prevent further incidents, as well as define and impose appropriate penalties. If the Defence Force Discipline Act is inadequate, let us amend it. (Time expired)
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr MOSSFIELD
content: —I rise in this adjournment debate to congratulate the Leader of the Opposition, Kim Beazley, on his statement last week that the coalition government should introduce a freeze on automotive tariffs at 15 per cent until the year 2005 with a further review in 2003. Mr Beazley urged the government to take a bipartisan approach so that car makers faced more certainty in their long-term investment decisions.I believe a tariff freeze clearly has widespread support from some coalition backbenchers—and I certainly think the member for Kingston (Ms Jeanes) would be included in that—and from the Premier of South Australia, John Olsen. Mr Olsen is quoted as saying that the Australian industry was hamstrung by the lack of economies of scale at home and the fact that the international trade playing field was not level.I refer to the car manufacturers themselves. Toyota Australia told the Productivity Commission:None of the four local car makers would survive if the Industry Commissions major recommendations were implemented.Our own Australian icon, Holden, told the Industry Commission in Adelaide:. . . its international parent would not have approved the project to build the Vectra mid‐sized car alongside the Holden Commodore for 1998 if the Commissions interim recommendation to cut tariffs on imports to 5% by 2004 had been known at the time.Mr Thomas of Holden said:. . . the move to cut tariffs to 5% could lift to 23,000 the number of jobs lost in the car industry over the period from 1992 to 2004, equal to about 50 per cent of the 46,000 people directly employed by the sector earlier this decade.N/AThe car and automotive component sector is vital to the Australian economy and no doubt tariff cuts would threaten fresh investment and jeopardise thousands of jobs throughout Australia. In New South Wales, where I know manufacturing industry is struggling, the car component industry employs thousands of workers.The helpful proposals by Kim Beazley need to be repeated over and over again, and I will do that with pleasure this evening: first, a freeze on tariffs on motor vehicles, original equipment and replacement components at 15 per cent to at least 2005—while maintaining our commitments under APEC; second, the establishment of transparent measures by which the progress of our trading partners in reducing their tariff and non-tariff barriers can be judged; third, a review of the industrys position in 2003 to determine the assistance needed beyond 2005; fourth, continuing the export facilitation scheme, modified as necessary to be consistent with our World Trade Organisation obligations; fifth, continuation of the duty-free allowance to support domestic market value-added products; and, sixth, provision of measures which ensure a more supportive industrial research and development environment.In close proximity to my electorate, a number of car component plants—such as BTR, TRW and Astra—currently provide hundreds of blue-collar jobs. As a former trade union official, I serviced manufacturing industry and the car component industry over a long period of time. I have been shocked to see the number of jobs lost in these industries due to economic rationalist policies. I might say that many of these policies were vigorously opposed by the trade union movement.But it is not only people from my side of politics who are alarmed by the Productivity Commissions draft report recommending that tariffs be lowered. Mr Allan Handberg, the national Chief Executive of the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, was quoted in the Financial Review as saying:The draft report offered no positive encouragement for global manufacturers to maintain their investment in Australia.He went on further to say:A withdrawal of capital by car makers would send a negative message that would have disastrous implications for all foreign investment in Australia.Mr Handberg also slated the report for its lack of plans for industry, saying that it did not indicate what shape it would be in after the recommendations took effect. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has said that the idea that Australia would lose a car manufacturing industry is quite unthinkable; yet if he does not support the approach taken by Kim Beazley, that is exactly what could happen. (Time expired)
Speaker: N/A

name: Dr NELSON
content: —In little over a week, the Federal Council of the Australian Medical Association will meet to consider a recommendation from one of its key committees that, if adopted, could ultimately destroy the egalitarian principles upon which private health insurance has been built. After almost a century of tireless support for health insurance, the AMAs Health Economics Committee is recommending to its governing body that Australians be advised against maintaining it. Not known for making irrational or ill-considered policies, the AMA would be well advised to well and truly think this one through.Higher income Australians probably could afford to go without private health insurance and simply pay cash at the hospital door. Paul Keating and the member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence) are two notable examples who admit to such practices. However, what about those 850,000 contributors over the age of 65, the half a million people earning less than $20,000 a year or the one million families surviving on annual incomes below $40,000? I do not know how long they would survive without access to some kind of insurance pool.Whilst it is easy to suggest that, as 40 per cent of private hospital episodes are now day procedures which cost approximately $2,000 to $2,500 each, who could responsibly suggest a battler go without effective cover for several years whilst they save the money? If the financially fit drop their health cover, they abandon those with mental illness, with intractable disease or with meagre resources to the collapse of a system that provides their only hope of affordable and timely access to quality care.I think people should be under no misapprehension that, if private health insurance collapses or if low income people cannot afford to buy it, private hospitals in the private hospital sector would continue to flourish—with the exception of those in regional and certain rural areas—but the market to which they will be appealing will be those who are of higher incomes and who can afford to pay cash. At the moment there is also a very untapped but lucrative market in South-East Asia for people who would be prepared to come here—and in fact are in increasing numbers—and pay cash for hospital care.The AMAs seemingly radical considerations reflect its opposition to proposals by the health insurers that have been put to the Productivity Commission for the establishment of what is described as US-style managed care programs. These programs have been described by Hillary Clinton as `an assault on the doctor-patient relationship. Insurers would control both the quantity and quality of care delivered through the ownership of hospitals and the contracting of doctors.I would advise the AMA Federal Council, when it considers this matter in just over a week, to wait for the Productivity Commissions report on changes to the regulatory environment in which health insurance operates and the governments response to it before abandoning its social obligations to the poor and the weak. Important as the governments private health insurance rebates may be, of more significance are the regulations that currently shackle the private health insurance industry.If the AMA adopts a position of advising people to drop their private health insurance and subsequent regulatory amendments are adopted by the government, do they then turn 180 degrees? Do we find that some of the most vulnerable people in this country—frequently elderly people, quite a number of whom have been ringing my electorate office recently about this issue—are then told by the AMA in a few months time: `We retract our earlier advice and now suggest that you take up private health insurance? What of the confusion amongst those with chronic illness?Would a person quit their private health insurance on the advice of the AMA—whose advice frequently is taken by the community—and then subsequently sought to take it up again, and if they then suffered a serious illness and found that they suffered misadventure on a public hospital waiting list, would the AMA and its officers be held liable for the sort of advice which they had given?Whilst I understand the basis of the recommendations that are coming from the AMAs Health Economics Committee and the frustration that underlines it, I think the Federal Council of the AMA as a group would be well advised to wait for the governments response to the Productivity Commission report—the regulatory environment is very much in need of reform—and consider the social obligations that it has to the vulnerable people in Australia.

content: —to move—That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the notice lodged by Mr Martin relating to disallowance of Statutory Rules 1996, No. 277, being called on forthwith.Mr Jull to move—That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Decontamination for disposal of the former Albion Exposives Factory site, Deer Park, Vic.Mr Jull to move—That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Development of operational facilities at RAAF Base Darwin.Mr Jull to move—That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, it is expedient to carry out the following proposed work which was referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works and on which the committee has duly reported to Parliament: Development of buildings and services in support of the Department of Defence Joint Project 2043, High Frequency Modernisation Project.Mr Reith to move—That, unless otherwise ordered, the following amendments to the standing orders be adopted for the remainder of this period of sittings with effect from 18 March 1997:(1) Standing orders 195, 197 and 199 be amended to read:Members calling for division195. Members calling for a division shall not leave the area within the seats allotted to Members, and shall vote with those who, in the opinion of the Speaker, were in the minority when the voices were taken.No Member to vote unless present when tellers appointed197. No Member shall be entitled to vote in any division unless, when the tellers are appointed, the Member is within the seats allotted to Members. Except that when a successive division is taken pursuant to standing order 203A, this standing order does not apply.Division bells rung199. Before a division is taken, the Clerk shall ring the division bells and the doors shall not be closed until after the lapse of four minutes.(2) Standing order 200A be suspended.(3) Standing orders 201, 202 and 203 be amended to read:Question stated; Members divided; Tellers appointed201. When the doors have been locked, and all the Members are in their places, the Speaker shall state the question to the House, shall direct the Ayes to proceed to the right of the Chair, and the Noes to the left, and Members having accordingly taken seats, shall appoint tellers for each side.Members present when tellers appointed must vote202. On the tellers being appointed, every Member within the seats allotted to Members shall vote and no Member may move from his or her place until the result of the division is announced. Except that when a successive division is taken pursuant to standing order 203A, this standing order does not apply.Members counted, names taken down203. Every Member within the seats allotted to Members shall then be counted, and his or her name taken down by the tellers. When recording is complete the tellers shall calculate the total number of Members voting on that side. Tellers shall sign their list, and present it to the Speaker, who will declare the result to the House.(4) New standing orders 203A and 203B be inserted:Successive divisions—bells rung, tellers appointed203A. When successive divisions are taken, and there is no intervening debate after the first division, the bells for the ensuing division shall be rung for one minute only. Notwithstanding the provisions of standing order 201, the Speaker shall appoint tellers immediately after the division is called.Successive divisions—vote same as in previous division203B. When a successive division is taken pursuant to standing order 203A the tellers shall record each Members vote as being the same as it was in the immediately preceding division.Provided that any Member who—(i) wishes to vote differently to the way he or she voted in the previous division; or(ii) voted in the previous division and does not wish to vote in the current division; or(iii) did not vote in the previous division and wishes to vote in the current division—shall report to the tellers as necessary to have his or her voting intention properly recorded. Members who wish to vote in the same way as they did in the immediately preceding division shall remain in their seats until the result of the division is announced.Provided further that, if it is apparent to the Speaker that most Members wish to vote differently to the previous division, or if there is any confusion or error in the numbers calculated by the tellers, the vote shall be counted as provided in standing order 203.(5) Standing order 204 be amended to read:If 4 or fewer Members on a side204. If, at the time that the doors are locked, there are 4 or fewer Members on a side in a division, the Speaker shall, without completing the division, forthwith declare the decision of the House. In such event, the names of the Members who are in the minority shall be recorded in the Votes and Proceedings.
