name: Mr TUCKEY
content: —This legislation could be categorised as an omnibus bill because it has 10 separate measures incorporated within its covers. Some of them are of a more routine nature, but there are those that, to my mind, require special attention. While I wish to spend most of my time on the capital gains tax arrangements, I would like to record my significant support for the changes within this law relating to equity investments in small and medium enterprises whereby changes to the tax law are allowing and simplifying a process where major lenders can take some equity in a business, as compared to lending them money.One of the great difficulties for small business has always been the fact that their only source of growth capital has been to borrow the money, making them subject to the vagaries of the interest rate market and, frequently, not allowing them to take that option. Too often, debt has been the downfall of a business when, without the capital, they simply could not grow their business which is essential in modern‐day economics.When there is an equity position, the equity holder has to take the good with the bad. Their component of the investment does not become a burden when things are tough. It becomes a form of burden when things are good, because dividends are paid to the equity holder. But, as I say of taxation, if you are paying taxation, you are making profits and the tax man does not yet want 100 per cent of your profits, so it is always a much more advantageous situation.I thank the government for taking initiatives to simplify that opportunity and I think it has to be grown. In fact, our whole capital market structure has to be further reformed. The idea of a second board for medium sized companies has to be better understood as a speculative market. Admittedly, we have to watch out for the crooks, but the re‐establishment of a second board, which is now back on the agenda, is required.For very small companies, a company structure is required that particularly allows family members to invest in a company without liability. In other words, they do not have to go in as a retired couple and risk their family home to help their kids start a small business, but if they have a bit of spare cash that they are prepared to apply in that direction they should be able to put it in. Whereas in that type of small business company, as compared to a partnership, there is still the opportunity in a legal sense to require that the principal shareholders or directors have a degree of liability, which overcomes a lot of the other problems associated with granting credit to small business corporations. The whole capital structure of the small business sector needs to be reviewed and special provisions made so that people can get capital, as compared to debt. I welcome the initiative that is included in this legislation.It is interesting that we again revisit capital gains tax. I have been around for a reasonable time and, going back in history, when we were in opposition our then leader, Andrew Peacock, campaigned with a simple slogan—that, as sure as night follows day, if the people of Australia were to re‐elect a Labor government we would get a capital gains tax.As a consequence that was denied vociferously by the government at the time and, of course, history records we got a capital gains tax. We also got it without very much regard for the effect that it would have on, particularly, small business. There is a very simplistic argument that capital gains should be as taxable as any other gain and, of course, you can progress, if you like, to a wealth tax which says that people who are extremely wealthy should have their wealth assessed on an annual basis and that taxed at a flat rate.All of it is very negative to the accumulation of wealth. There are two points of view in Australian society. One is that everybody should be poor and the other that if some people are wealthy they assist the poor. I subscribe to the second view. I am not at all embarrassed to see someone drive down the road in a brand new Rolls Royce because I know a lot of people have got a job out of building it, maybe in a foreign country. There are also, of course, a lot of people getting a job out of the taxes that were paid to buy that vehicle and maintain and keep it on the road. Any suggestion that that sort of consumption only benefits the purchaser is silly. If someone can afford a butler then a butler gets a job as far as I am concerned. I am not at all concerned with the fact that by their efforts someone has achieved that level of income and they can afford to pay other people to assist them around their house. In fact, I hold the view, personally, which may not be even supported by my colleagues, that such household expenditure can be tax deductible. I see no reason why, where there is a family with two members, husband and wife, with skills in demand who should be both out there growing our economy, they have then got to come home at 5 oclock and do the household duties while someone else remains unemployed who would be ideally suited to doing those household duties and sharing in the income of those two people who have skills in demand.The incentive to do that would arise from saying to those people: part of your effort in both going out each day to earn a living and contribute to our economy requires that you employ someone in your household. I can see no reason whatsoever why that cannot be seen as a business expense. Furthermore, it would create a lot of employment that currently does not exist. It is all a bit silly. That is a personal view. I am not speaking on behalf of my government colleagues when I make it. I think we miss an opportunity because we have somehow still got this fixation with upstairs downstairs which is also, in my view, silly. I think all forms of employment are honourable employment. If peoples skills limit them to household duties, why not? Not everybody is going to have the skills to be a computer programmer or somebody in that category. Computer programmers marry computer programmers, doctors marry doctors et cetera, and we are suggesting to them that the society should still demand that one of them gives up work to look after the house when in fact there is a demand in society for them. But I will not continue on that particular subject. It has strayed a little bit away from this legislation.The reality of capital gains tax as I saw it in business was as follows: somebody goes out and expends say $50,000 to buy a small business. It is run down and they work extremely hard and extremely long hours and they build it up to a point where it has reached its capacity. It is not going to grow any more. They have ambition to go on to bigger and better things and they offer it for sale for $100,000 with the intention of buying another business for $150,000 and starting the cycle all over again. That is good for the economy. It is good for them and it is governments responsibility to encourage them. But what is the outcome under the present and past capital gains tax regime? They have made a $50,000 capital gain. They are going to sell a business for $100,000. They have probably sold it through a real estate agent so they have to pay commission on the sale. Then, of course, when they go to buy the new business for $150,000, the state authorities put out their hand for stamp duty. To add to their concerns we add a capital gains tax.In simple arithmetic those three costs consume the whole $50,000 of profit that they have built into the enterprise by hard work. It is silly and of course there is an absolute disincentive to sell the first business because in fact you are back to square one. That is what has been happening and the losers have been the real estate agents who could not turn businesses over and all sorts of other people and, of course, the state authorities with their rather iniquitous stamp duties which have got to the point of the ridiculous. They, again, are very much like a capital gains tax. I would like to address that issue in a moment.Suddenly we find that the idea that you are taxing people on this sort of hidden profit of capital gain has been very negative to the revenue. People have not been using it. Furthermore, it has discouraged people from going on and doing what is best for society. That is trying to expand their business activities and have this incentive to grow. This legislation specifically addresses that problem. It could not be more simple. It simply says that if you are in that situation and you wish to reinvest in another business, then you have the right to do so without paying capital gains tax. You are given two years to make that decision, which I think is very generous. To the great credit of the government, notwithstanding their policy position pre the election, they have wiped out the like‐business component.I campaigned very strongly against that by correspondence with our Treasurer and the committee that was looking at it. There are thousands of reasons that people would want to shift from, say, a newsagency to another business. More particularly, in my electorate, we find farmers wishing to move out of the farming industry sometimes because of physical injury—their back has given out or things of that nature—and they are seeking to invest in another business, say, a newsagency or a caravan park or something like that. And why not? The reality is that they might have inherited the family farm and found that they were not even suited to the farming business for whatever reason and that they would be more skilled in another. They should be able to move into different types of business within, of course, the $5 million turnover limit that is applicable.I congratulate the government on taking this step. They could stand to lose revenue in the process but I think, in the end, that may not be the case. I think there will be additional turnover in businesses resulting from this arrangement and I think the real estate industry is in for a bit of a bonanza. There are a lot of people just waiting for 1 July to be able to participate in this new arrangement and change from one business to another. We will see some quite significant activity which will benefit other governments such as state governments in their stamp duties. Taxes will be earned from the profits of real estate agents and others who will be the beneficiaries of this arrangement. It is, therefore, a very good proposition.Nevertheless, it is also worth addressing at this time the overall tax situation as it applies to business. I have been in business for all my life. I commenced in my first business while I was still at school. I went out painting houses on weekends and my school holidays and actually used to employ my school mates on certain of the less skilled jobs that were associated. I could give them as much in a day as the then department stores paid them for a week, over the Christmas period.But the reality is that a business, strangely enough, never enjoys profit. A business, for all intents and purposes, is a piece of paper that constructs that business. Those who enjoy the profits of a business are either the partners or the shareholders and I have never been able to work out why we therefore tax business. We have a hatred for them. We read in the papers constantly that nasty old BHP—that employs millions of Australians—made a big profit and we should be cutting them down to size. In fact, we should be leaving them with the profit so they can invest and create more jobs and more economic activity and maybe pick up the 800,000 or 900,000 unemployed we have in this country.Of course we should tax them the minute they pay money out to their shareholders or transfer it to another entity or want to transfer it out of the country. But that is the point. And, of course, that is the great opportunity that Treasurer Keating missed when he went for imputation. There is some reference to imputation in this particular legislation. Treasurer Keating had the choice with imputation. He could have taxed the company, as he did, and passed the franking credits on to the shareholder or he need not have taxed the company and he could have taxed the dividends. And, of course, he could have quite properly taxed them by way of withholding tax.The difference would have been that anybody who was prepared to reinvest in their business would not have paid tax on that investment and there would have been a massive incentive to do just that. It could have international implications—people in other countries making judgments that they had this opportunity to operate in this environment in Australia and bring their investments here, be it in petrochemical plants or any of the other secondary processing facilities, in particular, that Australia is wide open to considering its natural resources base.I welcome reading in todays paper how in Western Australia proper investors, quite properly, are going to bring our solar salt production and our huge gas production together by way of a petrochemical plant. We export them both to somebody else to do that particular job and that sounds silly to me. But, again, any incentive that says to business, `If you reinvest you do not pay tax seems to me to have a lot of merit. What is more, I do not believe government revenues would lose eventually because there would be a growth in PAYE earnings, a reduction in dole payments and the benefits from all the other things that follow from economic development. It is an issue that I would like to see considered.As you would be aware, I have advocated for quite some time that it is time the parliament of Australia—people from its own ranks—for the first time in history sat down with a select committee and studied our national tax system, right down to local government—not as a government but as a parliament. My proposition would be that the opposition got half the say because the reality of taxation is that unless the people of Australia, through its parliament, are prepared to take a bipartisan view and not play silly politics with taxation—put the national interest ahead of our political interest—then we are not going to get reform. We are going to go on, for instance, arguing about what level of tariff we should have on motor cars when in fact we put $800 worth of lead in the saddlebag of every car manufacturer for every car they produce through our indirect tax system—the height of the ridiculous.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr McArthur
content: —Hear, hear!
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr TUCKEY
content: —Treasury figures show us that 800 bucks is included in the manufactured cost of every car made in Australia because we have a fuel tax that they cannot recover and because we have payroll tax—a tax on employing people! I have always been rather stunned at the logic behind that particular argument. We have all these other taxes flowing into the system which they cannot escape. They add four per cent to the cost of growing a wheat crop, which we export. We see the great benefits to our balance of payments that this years wheat crop is providing. It is just silly, and yet apparently we have not got the capacity as a parliament—as a government and an opposition—to sit down and have a look at the proposition of whether income tax should apply to business or shareholders.I have expressed a view. I will express another view: in the international environment a VAT type tax is essential. Furthermore, it should be levied by the federal government but in two groups: firstly, for federal revenue at, say, 10 per cent and, secondly, for state revenues at, say, five per cent. At that point in time we say, `Thats where you get your revenue; the Commonwealth provides you nothing. Of course, that means that state governments lose this wonderful opportunity they have to blame the Commonwealth every time they put up their taxes but become answerable to their own constituency for the services they provide with that money. They are the realities. It goes right down—if you give state governments a reasonable revenue base then maybe they would abandon land taxes and stamp duties on such transactions and allow local government to raise their rate revenue at no real cost to the community and they would become independent.These are the issues that we should be confronting, but we are too busy worrying who is going to win the next election. Of course, we used to say of the Australian Democrats, `You cant buy the Democrats; you can only rent them by the hour. That is now a perfect description of the Labor opposition. You only have got to watch them. We knew what they used to stand for. Today, it is an hourly change; you are renting them by the hour.That stands in contrast to our term in opposition when on issues of privatisation and others we stood by our principles; we supported the government when they had problems in their own caucus. But the realities are that we need that in the national interest. Let us have a look. I am not predicting or demanding what the outcomes might be, but I think it is outrageous that a parliament for the nation cannot look for the first time ever at its own tax system.

name: Mr BOB BALDWIN
content: —It is a great pleasure to rise to speak about the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill No. 4 (1996). At the outset, I must commend my colleague, the very energetic member for OConnor (Mr Tuckey). Today he has given a great presentation of his thoughts on the capital gains tax which are exactly consistent with the thoughts he expressed prior to this hideous tax being introduced back in 1985. For many months he repeatedly asked questions of the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, and the then Treasurer, Mr Keating, about the tax. He was told many times during that period that there would be no capital gains tax. I am sure that as he leaves the chamber now he would agree with those sentiments.The main amendments in this bill deal with the change of entities involving capital gains tax rollover relief from capital gains tax for small business—a change to accelerate the depreciation rate cut‐off date for Australian trading ships, insertion of generic definitions of Commonwealth education and training programs, franking account concessions for companies which have not converted them for the purpose of imputation and beneficial changes to concessional tax treatment relating to employee share acquisition schemes.Capital gains tax is payable on the difference between the sale price and the index cost base of assets acquired after 19 September 1985 when the asset is disposed of. Assets changing ownership, even if acquired before that date, will attract capital gains tax as well.As you would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, it can be said that this was very much a core promise of the coalition in the election campaign of 1996. It has been argued however that there could be some administrative problems with companies listed on the Australian Stock Exchange and having to compare and trace stockholders interests. However, such argument would apply only if a literal interpretation of the Income Tax Assessment Act is applied rather than the view adopted in the various rulings made by the commissioner.A series of changes to subdivisions in division 20 of part IIIA of the Income Tax Assessment Act define the requirements of entities to calculate whether there has been a change in the underlying interests in the entity and if the continuity of ownership has been affected. On the basis of this information, capital gains tax will apply.This measure is consistent with the governments objective of reducing compliance costs and increasing the efficiency of capital gains tax systems. Rollover relief from capital gains tax applies in a number of circumstances, such as involuntary disposal, transfers to wholly owned companies, changes to superannuation trust deeds and the merger of superannuation funds.Prior to the 1996 general election, the coalition announced that, as part of the capital gains tax reform, rollover relief would be available where a business disposes of an asset to purchase a like kind of asset. This relief would be subject to certain conditions, including that the disposal and purchase occur within 12 months and that the disposal price does not exceed $5 million and that the relief would be available only once every five years.Since the 1996 budget, the scheme has been substantially the same but with the following amendments: rollover relief will be restricted to taxpayers whose net assets do not exceed $5 million; relief will be available only in respect of active assets and the acquired asset is used in the same business or a like business.Further amendments were announced by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) in a release dated 3 September 1996. These are that the like business test will be removed and that the period between disposal and acquisition will be extended to two years.That is a sign of a very progressive government, a government that has gone out and listened to the needs of business, in particular small business. To sell a business and buy a like business might be all right for a very large corporation, but imagine the average Mum and Dad or, indeed, just the single sole trader who has gone out and started a small business and built it up and then found that that is not quite his niche market, but that there is another niche market. I heard my friend and colleague the member for OConnor (Mr Tuckey) say, an example is a farmer which I have and which, indeed, many colleagues in regional and rural Australia have. Farmers may be forced to sell off the farm and, perhaps, move to town and rather than sitting back and going into a very early retirement they look to set up a small business.If you applied the objective of the intention of the amendment prior to those changes announced on 3 December, there would be capital gains tax applied to that sale of the farm business because it was not transferring to a like business. But the Treasury and cabinet, in their infinite wisdom, have determined that sometimes it is a matter of a situation out of their control where one has to sell one business and go into a totally different type of business. But the main thing is continuity. By allowing a period of up to two years, it does not mean that one has to risk all of the assets that one has built in that business, by rushing into a business that, perhaps, may not be secure or sound or, indeed, where time has not been available to do the necessary market research to ensure its long‐term viability.A new division will also be inserted into part 111A of the Income Tax Assessment Act, providing a definition of an asset currently used for capital gains tax purposes. These include any form of incorporeal property, such as goodwill. The usual capital gains tax definition will include motor vehicles used in the production of income, and will exclude personal use assets, rights under superannuation, or improved deposit funds and life insurance policies. Further assets will be excluded, which will result in total savings to small business.When the bill was originally suggested, the savings to small business were $150 million in 1998‐89, and $160 million in 1999 to 2000. However, with the announcement by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) on 3 December 1996, this has expanded to $200 million in 1998‐99 and $215 million in 1999‐2000. While some would say that the government is giving away money again to small business, it is actually an investment in small business. It is small business that employs the majority of the people. It is small business that takes the risk. So, to provide a small investment in that amount, spread across the 800,000 small businesses that are out there, is a very small outlay for a maximum benefit of return.We have long heard it said that if all of these small businesses increased their workforce by one, our unemployment figures would disappear. But the members on the opposite side of the House have absolutely no understanding of small business. We have only to look amongst their dwindling ranks over there and see how many of them actually come from small businesses—

content: —Thirty years in small business. You must be a rare exception. I look through the listing at the number of ACTU officials and presidents and those that have been employees. I am talking about people who have put their own money and assets into small business and who have begged and borrowed from Mum, Dad, or whoever, to be able to finance a business. I have respect for you, then, if you have been in small business and have been able to make it go, and have had to suffer like so many other Australians then, you, as a member of the former government—

Speaker: N/A

name: Mr BOB BALDWIN
content: —I apologise, Mr Speaker. As the honourable member over there would know, he was a member of the former government that inflicted the greatest pain on small business. They reigned over the period of absolute record high numbers of bankruptcies and drove interest rates up to a level that would never have been dreamt possible. The only ones who benefited—and God bless their souls—were the pensioners who had a few dollars tucked away. But small business suffered. Small business could not afford to borrow or invest. Then, when people had to sell off that business to reduce the overdraft because the banks were putting the pressure on them, the former government, in their wisdom and absolute support for small business, decided that they had better nail them a little bit more and take some capital gains tax out of them. Even though they might have wanted to go on and start another business, or reinvest into something like their superannuation, the former government said no. They wanted it all.They got it all on 2 March when Australia voted them out of power. It was not just a trickle, it was not a small run; it was a massive flood. The initiative of this government has been well received, and I will quote quite a few eminent people in the small business industry who do understand what small business is about, unlike the members of the former government and now the current opposition. In the Financial Review of 4 December 1996, Mr Robert Bastian, Chief Executive of the Council of Small Business Organisations, described our initiative—this bill—as:. . . absolutely fabulous, an excellent gesture to small business.He also said:It gives a psychological lift which far exceeds the $50 million input by the government.He was a bit incorrect with his $50 million; it is a bit more than that. That psychological lift is what it is all about. If we talk up the economy, show that we are serious about getting things going in this country, and show some leadership—which our government does, but which was never there under the former government—that psychological lift will be there for small business and it will get them going.At the moment, the shadow Treasurer, the Leader of the Opposition, and others, continually talk down the future prospects for small business. And this is at a time when the government has been able to deliver interest rates, and now interest on overdrafts, at the lowest levels not seen since the 1970s. I ask: who can be serious about talking down the economy for small business? In that same article, Mr John Martin, the Executive Director of the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, said:It is an important step in increasing the confidence of small business and freeing up investment.Mr Kurt Rendall, the small business spokesperson for the Institute of Chartered Accountants said:The decision highlighted the difference between the coalition government and its predecessor.He went on to say that these guys had a really good understanding of small business. Mr Deputy Speaker, do you know why that is? It is because a lot of the people in government today understand small business because they have come from small business. They have invested in themselves. They have invested in their employees and they have continued on. That is something that cannot be said for anywhere near a majority of the people in the current opposition.In a press release issued late last year—I think it was in August—Mr Jonathan Ilbery, National President of the Taxation Institute of Australia, in reference to capital gains tax relief, said:This will obviously assist small business which would otherwise have incurred a tax liability on the disposal of the original asset. It will go some way to reducing the already heavy tax cost for small business.N/ATo have something grow and develop, we need to provide an incentive. If we provide an incentive, people will pick up the reins and run with them. As they run, so it will grow and become a river rather than a rivulet, and it will lead to an ocean. What will eventually happen is that we will be flooded with jobs and we will bring this nation back to a healthy, employed nation. But we cannot do it whilst we have an opposition that is hell‐bent and determined to keep up the structure of destroying small business.Perhaps they wanted to get rid of small businesses under their previous regime of government. By having small business out of the way, and having more large employers that the ACTU could go and apply pressure to, they could build up the dwindling number of union members. Even union members walked away from you because they felt you could not deliver the one thing that they needed, security in jobs. We do not get security in jobs if we do not have businesses employing people.We are going a long way towards that but let us look back a little in history at the yells and screams, particularly of the former Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, who was asked repeatedly about a capital gains tax. As I said, one of the people who asked questions about this on a regular basis is my friend and colleague the member for OConnor. On 16 February 1983, the former Prime Minister, Bob Hawke, said:And here let me make one point so that even our opponents can understand it; and let me make it beyond all their powers of misrepresentation and distortion.Wait for it.There will be no new capital gains tax.N/ADo you remember those words, etched in history? No new capital gains tax. You did not seem to understand that what it was was a disincentive for people to invest in Australia to start to create jobs.What happened way back in February 1985? Remember Placido Domingo? You must; you worked with him. In May 1985, the then Treasurer Paul Keating said, `The government has decided to introduce a capital gains tax. Where is their credibility? The situation is that during that period the now Prime Minister (Mr Howard) said that the coalition government, on coming to power—and he was referring to the next election thereafter—would remove a capital gains tax.It would be ideal to remove a capital gains tax right now but, unfortunately, the former government—the current opposition—have driven a need for dependency on tax revenue in this country by having such high levels of unemployment, such high levels of welfare and such high levels of debt that we cannot afford to get rid of capital gains tax in its entirety. What we can do is we can start to create an incentive that again will get small business going.As I said, how many of them are from small business? Very few. Let me remind this House that I do come from small business. I know what it is like to go out to my mum and dad and say, `Mum and Dad, I want to put your house on the line; I want to start a small business. That is something that a lot of my colleagues would also be able to understand. Having put their house on the line and taken out the overdraft, I went out and started a small business. Let me tell you it was in wholesaling. I bought an old ute and, because I could not afford to live the flash life of union officials, I slept in the ute at night so that I could save on the accommodation as I travelled around the coast of Australia selling diving equipment. But I had my money and my parents money on the line invested in that business. And it went on.Do you know what it is like, members of the opposition, when people do not pay their accounts in 7 days or 30 days and they have strung you out for 60 days, 90 days and 120 days? You have to put on a brave face when you are asking for your money. Do you know what it is like to have to live on Vegemite sandwiches because you cannot afford three proper feeds a day because your money is at risk? Let me tell you that a lot of people in small business in Australia understand that. They understand what it is like to have their money at risk. They understand what it is like to have `No said to them. They understand what it is like to have to deprive their kids because other small business operators are finding it tough. But you do not. You do not and you never have. That is why small business has totally rejected you as a government as, indeed, most of your former union membership rejected you on 2 March.But why do people go into in small business? They do it because there is nothing of greater pride than to work for yourself and to occasionally see the bank balance go into the black. As it goes into the black and you build up that account, you start to acquire a few assets for that business. A lot of people build that business for one reason only. They build that business as their superannuation retirement fund. They work hard all their lives, building that business up. They cannot afford, in the early stages of business, to pay out superannuation for themselves so that they can invest in their long term, so they do it through their business.Under the former government—a government that had no idea or understanding—what they wanted to do was just rip the majority of that away in capital gains tax. What we have said to the people now is, `You can take half a million dollars of that money—and there are not many small businesses that build up an asset worth half a million dollars in a business to be able to sell off—`and you can put it into an approved rollover relief fund. If that is not incentive for people to keep going, then I do not know what is.As I said, most of the people on the opposition benches would not understand that. Why? Because they have never had a small business. They have always had their superannuation packages because the union has provided for them on the way through, it has always been there. They have had a level of security because they have worked, in the majority, for large companies and they have had their superannuation deducted and put away. They have had total reliance and support on that business to provide for them in the future. I only ask and wish that more of them could have experienced what it was like to be in small business; to have to be called in to the bank manager and to have to explain why your account is in overdraft; to have to explain to the people that you owe money to, `Well, I cant afford to pay you this week but maybe next week.Time is running away, but this is one subject in particular that I do know and understand. It was one of the reasons why in July last year we had in my electorate a Small Business Summit attended by over 230 local business people. They were clear on one thing: they wanted action. And this government is delivering action. One of the things it is delivering, by the introduction of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1996, is a core promise to ease capital gains tax. It is an investment in small business and, more particularly, in the long term it is an investment in the job futures of all Australians.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr VAILE
content: —I certainly support the question before the Main Committee that the words proposed to be omitted do stand part of the question, because the amendment being moved by the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) really is a pious amendment. How could anybody move against the measure that is being introduced by the government? There are a number of measures in the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) but, obviously, the one creating the greatest amount of interest is with regard to the capital gains tax rollover relief that we are providing to small business—which is the manifestation of a government commitment at the election last year to provide that relief. It has since been embellished further by the Prime Minister and the government, and extended to rolling over profits not just into like businesses but also into any other business.Like the member for Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin) and previous speakers from the government side participating in this debate, we certainly welcome what the government is doing in this regard. It is something that the small business sector and a lot of people generally have been very concerned about since 1986, when a line was drawn in the sand by the previous government such that if you purchased property before that time you were not going to be liable for capital gains tax but that, after that time, you were liable. I remember that, at the time, I had a couple of real estate businesses, and there was from the small business sector a mad scramble to get properties exchanged prior to that September 1986 date.It has taken all these years for some element of equity to be reintroduced into the system, particularly with regard to small businesses. My understanding would have been at the time that the concept was about trying to tax speculative gains; and that, in itself, I suppose, is not something that we would argue against. But, like the FBT introduced by the former government, the net of this particular measure has gone a lot wider and it has been a disincentive to investment and development, and has slowed down growth in some sections of the economy. Certainly, along with a lot of other things, it has been a monkey on the back of small business over a number of years.I certainly welcome this measure and the other measures contained in the bill that we are debating today. As I say, the capital gains tax rollover relief for small business is a measure which was a pre‐election commitment, and it has been warmly welcomed by small business right across the board in Australia. It will take effect from 1 July 1997, and the people that I know in small business have certainly welcomed the announcement and look forward to the legislation being effective from that date.The coalition announced that, as part of the capital gains tax reform, rollover relief would be available where a trading business disposes of an asset to purchase a like asset, or where a business is disposed of to purchase another business of like kind. A number of conditions applied to this rollover relief, including that the disposal and purchase occur within 12 months; that the disposal price not exceed $5 million; and that the relief only be available once every five years.In the 1996‐97 budget, the decision to implement the measure was announced in the coalitions first budget. It was subsequently the same, except for relief being restricted to taxpayers whose net business assets did not exceed $5 million, relief only being available to respective active assets, and the like kind asset test not applying. That was the big move that was made at the end of last year from the original election commitment.In the election, we committed to Australian people that we would provide rollover relief on capital gains tax moving from selling a business to re‐investing in a like business within 12 months, with a limit of $5 million and availability only every five years. In the budget at the end of last year, we extended that and removed the test of like kind so that, if you wanted to sell one business and buy another business that was unrelated, provided that it was reinvesting in the small business sector as we know it, the relief would also apply.It was interesting to note the Treasurers statement on 3 December 1996. Following consultation with small business, the Treasurer (Mr Costello) announced further changes to the rollover relief provisions, including the removal of the like kind business test and the extension from 12 months to two years of the period between disposal and acquisition. As I say, that embellished what was a good policy at the last election and provided a better application of the policy, extending it more widely to encompass a broader decision making process as far as small business is concerned. On 3 December, the Treasurer said:This will be another boost to small business, another delivery on the coalition mandate, another encouragement to small business to grow bigger, and new opportunities for jobs in new, growing Australian businesses. This government takes its commitment to small business seriously and this is a government which intends to deliver.And certainly we have delivered in a number of areas, as far as small business is concerned. On 4 February this year, during question time, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) said:From 1 July this year it will be possible for any man or woman in Australia running a small business who sells that business with proceeds of less than $5 million to invest those proceeds in another business, not necessarily a business of a like nature, without there being any capital gains tax liability. I remind the parliament of what was said by the Business Review Weekly . Managing editor Robert Gottliebsen said that this particular announcement was the most important corporate tax reform for 30 years because what it will do from 1 July this year is transform the landscape for the operation of small business in Australia.It is all about getting the monkey of government off the back of small business, along with what we have done as far as the election commitment goes to instigate a small business deregulation task force, now known as the Bell committee, which reported back to government at the end of last year. We maintained our commitment to the small business sector by trying to alleviate some of the burdens and regulations that government imposes on them and that cost them so much in time, energy and resources taken away from running their businesses and making a profit.With the announcement of the capital gains tax rollover relief measure and the changes announced in December by the Treasurer, the response has been overwhelming from small business. I quote Robert Bastian, the CEO of the Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia, who, in the Courier‐Mail of 5 December, described the changes that we announced thus:. . . exactly what small business was asking for. . . the psychological lift this will give to small business owners is far more important than the $50 million the Government estimates it will cost.I repeat: the psychological lift to small business owners will be far more important than the $50 million the government estimates it will cost. He probably best summed up the feelings of the small business community when he said, `It is bloody fabulous, an excellent gesture for small business. And that is what it was: a gesture with substance to small business that we were doing something positive for them.Government was at last, after so many years, doing something positive for small business—and it was done within 12 months of a coalition government being elected. The chairman of the Small Business Coalition, Mr Tom Meucke, in a media release on 3 December 1996 said:By this action the Government is indicating that it is both listening to small business and being prepared to modify its policy when this will result in significant practical benefits.It is further encouragement to confidence and expansion of the small business sector following the positive signals from the recommendations of the Small Business Deregulation Taskforce.N/AIt certainly is. I have a series of quotes, which I will not go on with at this stage, from different people involved in organisations representing the small business sector, all congratulating the government on this measure and highlighting its importance and positive nature.I was in this chamber late last night when this debate had resumed and it was interesting to listen to some of the representatives from the opposition parties, particularly the Labor Party, criticising this measure and the government. A number of speakers had a problem confining their comments to the bill. But it was interesting that the coalition government was being criticised by the Labor Party for not paying enough attention to small business. Some of the comments by members of the Labor Party were beyond belief.Since we have been in office, which is just on 12 months, one of the things we have achieved that we were committed to achieving for small business are low interest rates. There is nothing more important that a government can do than to try and encourage and create the environment for sustainable low interest rates for the small business sector. Just remember what happened during the 1980s and early 1990s in this country. The most devastating thing that happened to small business in the entire history of this nation was the high interest rate regime which was overseen by the former Prime Minister who was then Treasurer. He sent tens of thousands of small business people out of business. Whether they were small business people in towns, cities and urban areas, or small business people on the land, the monetary policy run by the former Prime Minister sent tens of thousands of them to the wall. That was the most damaging thing ever done to small business in Australias history.If you want to look at where the unemployment we are still struggling to deal with today started from, a major contributing factor was the high interest rate regime overseen by the previous government. It was under the previous government that unemployment rose to the unacceptably high level of about 11 per cent. A lot of those people came out of the small business sector that the former Labor government sent bankrupt purely through the interest rate regime and the monetary policy they were running.The most telling article on this is one I keep in my office all the time to keep repeating in this parliament and reminding members of the opposition of what their former leader, who has evidently now been junked as the great icon by the Labor Party, did to the nation Australia when he was Treasurer. The article is by Max Walsh in the Sydney Morning Herald and is called `A pocketful of wry from the Reserve. It is about former Treasurer Paul Keatings boast that he had the Reserve Bank in his back pocket.The article has some interesting comments that are drawn from John Edwards biography of Keating, Keating—The Inside Story . I will quote from the article which is very important to this debate because those were the darkest days of small business in Australia. I know, because I was operating a small business at the time interest rates went through the roof. I am not sure whether the member for Fowler (Mr Ted Grace) had his small business at that time or not, but they were devastating days for small business.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr Ted Grace
content: —Ill tell you how it went during the Menzies years!
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr VAILE
content: —You did not have interest rates that high during the Menzies days. The article by Max Walsh says:The Treasurers direct involvement in day‐to‐day monetary policy was an accident of history and personalities. With the floating of the exchange rate and the removal of exchange controls, monetary policy assumed a much greater role in economic management than it had previously.N/AThe Reserve Bank, accustomed to taking its riding instructions from the Treasury, approached its new responsibilities with apprehension and caution—two words not in the Keating vocabulary, especially when backed by his equally hubristic adviser, Don Russell.If its policy approach was sometimes confusing, its hardly surprising.Edwards quotes Keating as saying: This is all bull. . . . about the science of monetary policy. All bull. . . .. Every month for years we had papers on credit growth, the yield curve, etc etc, the relation to GNE, and it was never any good in prediction. Never. You have to be able to feel what is happening.Two paragraphs later, Edwards writes: Beginning in March 1988, Keating would encourage and authorise—sometimes in the face of objections, insist upon—a series of interest rate increases which were the cause of the subsequent recession.Keating had returned from his summer holiday all fired up about the way in which Noosa was full of bulldozers. He wanted the Reserve to lift rates by 2 percentage points in one hit.The Reserve procrastinated but, under daily urging from Don Russell, lifted the rate by 1.75 percentage points.Between March 1988 and November 1989 the cash rate was lifted by nearly 8 percentage points, with Paul Keating cracking the whip. Rates were pushed too high for too long.Then, at the end of 1989, Don Russell (as he told a seminar a few years later) heard the economy snap: not a slowdown or a steady decline, but an audible snap.N/AWhat that snap represented, Mr Deputy Speaker, was tens of thousands of small business people going bankrupt and going out of business because they could not afford the interest rates. They could not afford the interest rates that the former government and the former Prime Minister and Treasurer oversaw in this country in the late 1980s.So, Mr Deputy Speaker, we are not going to be lectured by the Labor Party in this debate. We are not going to be lectured by the Labor Party about what we are doing for small business and what they did or did not do for small business. This government, in 12 months, has overseen a regime in this economy which has seen interest rates fall; which has seen inflation come down; which has seen a strong growing economy; which has seen reform of the industrial relations system, including the removal of Labors job destroying unfair dismissal laws; and which has seen, in this bill today, a range of incentives for small business, including the capital gains tax rollover relief incorporated in this legislation. It has seen the report from the small business task force of the Prime Minister on deregulation. They are the things that this government has done in 12 months for the small business sector of Australia and that is the commitment of this government to seeing that we create a stable economic environment for small business to prosper in this country.We have done that in a 12 month period, whereas we know history has already recorded what the Labor Party did over 13 years to small business in this country. I can guarantee that what the Labor Party did over 13 years in government to small business is one of the key motivating features why a lot of the members of the coalition parties are in this place today—because they are motivated by what happened to small business over those 13 years, and particularly in those dark, black years when Paul Keating was the Treasurer of this country, driving interest rates to the level that he did and then coming out with the glib comment that `it was the recession that we had to have. It was the recession that Paul Keating wanted. It was the recession that Paul Keating wanted because he wanted to bust the developers that he saw investing money in Australias future in Noosa when he was on holidays up there. That is evidenced in that article that Max Walsh wrote and it is evidenced in that biography that is written by John Edwards about the former Prime Minister and Treasurer.So, Mr Deputy Speaker, we are not going to be lectured by the Labor Party with regard to what we are doing for small business in this country. We made a commitment at the election last year. This is the manifestation of part of that commitment and we are going to continue on that path so that we can create a stable economic environment in the Australian economy for small business to prosper, because they will provide the future growth of Australia and they will provide a lot of jobs in the future. I commend the legislation to the parliament. If we divide on this and if the Labor Party want to divide on their amendment, let the people of Australia know, and let the small business people of Australia know, that the Labor Party did not want to provide them with the capital gains tax rollover relief that the government does.
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr MILES
role: Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister)
content: —I would like to sum up this debate, and I think that summing up is probably encapsulated by certainly the last two speakers: the member for Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin) and the member for Lyons (Mr Vaile). Also, I would make the observation that, in regard to a debate centrally focused around the engine room of employment in this country—small business—we find that of the 14 speakers, 10 were from the government and only three from the opposition. So I think the enthusiasm with which the last two speakers have spoken in regard to this motion and debate, on behalf of the government, indicates their empathy and understanding of the actual small business sector.The very fact that there are only three people who came in here from the Labor Party to talk about small business and how important it is to employment really illustrates how out of touch the opposition has become in this place. We know that from the way in which the Australian people voted just over a year ago. This is a great opportunity to come in here and talk about the $200 million benefit to small business by taking away the capital gains tax. It really is a mark of this government that we are interested in small business people and small business operators. This is a fulfilment of a government promise prior to the last election that we would address some of the real difficulties that small businesses were placed under by the previous government. This is a quantum leap forward by the government to assist families, to create jobs and to assist businesses throughout this great country of ours. I think for the opposition to ignore this debate in the way in which they have illustrates their lack of interest in small business in this country.The opposition has foreshadowed a second reading amendment and the government will be opposing that amendment. That amendment deals with three particular issues. Firstly, the second reading amendment provides that the House calls on the government to ensure capital gains rollover relief is restricted to situations where a net increase in employment will occur. If the opposition spokesman on this really understood small business, this section of the amendments would not have been put. It is really about short-term populous politics as against principled positions by a government. That is what it is about—nothing more, nothing less. In framing the policy, the government, unlike the opposition, listened to small business. We actually went out there, listened to them and understood them. Small business said that the capital gains tax was an impediment to expansion and growth. Does that not imply that they were saying that the way to get employment in their sector was to take away the capital gains tax? I am not sure what the opposition really is on about in moving that sort of amendment. We believe that small business is the engine room of the economy and that the rollover relief will encourage further expansion and employment growth in this sector. It is pretty obvious to anybody who thinks about it. We listened to small business in this area and this is one of the major planks of what they were saying to us. Clearly the opposition and certainly their opposition spokesman did not listen at all.Secondly, the purpose of restricting rollover relief to active assets is so that the relief is only available in respect of assets directly linked to generating employment. That is why that is there. Again, I do not think that the opposition have actually read what is in the bill.It calls on the government to closely monitor the integrity of the tax system in the light of the capital gains tax changes. They are nice sounding words in this amendment but I really find this criticism very interesting indeed. The opposition is all over the place on this measure; there is no doubt about that. On the one hand, it is frustrated that it was not able to come up with such an idea as we have and is showing its annoyance. On the other hand, it criticises us saying that company shares are not eligible for the rollover relief. It then states it is concerned about the integrity of the taxation system. How can you run both arguments on the floor of a parliament; they are totally contradictory.Thirdly, this amendment put by the opposition says:Reverse the reduction in the minimum proportion of the work force which must be invited to participate in an ESOP.As the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) would know, the provisions in the bill implement the coalitions election commitment to provide more generous tax treatment for employee share schemes. That includes easing the employee participation conditions.We, unlike Labor, framed these changes to recognise that the employee share schemes contribute to strengthening employee participation in Australian business and to encouraging voluntary savings. These changes have been welcomed by all but the Labor Party. Everybody out there—employees and employers—have welcomed these changes. It is fairly natural that they would. Why is the Labor Party being totally ignorant of the desires of the overwhelming majority of Australian employees?Finally, the second reading amendment asks the government to reverse the proposed limitation of accelerated depreciation to shipping. The repeal of section 57AM gives effect to the governments election commitment to repeal the Ships Capital Grants Act 1987 and related accelerated depreciation provisions. This government believes that the Australian taxpayer cannot be expected to continue pouring capital grants and depreciation concessions into the shipping industry when it failed to address the serious problems impeding development as an efficient and competitive world class industry.I would also like to touch briefly on a number of issues raised in debate concerning the capital gains tax rollover relief for small business. Certain speakers referred to comments reported in the Financial Review today by the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants. The ASCPA have raised two major concerns, and I would just like to quickly go over them. Firstly, there is the ineligibility from rollover relief where shares in a small business are sold and where that relief is available only as a trade‐off against the 50 per cent goodwill exemption. When a taxpayer chooses to rollover a capital gain made on a disposed or goodwill replacement asset, the 50 per cent of goodwill exemption is deferred, not lost. The exemption will be available when the replacement asset is eventually disposed of.Secondly, both of these design features were specifically highlighted in the budget announcement and are necessary to prevent abuse of the provision. Thirdly, the ASCPA were involved in the consultative process on the legislation for the measure after the budget. They did not raise any objections to either design feature at the time, so there was consultation with the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants. We did listen to them, and they did not raise any objections to that design feature.Fourthly, a small business operated through a company structure can be sold in two ways: by selling the shares in the company, or by selling the underlined active assets. Rollover relief will only be available where the underlying assets are sold. While this may not always be the preferred method of disposal in some cases, this must be weighed up against the value of the rollover relief to the taxpayer, and a threat to the revenue of the measure to be extended to the sale of shares. If the measure were extended to the sale of shares, the legislation would be even more complex if the revenue were to be protected.Comments were also made concerning the proposed amendments to section 160ZZS relating to additional compliance costs. The point that was overlooked in those comments was that the budget announcement and this legislation contain some significant concessions. Firstly, the amendment defers the date at which the assets lose their pre‐CGT status, from the date when the majority underlying ownership changed to when the test of underlying ownership is required to be conducted. And, secondly, where a change in ownership has been found, entities will be able to determine the cost base for CGT purposes on the basis of market value at the date that the test was required, rather than valuing the assets at the market value on the date on which the underlying ownership actually changed.We are opposed to the amendment which was brought by the opposition into the Main Committee and, hopefully, I have addressed some of the issues which were raised by some of the speakers and by some of the bodies outside this House that have expressed some concerns. We believe, as the government, that this legislation is vitally important to small business throughout this country of ours. It will underpin employment opportunities and will give small business a break. It is costing the budget $200 million per year, and that is a massive boost, we believe, to small business. We think that Australian families throughout this country will benefit from this measure. We oppose the amendment put forward by the opposition and I request everybody to give support to the amendment bill as proposed by the government.Amendment negatived.Original question resolved in the affirmative.Bill read a second time.Motion ( by Mr Miles ) agreed to:That further proceedings on this bill be conducted in the House.

name: Mrs WEST
content: —It gives me a great deal of pleasure to speak today in support of Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and cognate bills. The bills cover a wide range of departments and will impact in many positive ways right across Australia, including in my own electorate of Bowman.I am going to concentrate on areas which, in my opinion, will have a significant effect on many of my constituents. Unlike many of the members opposite, I will not waste time quibbling over areas on which I may or may not personally agree. It is better to take these matters as a whole rather than waste time tearing them apart and moving amendment after amendment.Members opposite have spent much time deriding these bills and pulling them to pieces, suggesting savings here and there. Would they like money cut from the veterans childrens education scheme, or cutbacks on pharmaceutical benefits, or perhaps the War Memorial or the War Graves Commission could do with a cutback? However, there is one payment they will not be arguing about, and that appears on page 17 of Appropriation Bill (No. 4). It deals with legal costs incurred by, or on account of acting for, Dr Carmen Lawrence for or in relation to the Marks royal commission. The amounts are: additional appropriation, $49,776; total appropriation for the year, $319,927.I digress. I actually came to speak about the positive aspects of these bills. Let me start with the environment, of which I am very fond—particularly the environment of Moreton Bay and surrounding areas. I have made no secret of my love for this area. I am deeply honoured that I am fortunate enough to be the member responsible for such a magnificent area.These bills include provision for National Landcare, the Australian Heritage Commission, the National Parks and Wildlife Service, the Australian Institute of Marine Science, Australian fisheries management, fisheries resource research, Australian maritime safety and search and rescue. All of these areas have an impact on my electorate.Moreton Bay is recognised as one of the most significant breeding grounds in Australia for a variety of fish, crustaceans and marine life. There is also a substantial colony of dugong and a large population of dolphins. With the increased usage of the bay for both recreational and industrial purposes it is increasingly important that proper management of the bay be considered.Currently, there is a major dispute over state government plans to change policy on crabbing operations in the bay. A number of professional and recreational crabbers and fishermen have approached me with their concerns. It has been put to me that, should the current catch quota continue unabated, Moreton Bays crab stocks will be depleted within a matter of two years.There is also a considerable problem with the continual raping and pillaging of all varieties of sea life through trawling. It would seem that some professional fishermen have little regard for the future viability of the bay. The commercial fishermen have put it to me that as an industry they need these changes to the catch allowance, as there is growing demand for their product at the markets.Their other point is that this industry supports a growing number of families. If this is the case, then better management strategies need to be used to ensure future viability of fishing for all those involved, not just the commercial fishermen but recreational fishermen as well. It is the long‐term future of the fishing industry that is at stake at this point in time. With over 7,000 recreational fishermen using the bay regularly, depletion of fish stocks has been a concern for many of these fishermen. To ensure the future viability of this industry, it is essential that we continue to fund research into fish stocks in this and many other areas of Australia.In Bowman, I am fortunate to have a variety of research and breeding facilities. In Cleveland, there is the CSIRO, which is conducting research into a variety of marine species. I have met with Dr Ian Poiner and Mr Peter Rothlisberg and have seen the variety of facilities that are being used to continue their most important work. They are also doing considerable research into aquaculture.Down the road at Thornlands, I have a prawn farm and a yabby farm, both of which are working on new and more efficient means of farming their product. And on North Stradbroke Island there is the University of Queensland Marine Research Station. This station, which I have referred to previously in this House, is conducting research into everything from exotic marine algae to the effect of yabby pumping.The work of these groups will benefit both the recreational and commercial fishing industries. In fact, through the work of the marine research station, new research methods have been developed which have led to advances in environmental monitoring. Future research includes a study into the influence on sand erosion of dredging, land reclamation and the construction of jetties, boardwalks, groynes and seawalls. This sort of research will be of benefit to many areas, not just to Moreton Bay.Only recently, there was discussion on the Gold Coast about the effectiveness of seawalls. Every time we have big seas combined with king tides, the beaches on the Gold Coast disappear. The popular solution has been to build another seawall. Recent data would seem to show that this is not the correct course of action.Similarly, how many members present have enjoyed a moonlit walk along the boardwalk at Noosa? It is very pleasant indeed, but what is the long‐term effect of this structure? Without continuing research where will our coastline be in 20, 15 or even 10 years?I also ask those keen fishermen present: when was the last time you took home a decent feed of fish? I do not mean two or three whiting or a couple of bream; I mean a catch that would feed half‐a‐dozen friends at a barbecue. Recreational fishermen in my electorate tell me that the humble mud crab is becoming increasingly scarce in Moreton Bay and surrounding estuaries.If we continue down this track, where will the fish be for my grandchildren? A fishing trip of the future could well become a sitting trip where you may be lucky to spot the marine life. There will come a point in time when we will not even bother to bait our hooks because there will be nothing to take our worms.I say again that we need to manage our fisheries now and we need to do it properly. To this end, I would like to congratulate the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer) for his work in this area. The minister, to his credit, chose North Stradbroke Island to launch the governments new fishing code.However, Moreton Bay and the surrounding coastline are more than just a significant fishing ground; they are also the habitat for a variety of seabirds, and the wetlands area around Manly was considered as a Ramsar site. We must do what we can to protect this delicate area, and I believe that through the coasts and clean seas initiative we will be able to do just that.Future development of the foreshores needs to be closely monitored to balance environmental concerns with maintaining its economic viability. The complete oversight of all the activity carried out in the bay, along the foreshores and around and on the islands, needs to be carefully managed and monitored to cater for the diverse groups that share this waterway and adjacent environment.All relevant interest groups that use the area for recreational, residential, industrial, manufacturing or employment purposes need to be encompassed under an umbrella of one authority to coordinate the whole development of the bay. For too long, the overall management of everyday business in the bay has been ad hoc and uncoordinated, with conflict arising from special interest groups having too great an input into the extraction of resources and riding roughshod over general environmental concerns.One single authority would include representatives from the port of Brisbane and the Gateway port authority, local, state and federal decision makers, environmental groups, commercial and recreational fishers, business, tourist and residential groups. As all sections with a specific interest in the bay are represented, the continuous monitoring of development and use of the bay would be in a better state than they are at present.The objectives of the recently announced Australian oceans policy can foster and develop such a concept of a single Moreton Bay authority with further work and consultation from all interested parties. I admit this is not a new idea. Previous elected representatives have raised this concept but nothing eventuated. Anyone with a genuine commitment to the long‐term future for the sustainability of human habitation and industry in the bayside area could see that this policy can provide a wonderful opportunity to apply for assistance to make this come to fruition. It will not be an easy task but it is well worth fighting for.It is possible to have both economic viability and environmental management; we just have to be smarter about how we handle these developments. Unfortunately, when you have such a magnificent body of water, and enticing islands, you will also attract a large number of people. This, in itself, is not a huge problem. However, not everyone is as responsible as we would like and not everyone has the skill or knowledge to handle difficult situations. Mother nature can be both kind and cruel and Moreton Bay is not a place for the faint‐hearted when she turns nasty.On one of my recent trips across the bay to North Stradbroke, I had the privilege of accompanying the state minister for emergency services and the local Air Sea Rescue crew. They were possibly the roughest conditions I have ever encountered in the bay—there were 25‐knot winds; I do not mean the company on board! However, these men told me that it was nothing compared to what some fools will attempt and, unfortunately, when these reckless idiots get themselves into trouble in the middle of the bay it is these brave men and women from Air Sea Rescue who have to risk their lives to save them. The men and women of Air Sea Rescue give up their time and put their own bodies on the line for very little reward. It can also be a very gruesome job. Quite often it will be the Air Sea Rescue crew who have to pull the body of a victim from the water. This is not a job I would care to do. However, when the rewards come they can be great. This was obvious from the emotion shown by the Australian Navy officers who recently effected the rescue of the round the world yachtsmen. The sense of achievement these men must have felt would have been enough to make them forget the risks they took. For my local Air Sea Rescue crew, the elation of saving a life on Moreton Bay would be no less than it was for these brave naval officers.There is also a great need for the provision of emergency services on Moreton Island, another of the idyllic but remote areas in my electorate. Representatives of the Koringal community approached me recently to see what could be done to overcome a most extraordinary problem. When an accident occurs on Moreton Island the locals contact the Royal Flying Doctor Service in Charleville, an arrangement which seems strange when the Royal Brisbane Hospital is just two hours away and the recently upgraded ambulance station on North Stradbroke Island is just half an hour away by helicopter.I will digress for just a moment to congratulate the work being done on North Stradbroke by Dr Frank Carrol and Sister Dorothy Gerkhe of the Marie Rose facility. They do a tremendous job under sometimes trying circumstances.Back to Moreton: in recent times there have been two deaths both of which could have been prevented had they received emergency care sooner. I will continue to work for the Koringal residents association to ensure that this and other remote areas of my electorate receive adequate emergency medical services. You may be forgiven for thinking my electorate of Bowman consists solely of water. This is not the case.I would like to turn my attention to another section of the bill, and that is the additional appropriation for assistance to people with disabilities. Just this week I had great pleasure in confirming additional funding and employment places for people with disabilities in my electorate. Both the Horizon Foundation and Bayside GATE Employment Service have received extra funding for the disabled. I met with representatives from both these organisations recently to discuss their needs. So, naturally, I was very pleased to be able to ring them earlier this week with the good news.These services provide a vital service to the local community. The projects being run by the Horizon Foundation include Dial‐A‐Mower service, a service called Wire and Wood, and Link Personnel. As its name implies, the Dial‐A‐Mower service is operated by a team of workers and run as a mobile garden care business. Wire and Wood is a business activity which produces wood products and which currently holds a significant market share. Both Link and Bayside GATE are open employment services which provide employment opportunities for the disabled in the local area. In total, the new services funding is for 11 positions.With the increase of over $70,000, the total recurrent funding for Bowman is just short of $700,000, an increase of almost 12 per cent. I spoke to the directors of these services shortly after receiving the information and both were very happy with the increase. Both services have assured me that the increase in funding will go a long way to providing much needed employment opportunities for the disabled. These people have an enormous contribution to make to our communities and the governments commitment to these services is to be applauded. I am committed to helping these people gain and maintain employment and it is only through budgetary measures, such as the ones we are discussing here today that we can achieve this.Another area in which my constituents will benefit is through the increased funding for black spots. Road trauma costs the residents of Redland Shire $10 million per year. In the past 12 months we have seen four deaths in the Redland Shire and 57 casualties. Under the governments black spot funding program, local communities are being encouraged to identify black spots in their community. In my electorate of Bowman we have several potential sites. I will be encouraging local residents and community groups to put forward submissions to the minister for funding.Two such areas are School Road in Capalaba and the corner of Finucane Road and Cambridge Drive in Alexandra Hills. School Road is being treated as a speedway by local hoons who show very little respect for either the local residents or for the hundreds of school children who use the road every day. The corner that I mentioned was the site of a fatality on New Years Day this year. An elderly lady was struck by a car as she crossed the road. It is not uncommon for pedestrians to come to grief on this corner, as usually confusion reigns supreme. To make matters worse, it is used by a great number of school students and parents. It links a child‐care centre, a primary school, a high school and a shopping centre—a lethal combination if ever there was one.The black spot program, initiated by the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp), is one of the most worthwhile introduced by this government. Again, it would not be possible without the funding being provided by these bills. The road toll across this nation, particularly in regional and rural Australia, is unacceptably high. However, instead of legislating to solve the problem, as the former government was prone to do, this government would rather educate and give the community ownership of the program.I could speak on many more of the worthwhile aspects of this bill, however, I know many of my colleagues would also like an opportunity to do so. In short, if we are to see this country go forward we have to pass these bills. It is for this, and for the reasons that I have outlined, that I commend this bill to the House.
