name: Mr MOSSFIELD
content: —I rise to speak on the appropriation bills as they apply to the coalition governments industry policies. This is not unrelated to the debate that we had in this chamber this morning. My speech is made against the background of a mixed industry response to government industry policy. Last Saturday, 1 March, in the Australian , there were headlines that said `Flotsam of policy leaves captains of industry all at sea: John Howard promised a cohesive plan for industry. A year later, business is still waiting. There was also an article last week in the Australian Financial Review relating to manufacturing increasing as a percentage of exports. The article says that the national chief executive of the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, Mr Alan Handberg, stressed that the growth in manufactured exports was unlikely to be sustained without a national plan, and that manufactured exports still lagged a long way behind manufactured imports.So there is still a long way to go, but I see manufacturing as having the potential to fill the employment gap between the high wage, high skill industries, where there is not a lot of employment growth, and the low wage, part‐time and casual employment areas where most of this countrys employment growth is. The recently released ABS employment figures show that 38,400 new jobs were created in January. However, nearly 35,000 of these were part time. To highlight a problem that this is creating in the training area—I know the honourable member for Latrobe (Mr Charles) would be quite interested in this—I will quote from a paper given by Richard Sweet from the Dusseldorp Skills Forum at the Tasmanian Education Consortium in Hobart, which was held on 10 to 12 October last year. It states:In May 1996 part‐time work accounted for a quarter of all employment, but in retail trade and the accommodation and hospitality industries it accounted for one job in two. In the service sector in particular the rapid growth of part‐time casual employment, among both adults and among young people, has severely limited the scope for apprenticeships or traineeships to establish themselves, as the existing models are largely based upon the assumption that both young people and those that supervise and train them in the workplace have a full‐time job.I believe that the manufacturing industry can provide the real jobs, the training and employment growth and the fair wage rates that middle Australia is crying out for. Yet under the coalitions policy of cutting assistance, manufacturing industry is not being able to reach its full potential. In fact, the long‐term prediction for our manufacturing industry is far from rosy. Surely this must be of some concern to the government.If we look at what industry is saying, we can get a clearer position of how industry sees the future. I looked back over the last nine months to see what business commentators, business reports and surveys were saying. In June last year, a survey by the Australian Business Chamber and the State Bank of 500 New South Wales companies showed that the June quarter was the sixth in a row where production, sales and orders had all weakened. In response, companies were reducing prices and cutting back on employment.We saw the same two organisations reporting in September that Australian manufacturers were continuing to experience adverse conditions. The prediction in that survey was that manufacturing could shed as many as 15,000 jobs in the year ahead due to these adverse conditions. Mr Philip Holt, the managing director of the Australian Business Chamber, said at the time that several factors were affecting business conditions in manufacturing—and he listed them—but, clearly, Mr Holts major concern related to the governments lack of commitment to a strong, clear industry policy.This lack of leadership in industry policy was further amplified at a dinner hosted by the Heavy Engineering Manufacturers Association, whose membership includes major companies such as BHP, Transfield and ANI. The chairman of the St George Bank and Howard Smith Ltd, Mr Frank Conroy, told the dinner that there was a `vacuum of embarrassed silence on key issues relating to industry and employment. In his speech at the associations dinner, on 9 October in Canberra, Mr Conroy said:Perhaps even more frightening is that there is no apparent answer to the problem of employment. Worse, there is very little serious public debate or understanding of what might be an acceptable level of unemployment in todays fast changing economy.Indeed, the phrase itself has fallen into disuse politically, perhaps because there are no apparent answers, perhaps because scapegoats are easier to find than answers.N/AMr Deputy Speaker, you can see that industry itself is certainly not conveying a lot of confidence in the governments policy. In August, a visiting Harvard economist Mr Jeffrey Sachs, while praising some of the economic reforms introduced in Australia was nevertheless critical of Australias lack of encouragement for manufacturing exports. In his talks in Australia, Sachs referred to the successful Asian economies where special export manufacturing zones, with tax holidays and other assistance, are designed to attract foreign investors. Some of those may well be disgruntled Australian manufacturers.In October we saw a report which referred to a survey carried out by Price Waterhouse that showed that the federal governments decision to drop research and development tax concessions from 150 per cent to 125 per cent could reduce business expenditure on R&D to early 1980s levels. The survey covered 250 businesses in technology, mining, telecommunications, building, food, chemicals, pharmaceutical and manufacturing, and showed that more than half expected to reduce their R&D investment by 20 per cent or more because of changes to R&D assistance.An article in the Financial Review of 13 February this year says:Companies have little faith in government industry policy and the cut to the research and development tax concessions has made them less likely to undertake risky R&D or even claim the reduced concession.The article referred to a survey released on 12 February by Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu which showed that only 16 per cent of respondents believed that the government was achieving its industry policy objectives. Seventy‐five per cent of respondents said that the government was not providing adequate support for promising new industries with strong international potential. The survey also found that 83 per cent of firms believed that cuts to R&D tax concessions would inhibit industrys quest for high growth. What an absolute indictment of a government decision.The growth areas in manufacturing are those that require a high degree of research and development. Some of these areas cover groups such as computers, general electronics, scientific instruments, cars and pharmaceuticals. Yet we have seen the government stripping back assistance to these industries. The Metal Trades Industry Associations December 1996 quarterly survey of business conditions showed a pick‐up of sectional activities, but this was largely seasonal. The MTIA Chief Executive, Mr Bob Herbert, said:No early return to the more robust demand conditions that prevailed in 1994‐95 is anticipated.The Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry has called for an overhaul of the federal governments industry policy, including the restoration of the research and development tax concession.Among the many ACCI submissions to the governments review of industry assistance programs was a call for Australia not to move too quickly on tariff reductions until the government was satisfied that Australia has a fair and reasonable access to overseas markets. A report in the Australian of 18 February said:Female factory workers have borne the brunt of job losses caused by tariff cuts in the textile, clothing and footwear industry, with 26,000 laid off in the last two years, a study shows.An analysis prepared for the Productivity Commissions inquiry into the textile, clothing and footwear industries reveals manufacturing production is the lowest in 20 years, with profits approaching the low level recorded in the 1990‐91 recession.The productivity slump has cost 20,000 jobs in two years with employment dropping from 124,000 workers in November 1994 to 104,000 in November 1995.N/AThe Australian Chamber of Manufactures in its submission to the Mortimer review of Australias business program said that the manufacturing share of the Australian economy had fallen from 24 per cent in 1970 to 14.7 per cent now. The ACM calls for: firstly, restoration of export development and R&D funding to at least the level applying before the 1996‐97 budget cuts; secondly, bilateral negotiations to secure for Australian manufacturers the same treatment in overseas markets as exporters from these countries receive in Australia; and, thirdly, expansion of the activities by the Industrial Supplies Office and establishment of a major regional development program.I want to expand a little on the third point of the ACMs submission to the inquiry relating to the Industrial Supplies Office. I was pleased to receive in the mail recently a copy of the New South Wales Industrial Supplies Offices annual review for 1995‐96. The role of the New South Wales ISO is to source for Australian industry goods and products manufactured in Australia and so reduce Australias reliance on imports.The executive director of ISO reported in the annual review that 1995‐96 had been a very successful year for the New South Wales ISO, with the organisation having participated in projects which have returned $145 million worth of business to Australian manufacturers. New South Wales manufacturers received $65 million in orders, which, according to ISO economic multipliers, converted to approximately 1,900 New South Wales jobs.As a nation we are relying too heavily on imports to meet local demands for manufactured goods—as we all know. Our reliance on imports is a major contributor to Australias disastrous balance of payments figures—our current account deficit was $1.4 billion in December last year.Mr Bert Evans, Chairman of the New South Wales ISO, said in the annual report:Consider our 1995/96 import bill of $77 billion. If we replaced just five per cent of that with local production we could create 113,000 new jobs; over $1 billion in extra taxes and charges to governments; nearly $1 billion in welfare savings; and nearly $900 million in extra consumer spending. These are the objectives that the ISO is endeavouring to achieve.Rather than depend on restricting imports by tariff and non‐tariff barriers, the ISO lets the market decide what imports should be replaced. By matching the needs of purchasers, who would otherwise be importing, to the industrial capacity of Australian manufacturing the ISO has replaced imports on a commercially viable basis.The ISO has been successful in convincing many Australian industries to switch to locally made products based on cost and quality. This means that the economic growth which occurs with the replacement of these imports has been achieved without adding to inflation. By buying better value, these purchasers actually contribute to the control of inflation.During its 12 years of operation, the ISO has been demonstrating how to develop industry and create jobs through import replacement. The annual report highlights a number of major projects that the ISO has been involved in over the past 12 months. I intend to briefly mention some of these projects as outlined in the review.The Sydney airport noise attenuation project required airconditioning of houses and schools under the flight paths and for these premises to be completely sealed and insulated against noise. A major problem arose as to how to provide fresh air and how to aircondition insulated buildings. These problems were overcome by the ISO Commonwealth purchasing consultant developing a unique in‐loft airconditioning unit. The solution of this problem has resulted in Emailair and its Australian suppliers benefiting by more than a million dollars, and it has placed Australian companies in the forefront of domestic airconditioning internationally.ISO involvement has led to Australias only spark plug manufacturer, Champion, replacing its wide use of imported steel rod with a BHP product which will result in millions of dollars worth of export income for Australia. ISO has also targeted overseas manufacturers to replace steel intensive imports with Australian made steel. The program has resulted in one manufacturer of 50‐ to 120‐tonne mining trucks, who was about to import onto the Australian market, being introduced to local manufacturers capable of producing payload trays. An additional $3 million of work for Australia also is being targeted in the ship container market.Also, the close working relationship developed between the New South Wales ISO and the Australian defence industry has exposed many Hunter region manufacturers to the world of leading edge defence technology. This exposure has come about through the construction, at Carrington, of one of the most advanced naval vessels in the world. After just two years into an eight‐year contract, the Australian industry involvement in this project is already set to exceed 69 per cent of the $1.2 billion total contract value. Of the 1,150 active suppliers to the project, over 900 are Australian and New Zealand companies and more than half of them are based in the Hunter region. The approach by ISO and ADI has enabled local capacity to develop the Hunter region into one of the worlds most advanced shipbuilding centres.The ISO annual review also reported on a successful project involving ISO, Davey John Brown Pty Ltd and BHP Steel. The joint effort related to the No. 6 blast furnace at the BHP Port Kembla facility. While ISO located suitable Australian manufacturers for different components, Davey John Brown Pty Ltd and BHP negotiated with offshore equipment designers to have their designs built locally rather than in foreign workshops. The $10 million of extra local business for this project will create approximately 300 extra jobs and place some $2.6 million in consumer spending power into the pockets of Australian families. The development of regional manufacturing capacity, as detailed in the minehunter and BHP projects, is being encouraged by the New South Wales ISO establishing regional offices in the Illawarra, Orange and Albury.Mr Deputy Speaker, it is appropriate that you arrived in the chair at this time, as I was speaking about the great value that ISO has brought to the industry in Port Kembla. I am a strong supporter of the Industrial Supplies Office—I am not too sure whether you are familiar with its role. As I understand, it is basically funded by the New South Wales government. However, there is a peak national body called the ISO network, and I would appeal to the current federal government to look strongly at the work that this organisation does because it does a great job for Australian industry.You can see from these remarks that the ISO network is playing a major role in sourcing work for Australian industry. I understand that, under the previous Labor governments industry policy, some 13 consultants were funded to work with various ISO networks throughout Australia in specific fields. I am concerned that this current government will cut the funding for these consultants. I would urge the government to follow the Australian Chamber of Manufactures suggestion and expand the activities of the Industrial Supplies Office in the interests of manufacturing industry in Australia.

name: Mr EOIN CAMERON
content: —I would like to bring to the attention of the parliament a report following my original concerns in regard to Cash Converters which I aired in the last parliament. The report was prepared by Mr Terry Donnelly of Western Australia. Mr Donnelly is not a professional investigator; he has no personal or vested interest in the subject matter of this report. He does have a history of honorary work in crime prevention and control, being the founder of the concept of Crime Free Day, as well as having been chairman of Citysafe Perth Community Policing Committee and a member of the Safer Australia board, established by the then federal Minister for Justice, Mr Duncan Kerr.Many of the documents on which the author has relied came to him directly from former employees and franchisees of the Cash Converters group. As a result of his experiences over three years, he feels entitled to ask one question:When I was able, with so few resources, to unearth so much that cried out for investigation, why is it that these are areas where the various law enforcement agencies of Australia appear so reluctant to enter?N/ACash Converters Pty Ltd was registered on 6 January 1988. According to its documents of incorporation, the companys principal business activity was to be that of `franchisor.The trading company began its operations in Western Australia where it opened a handful of stores. After that, expansion was rapid. In April 1995, following some changes in the composition of its board of directors, the trading companys shares were acquired by a new company called Cash Converters International Ltd, the `holding company. Thirty‐five per cent of the share capital in the holding company was floated on the London stock market in December 1995. By that time there were 129 Cash Converters stores in Australia. In addition, there were 85 overseas stores.The public trading activities that the Cash Converters group support are pawnbroking and dealing in second‐hand goods. Both are regulated businesses, the first being concerned with lending on the security of goods and the second with the simple purchase and resale of goods. Because of the high interest rates charged by pawnbrokers to their customers and the wide margins expected by dealers on buying and selling goods, both these operations form highly profitable businesses. But, above all else, they need substantial working capital. The Cash Converters group has gone beyond the simple practice of pawnbroking and dealing to develop the concept of packaging and franchising those activities.There are a handful of key individuals whose influence on the organisation is all‐pervading. Brian Cumins is the founder of the business. He personally opened the first Cash Converters pawnbroking shop in Perth, Western Australia. George McIntosh Smith was involved formerly with Brian Cumins in his Bed Shed business. He is a director of Kundahera Pty Ltd, the franchisee of Cash Converters Subiaco; a director of Cumbri Enterprises Pty Ltd, the franchisee of Cash Converters Fremantle; and a director of Sunvale Pty Ltd, the franchisee of Cash Converters Bunbury.Craig Eric Green operates franchises at Melville, Cannon Hill and Stones Corner in Queensland. Peter Cumins is the younger brother of Brian Cumins and a qualified accountant with a civil service background. Michael Ian Cooke is a solicitor who has practised for some years in Western Australia. His practice has handled Cash Converters non‐contentious legal work since 1992. Wayne Hubbard and his brother Russell are the largest franchisees in Australia, having numerous stores in Western Australia, South Australia and Victoria.I would now like to highlight some accounting and administrative irregularities. First, the cost of establishing each new trading outlet is typically between $200,000 and $500,000. Apart from initial setting‐up costs and usual business overheads, trading itself makes enormous cash demands—at least during the first two or three years. The operation was only established in 1988 and it now has nearly 200 outlets around the world. This has required far more money than is disclosed anywhere in the accounts of the various group companies lodged with the Australian Securities Commission.Second, individual bookkeeping irregularities are necessarily complicated to demonstrate, but are to be found throughout the companies financial documents. For the sake of convenience, these are highlighted as and where they have been discovered among the case histories of failed franchises set out in appendix 6 to the report by Terry Donnelly.Third, there is a curious anomaly in the April 1994 prospectus concerning the finance company. In it, the auditors are shown as Messrs Murphy Sherry and Co., 1st floor, 885 Albany Highway, East Victoria Park, Western Australia. The independent auditors report is provided on the letterhead of Messrs Murphy Sherry and Co. showing their address as 305 Abernethy Road, Cloverdale, Western Australia, and giving telephone numbers pertinent to Accountancy WA and Half Price Accounting, of which R.J.Murphy is the principal.The reality is that Murphy Sherry and Co. did not move out of the Victoria Park address—Cash Converters own main office—until after or about April 1995. The false statement maintained, over a very long period, the illusion of the auditors physical separation from the trading company. It ought to be a matter of concern to the ASC that this irregularity was allowed to persist in the important area of information provided in a registered prospectus.Fourth, when the holding companys shares were floated in late 1995, Henderson Crosthwaite, as the companys UK institutional directors, correctly stated on behalf of the holding company that the potential for its continued growth depended on the requirement that `all existing outlets continue to trade, and continue to make their contracted weekly payments.Similarly, the directors of Franchise Investments International Ltd—another group company—stated at pages 25 and 26 of their prospectus, dated 24 July 1996, that the risk factor of investing in their company was `the financial security of Cash Converters International Ltd and hence the reputation of the Cash Converters system is substantially dependent on the continued success of the Cash Converters franchised outlets linked to `the continued ability of franchises to pay contracted fees to the company as and when they fall due.Notwithstanding the above statement contained in prospectus documents for the information of potential investors, the accounts of the holding company prior to its flotation failed to make any provision for the fact that by October 1995 the companys Victorian franchisees were in arrears to the extent of over at least $400,000 and that the majority of its Victorian franchisees were struggling to meet their obligations. Those same facts were not made public in the holding companys prospectus dated 16 October 1995, which was approved by its directors, its auditors and both the Australian stockbroker, Morgan Stockbroking Ltd, and the UK stockbroker, Henderson Crosthwaite Corporation Finance Ltd.Franchising, as a business solution to the inherent problem of expanding while under‐capitalised, was explored for the trading company in a thoroughly researched feasibility study prepared in 1988 by Penny Kirby of All Media Direct. She is the wife of Barrington Kirby who was originally a director of the trading company but had resigned in 1990. In the `Cash Converters story, 1995 at page 64, Brian Cumins lists the common benefits of franchising as follows: first, the franchisee gets to operate under an accepted and well known trading name. Second, a business management system which is proven and tested is supplied. Third, head office makes sure that physical support is available during the commissioning process of a new franchise. Fourth, information on how to handle legal, accounting, taxation and employment regulations is immediately available. Fifth, training is provided and professional marketing services are handled on a centralised basis which allows for economies of scale. Sixth, it is in the interests of franchisors to make their businesses work, it is against their interests to allow a franchisee to fail, and they tend to react accordingly. Seven, new franchisees are chosen with great care, and not simply because they have the licence fee available. This has the effect of screening out those who are patently unsuitable. Eight, statistics show that 90 per cent of franchised businesses survive and flourish.Such ideals have not characterised the Cash Converters system of franchising. Nearly 70 per cent of their Victorian franchises have failed.Subjugation by debt has been achieved by Cash Converters Pty Ltd by enforcing the following key elements: first is the enforcement of initial and weekly licence fees, the former being known as a fixed fee, though in reality it is a sum of money ranging from $50,000 to $200,000 per store, apparently based on no better criteria than what each franchisee could bear. The weekly fee tends to start at around $500 and rise annually to $1,500 reviewed thereafter on CPI changes.Second is the enforcement of a training levy debited monthly to the franchisee whether or not he uses the Cash Converters training program. Third, there is an advertising levy of 7.5 per cent of gross bookings charged to each franchisee. Such advertising is controlled entirely by the trading company, which retains any discounts obtained and fails to account properly for its charges. Some amazing calculations and extracts from the trading companys standard franchise agreement are set out in appendix 5. The real effect is that the genuine franchisees are in fact subsidising the advertising costs of those outlets under the control of the trading companys core directors.Fourth, every franchisee must initially invest $5,000 in the Cash Converters finance company and agree to vest all share voting rights and interest earned in Cash Converters Pty Ltd. In addition, each franchisee must advance to the finance company a monthly sum to build a capital fund to enable renewal of the franchise on expiry of the prior term. These payments are received by the finance company as subscriptions for unsecured notes, and therefore constitute an interest free loan to the finance company. The right, title and interest of the franchisee in and to the notes is assigned and mortgaged to the franchisor.Upon assignment, expiration or termination of the franchise agreement, the franchisee is required to sell his shares to the franchisor for $1 per share. Ostensibly, these payments are for the renewal of the franchise at the end of each 10 years. In fact, with the constant turnover of franchises, this scheme allows the key players access to a massive ongoing cash flow—an enhanced debt subjugation of the franchisees. Most loans that the author of this report has cited have been made to enable franchisees to pay arrears of advertising and franchise fees.Brian Cumins has often remarked that Cash Converters franchises are sold on the sizzle and not the sausage. Much of that sizzling has occurred in Victoria, which was targeted by the company following Mrs Kirbys bullish feasibility study. Some of the result in human cost is exemplified in the case history summarised in appendix 6. These represent just a handful of the many franchise breakdowns where the only beneficiary was the trading company or one of its associated companies.It can be argued that the franchisees entered freely into their standard contracts and have to accept them. Against that, all the evidence is that it is the policy of the trading company to dissuade incomers from taking independent legal or accounting advice. The accounting practices are unfair; the contracts themselves deliberately fail to provide any dispute resolution procedures or arbitration clauses; and the manipulation of the contracts by the trading company amounts to systematic oppression of those who are in a manifestly weaker bargaining position.One of the main themes of the report has been the inherent commercial impossibility of expanding so rapidly a cash hungry business that has no obvious sources of funding. The existence in Australia of large sums of black money is an officially acknowledged fact. Money laundering, in the sense of trying in financial terms to legitimise such cash in the hands of its possessor, is a task that occupies the minds and ingenuity of many. One typical way is to feed the cash into an apparently respectable business so that it can be drawn out again in what appears to be a lawful payment or expense.It is from sources such as those that Brian Cumins was able to borrow, at interest rates of around 40 per cent per annum, the funds that would be lent through the stores that he and his fellow directors controlled. As illustrated in appendix 2 of the report, the same funds would be lent to Cash Converters clients, borrowing at interest rates of 30 per cent per month.Even on the evidence of disclosed accounts, huge amounts of cash have been injected into Cash Converters businesses, always provided that they have been stores in which Brian Cumins has had a personal financial interest. This happened systematically during the companies expansion in Victoria during 1991. As then managing director of the trading company, Brian Cumins lent or invested cash sums totalling not less than $634,043.62 in Cash Converters stores at Dandenong, Moonee Ponds, Preston, Clayton and Forest Hill—all of them stores in which he was financially involved. The details of these are listed in appendix 7.Over the past seven years there has been a sharp increase in the nations crime figures, particularly those involving juveniles. In Western Australia, where Cash Converters has its roots, the number of offences relating to stealing and breaking and entering rose from 87,238 to 133,247—an increase of 65 per cent. In order to fund their expensive habit, young drug addicts steal—often from family and friends—and take the goods to Cash Converters and other pawnbrokers and second‐hand dealers. Within two hours of committing a break, young criminals have sold the goods, organised their drug purchases and hit up.Modern homes, as we all know, brim with smart items—television sets, computers, hi‐fis, videos and camcorders—whose great merit is that they are portable, valuable and instantly marketable—as good as cash, in fact, just waiting to be converted. In its simplest form, a desperate addict with a $600‐a‐day drug habit will steal goods worth several thousand dollars and pawn or sell them for a few hundred.When South Australian police raided a Cash Converters store in Gouger Street, Adelaide, in April 1996, they found that 40 per cent of the goods held there were reported stolen. The store had been open for four months, but still its opening stock had not been recorded in its books, as legally required. Peter Cumins admitted later that the franchisee at Gouger Street failed to follow the proper procedures in this respect. You can only ask what the proper procedures might be!Another police operation in New South Wales, known as Operation Basalt, led to 135 people being charged on a total of 2,612 counts involving stolen goods worth about $2 million. The much heralded and publicised Cash Converters ID card has not reduced crime against property. Rather, it has led to an increase in the volume of stolen goods being processed through Cash Converters stores. A single example of multiple pawning by a young drug addict holding such a card is set out in appendix 8.The reality is that almost anyone can pass the 100‐point test to get the ID card and, once in possession of it, there will be few—if any—checks on whether its holder is selling stolen goods. The words of the many innocent victims, helpless in the knowledge that the loss of their possessions has been facilitated by an apparently unregulated system, are represented by the examples set out in appendix 9 of the report. Their names have not been divulged, but all such details are available with supporting documents.On Thursday, 30 November 1995, the holding company, Cash Converters International Ltd, was launched on the London Stock Exchange. In the light of all the comments above and the criticism at the time in the Australian parliament regarding Cash Converters operations, it is surprising that the flotation went ahead and was counted a success. Apart from all other considerations, why should the controlling directors want ownership of the phantom money in the group to pass to outside shareholders? The answer is that it did not. When you have phantom money, it is best to have a phantom flotation.Appendix 10 shows a list extracted from the holding companys register of shareholders following the flotation. It reveals that of the 34 million shares issued by the holding company more than 73 per cent are held behind a screen of nominees. A further two per cent of the floated share capital is owned openly by Brian Cumins and his co‐directors, Peter Cumins and Michael Cooke, or his other close associates, Simon Martin and Russell Hubbard. All of this, of course, excludes the retained 66 million shares, which remained at all times in the hands of the controlling directors and their associates.In conclusion, having obtained the accolade of a Stock Exchange flotation, the holding company is anxious to press ahead with the marketing of its franchises internationally, but indications are that this is proving more difficult than expected in Europe and the United States of America. It is easy to find victims in the pages of this report: those who have been unwise enough, as outsiders, to invest money as franchisees in the Cash Converters group; those whose goods are stolen, often by family and friends, to provide the raw stock for the pawnbroking and dealing trades; those who pay their taxes knowing that others in their midst are above such concerns; even those with a dependency on drugs who remain beyond help while such a well‐organised system makes it easy for the desperate to get what they think they need.It is not the task of this report to lay down what should be done, but rather to draw attention to the activities of people who care for nobody but themselves while pretending to offer a public service. If that is the public service, then it is the service that powers the needle on the end of the syringe. I would like to conclude by reading, for the information of the House, a letter that I have sent to the Hon. John Day MP, the Minister for Police and Emergency Services in Western Australia. It reads:I am writing following a complaint concerning Cash Converters. You may be aware of my concerns regarding this chain of stores, and I attach a speech I made to the House of Representatives concerning it. My concern is still as strong as when I made those comments, because still, today, Cash Converters continue to launder stolen goods, unwittingly or otherwise.You may be aware of a theft at a private girls school recently where approximately $20,000 worth of various equipment was stolen, such as microscopes, computer equipment and so on.The thief allegedly took the goods to Cash Converters and sold them to the pawnbroker. It is alleged the computer, worth $7,000, was sold to Cash Converters for $300. There were allegedly no checks made of the equipment, which if any had, would have identified the schools ownership engraved on the equipment.The thief was allegedly tracked down through the compulsory identification checks that now apply and has apparently been charged, however, in the interim, some of the equipment had already been sold and could not be returned to the school.One such piece of equipment was a computer which Cash Converters sold for $3,000. The person who bought the computer `booted it up and the schools identity immediately came up on the screen at the opening of the starting program. The person apparently contacted the school to ask if they had `lost any equipment lately, and was advised that a theft had occurred and equipment had been stolen.The person when advised of the circumstances in which he attained the computer returned it to the school for which Cash Converters refunded him. Unfortunately, the school did not get everything back, and I understand, were not compensated by Cash Converters for the missing equipment. Luckily, they will be protected by their insurance company, but that is not the point (no wonder premiums keep increasing!!).I am dumbfounded that a company receiving and selling stolen goods is able to wash its hands of responsibility for identifying the ownership of goods before it places them on sale. Further, I am appalled that even though they may conduct identification checks, Cash Converters apparently does not check out the property for other identifying marks, in the event it could have been stolen. Surely, when a schools engravings are on the equipment, plus the installed software, then why werent they contacted to determine if the school was missing the equipment before they put it on sale.There is a bit more to go on with, but I have run out of time. I thank you for your time, Mr Deputy Speaker.
debateinfo: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1996‐97 Cognate bills: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1996‐97 APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1996‐97
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr ADAMS
content: —I wish to speak on the appropriation bills on the matter of the economy, with a focus on regions and, in particular, Tasmania. I recently submitted a paper to the Nixon inquiry, which is an inquiry into the Tasmanian economy. I believe that we have to consider the implications of past, current and future policy on the direction that can be taken by areas outside the urban fringes. Tasmania is a good case study, as it holds many of the problems that other states also face.Australia has had a number of challenges over the years. Change has been massive in the past three decades, with technology changing as rapidly in the past 10 years as it has in the past 100. Politicians need to understand the processes of change to adapt their strategies to cope with the results of that change. It is often a fine balancing act of knowing where and when to intervene and when not to, and this is particularly poignant in Tasmania because of its small population and isolation. It being my home state, it must be my prime consideration. However, I am interested in the overall regional economic questions for the country.Current trends in regional development which affect the economic wellbeing of rural and regional areas are infrastructure, transport, unemployment, communications, health, education, energy, banks and commerce, changes in the major industries, growth or decline of regional markets and foreign markets, exports and tourism—to name the major ones. There are also the difficulties of cutting back the public sector without replacing it with some mechanism to assist those who live and work outside urban areas. We should look at the implications of social and technological change on our major resource industries. The sale of government assets—and the impact of the Hilmer report on a community that cannot benefit by either the public or the private sectors economies of scale—is considerable.The size and distribution of the population is a contributing factor to a states ability to deal with regional variations. When the state moves out of an area such as health, who moves in? Those that would like to make a profit at it, and they may not be Australians. Who is buying Australians right to health? Is this bit of the farm being sold as well?In the 1970s, Australia was going through the first throes of massive industrial change and structural adaptation. It was a time of great discussion, and new ideas were on the horizon, with the future being predicted through populist books like Barry Joness Sleepers, Wake! and Alvin Tofflers Future Shock and The Third Wave . We knew there was going to be real change in lifestyle, in economies and in the viewing of work, industrial relations, social breakdown and societal relationships. What we did not know was the sort of effect it would have on peripheral areas or how it could be coped with.The 1970s and the 1980s showed much hope for Australia, but now we have to face the effects of change. As the Chicago Tribune s Bob Herbert wrote in an article on 23 January of this year:As America continues to prosper, there is less and less of a sense that everybody has a stake in what is going on. More and more Americans are being left out.Substitute `Australia for `America, and much the same is occurring. I believe that, under the Howard government, that will be the situation in Australia: more and more people being left out.The communications industry has had a major impact on the Australian scene: whether it be television aggregation, the introduction of mobile phones, fax modems, the Internet and the World Wide Web, all have combined to produce a major post‐industrial revolution in interpersonal contact. Australia has taken to the technology like a duck to water, and Australians are clamouring to be part of the action. However, we have a big problem in Tasmania, where there has been a number of major problems and setbacks because the infrastructure is not in place.The few opportunities that were fought for, particularly in Lyons, my own electorate, have been either removed or not extended. Examples are the removal of the Community Information Network from the local communities, which particularly affects Lyons; the non‐extension of the mobile digital phone coverage to the lower east coast, the Tasman Peninsular, the central highlands, and Flinders and King islands; and the difficulties experienced with UHF coverage for television, even in the most populated areas such as New Norfolk, Queenstown and much of the east and west coasts, which have caused major concerns to those communities.Other services, such as telegrams, post office fax facilities, and even an interstate service for finding addresses through Telstra, are non‐existent, the latter having been removed in November 1996 without public advice, which means that somebody who does not have a fax number and cannot phone is unable to write to a company in another state. Community obligation should ensure that a comparable communications service is available to everyone in Australia. At the moment, only those communities close to urban centres and the cities have access.In the next five years we are looking at some major changes in IT format which will include: multi‐media with video, graphics, text and Internet activities—for both educational and entertainment purposes; personnel management, systems and office programs to allow more efficiency in offices; on‐line electronic commerce which is currently being developed by IT but has yet to be introduced fully by the banks.What is the most lucrative part of this industry? It is in its future and Australias ability to gain financially as a nation from being a part of it. Yet this is the area which is being sold off for short‐term gain, losing us a secure future and our kids a future at all.Federal government policy on tariffs will be of great significance to regional manufacturing investment. There needs to be a politically bipartisan approach in considering the tariff threshold. Tasmania can be the hardest hit when tariffs are lowered or abandoned when overseas competitors are comfortably subsidised. Areas such as dairy produce, car parts manufacturing, clothing and textiles, for example, are having difficulties competing in the export game when they are up against very differently structured and protected competitors.I was pleased to see the favourable press on the oppositions automotive industry plan launched last week by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) and the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Crean). We have realised more quickly than government what impact the tariff reduction has had on jobs in Australia. So those companies that are still operating successfully need to be encouraged to stay in the country and maintain job levels. We can do this only by giving them incentives, help to secure a base for investment and a commitment not to leave some of the small sectors open to takeover or asset stripping by international raiders.Both state and federal governments have set out on an exercise of radically cutting the public sector. This has not been able to be filled by the private sector, which was not in a position to fill this area in a non‐profitable or in a socially oriented way. The traditional big employers in the states are no longer there. Many of the industries have been cut back because of the introduction of new technology.During the introduction of new technology there were no trade‐offs made to retain or re‐employ people in other areas, which means there is a large group of ageing employees for whom positions cannot be found, and they will continue to have difficulties in finding positions.At the other end of the spectrum there are fewer traineeships and apprenticeships being offered as smaller companies cannot afford to train, preferring to pick graduates who can be financially useful from the day of employment. This leaves a sizeable group of young people just out of school to go onto the long‐term unemployment list, without much hope of finding meaningful work.Job opportunities are being lost because this government does not have the foresight to help expand small but successful business or assist in the development of new ones that spring up through community effort. Sometimes a little risk capital worked strategically can mean success to a struggling new business. This government sees intervention in a way as a charity, not as an investment into the future. They have abandoned small business.Doctor John Marsden pointed out in the Financial Review on 3 March 1997 that although Australias economic growth is well above its 20‐year average, 80 per cent of the small business that was surveyed in Australia see the economy in recession or at a standstill. Growth has been where small business and jobs are not.Government intervention should not be seen as interference. It can complement and facilitate in areas where the private sector is unable to assist. The tax system should not be seen as merely funding the welfare sector. This leads to resentment and criticism of one sector of the community by another. Government funds should be used efficiently but there needs to be an overall investment in the community, both economically and socially. Without it, we become a nation divided and destructively competitive.The overall question of unemployment must be addressed. Throwing money at it does not assist. There has to be an ongoing strategy to train our young people, allowing people in the older age bracket to retire early if they wish, or be meaningfully employed in their later years as trainers, policy developers or senior advisers in their areas of expertise. They should not be penalised for retiring early.There has been some deep concern also at the way that the Hilmer report has been used. Hilmer stated that competition is an important and powerful force for economic efficiency and he concluded that economic efficiency generally was a great benefit to consumers. He went on to say:We recognise that competition might not always be effective in achieving consumer benefits or that it might lead to conflicts with other social goals. Competition policy thus aims to produce guidelines that determine the nature and extent of competition and the ways in which possible conflicts between results of competition, economic efficiency and other social goals are to be handled.Those who have taken on the Hilmer ideas without reading what he was actually saying have come to interpret his paper as saying that competition is de rigeur without considering the possible conflicts with other social goals. In the public sector, which includes local government and all the other levels, sometimes competition is not the most efficient way to deal with efficiencies. Tasmania is not an easy state to apply competition policy in its completely deregulated sense. There are other factors where the marketplace cannot assist.Eva Cox has been addressing this question in the Boyer lectures and wrote about a civil society in the Evatt papers 1996. She said:We need a balance between the State, the Market and the Community. We have tended to give a dominance to the market, with a secondary role to government, but often supporting the market or just countering it in minor ways and we have forgotten about the community and the involvement of people.Other commentators have also been addressing this issue and have come to the same conclusion. The local community is best placed to develop solutions to local problems. However, these people cannot achieve these sorts of solutions on their own; there needs to be infrastructure, strategies and directions developed so that each group can feed into a format to allow a state plan to be formalised.The private sector cannot undertake roles played by the state and the community. State and local government are in a good position to facilitate and advise, especially where the marketplace fails, but they also have a role to help support the infrastructure for the marketplace. So much can depend on proper government policies and strategies. This government does not appear to have anything that will really deal with the ills that have beset this country in the last few months. Nor do they expect to have anything in the near future, especially since we have just heard that Treasurer Costello has blown out the budget by a further $2.5 billion.What does he have to show for it? Certainly, there are no new jobs, which is what are desperately needed in Australia. It seems that these days we want to make the poor poorer, the rich richer, and make the community more suspicious of their neighbours. All this is happening and there are fewer powers to deal with getting to the truth.We cannot keep selling off Australia. We must keep the farm intact and keep incentives for people to invest in Australia and its people without us losing the basic assets. Australias regions should be nourished and not abandoned and its people should be encouraged and not forgotten, as they are by this government.I will be very interested to hear how the member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), who is to follow me in this debate, addresses these questions. I have heard him talk elaborately about free trade but I have yet to hear him address the issues of loss in regional Australia, of loss in the public sector, and the economic decline in many of our regions. I have yet to hear him address how we deal with that. Maybe we need incentives in place to try to encourage the replacement of infrastructure and replace the private sector pullout such as the closing of banks. I would like to hear how economic problems in the regions can be dealt with.Overall, I have seen very little come from the government side in the debate about regions. I have seen the government withdraw many services such as CES offices, Medicare offices, legal aid offices, the reduction in legal aid now, and the Family Court in regions in my own state. I have seen those things withdrawn with nothing done to replace them. I have seen the private sector withdraw bank branches. We have seen these losses in many regional areas.Many people in regional cities have told me that the towns around them are dying and that the people in those towns are moving into the cities. Within a few years those cities too will start to have pressure on them as their infrastructure starts to decline and so the economic needs of regions will need to be looked at in some positive ways. I look forward to hearing some positive ways of how we can achieve goals and work towards looking after some of our regional cities and regional areas in Australia. I look forward to hearing something other than rhetoric.I am also conscious, of course, that the minister for transport and so‐called regional affairs in this government at the time of the budget last year said that the Commonwealth really had no constitutional responsibility for regional Australia. Of course, since then they have reduced the regional affairs department to five or six people who are employed to answer the ministers correspondence, basically. That has been the outcome of this governments response to the calls from regional Australia.

name: Mr ANDREW
content: —I welcome the opportunity to participate in the appropriation bills debate. I welcome the opportunity, as clearly the member for Lyons (Mr Adams) and before him the member for Greenway (Mr Mossfield) and other members on this side of the House have done, because the appropriation bills allow us to participate in a wide ranging debate. The member for Lyons rightly illustrated that point with the large number of issues that he dealt with and I am more than happy to pick up his challenge and deal with a number of the issues that he feels particularly sensitive about.One of the things that I wanted to discuss in the appropriation debate was the question of tariffs and protection, and I will come to that in just a moment. However, I must first pick up the challenge issued by the member for Lyons who accused the government of having done nothing for small business.Now that astonished me, and I am sure it astonished the member for Stirling (Mr Cameron) since we were both here in this very chamber this very morning when the question of capital gains rollover was put to the House—there was an indication of one of the things the government had done for small business. As someone who is involved in business, and someone directly disadvantaged by the governments decision to move to a capital gains tax, I welcome the opportunity for this rollover provision, which allows small business to expand without being penalised but which was not recognised by the member for Lyons at all.The member for Lyons has also challenged us to participate in this debate without rhetoric. That would mean that probably all of us would find ourselves pruned to about three minutes, with great respect. I will try to meet the challenge and not be any more disappointing than he was in that manner. I am well aware of the agony faced by rural communities as banks leave, as schools are closed and as hospitals are phased out. I am well aware of that because I represent a rural electorate. But I cannot stand in this chamber—I do not believe that state colleagues can stand in state chambers—and pretend that in the present atmosphere of supplying the health needs of rural communities the sorts of first‐rate health facilities, particularly in terms of the most modern forms of laser surgery and all the rest, can be available in every country town.One of the dilemmas that those of us who represent rural communities face is determining how it is that we keep a health facility that is adequate and meets the needs of the community and at the same time offer cost‐efficient modern surgical and laser techniques that have to be centrally based because they have to be used up to 20 hours a day in order to be cost efficient. I am conscious of that problem. So was the former government for 13 years, frankly. The member for Lyons suggests that the changes that have occurred have been characteristic of the last nine months—hardly a fair portrayal of what has been a run down of rural populations over some decades, and something that both sides of the House have endeavoured sincerely to address.One of the issues that I want to pick up—I apologise for not being here for the earlier remarks of the member for Lyons—was mentioned by the member for Greenway in his address in the debate on the appropriation bills. He was concerned about the fact that tariff reductions were causing job losses. The question of unemployment is a question addressed by the member for Lyons. It is a question that frustrates everybody in the federal parliament, and I suspect our state colleagues as well. It is a question that has very little to do with trade and trade policy and a great deal to do with technological change. The reality is that unemployment is a problem that all modern economies face simply because we have machines to do what people once used to do.I can address the question of unemployment for the member for Lyons; I could solve it for him tomorrow. I can solve it by saying to all my wine grape growers, of whom the member for Port Adelaide (Mr Sawford) would also be proud, `You will no longer pick your grapes with a machine; you will now go and pick them by hand. I could say to the member for Grey (Mr Wakelin), `You can cease harvesting your massive wheat crops with a self‐propelled harvester. You will now go back to bagging them. I would in the process create jobs all round Australia, and send those industries and the nation into bankruptcy, as you know. It is technological change that is in fact—

name: Mr ANDREW
content: —I am not interested, as the member for Port Adelaide knows, in who agrees or disagrees with me, and I do not care if, as characterised by a former member for Wakefield, I stand alone on this matter. The truth is that it was, in fact, a Labor administration under Gough Whitlam that pruned the first substantial 25 per cent out of the tariff reductions. It was the Hawke and Keating governments that subsequently put us onto an arrangement that saw tariffs falling progressively from as high as 57 to 60 per cent in the automotive industry down to 15 per cent now. The debate now is about what happens to the remainder.I know this and I feel passionately about it because the industry with which I have been most involved—the citrus industry—itself enjoyed tariff protection of something like 45 per cent which was phased down to five per cent—not by the present government but by the former government. Let Australia be aware: this is not an issue that we have initiated. But let us be fair as well as aware. This is an issue that we, in opposition, were supportive of. It is time that the now opposition paused and asked itself what it was like to be in opposition from 1983 until 1996 in the face of these tariff changes and to say that the then government was doing the right thing.

name: Mr ANDREW
content: —The member for Port Adelaide needs to be well aware of the fact that representing as I did the largest citrus growing electorate in Australia, I was in fact sorely tempted to make the same sort of cheap remarks as we have had from the present opposition while I was in opposition and the then government was driving a transitionary tariff change. But I did not. And to the great credit of all members of the then opposition, neither did they, because they knew that tariff reductions were in the long‐term best interests of the nation. They are damnably uncomfortable—particularly uncomfortable for suburban Adelaide, particularly uncomfortable for the riverland part of South Australia—but inevitable if we are to remain a world trading force.We should be commended for our support of your government while we were in opposition. The hypocrisy leaves me open‐mouthed that allows the current Leader of the Opposition to stand up and say, `We are going to change our approach to tariffs, because the truth is that, had we left all of those tariffs in place, Australia would have been a temporarily more comfortable place to be and substantially further in debt.

name: Mr ANDREW
content: —The point remains simply that Australian primary industries will survive regardless of what we do to tariff walls. Australian primary industries will survive principally because they are efficient by world standards. Every one of my wheat growers, every one of my wool growers and all of my major producers know that, effectively, tariffs raise their cost of production.That is the problem with tariffs. Every time you oblige an Australian to pay more for their utility, their boots, their shirts or anything else, you increase the cost of production in Australia. It is grossly unfair for us to say to farmers across Australia, `You can pay more for your utility; you can pay more for your header or whatever else, because we dont have a tariff on it. You can pay more for your boots and shirts and so can your shearers and transport operators, but then you will sell your product offshore into markets that do not have that sort of production. Every time you put a tariff in place, you increase the cost of production.Let me illustrate it this way, and I am actually indebted to the member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) for this illustration. He said that he was challenged—not surprisingly, given the recent debate—in Geelong by a friend who said, `Mr McArthur, explain to me very simply what a tariff does. Mr McArthur said what he said to him was, `A tariff is just like me saying to the plasterer in a country town We wont allow anybody else to come into the town and do any plastering unless their costs are raised by 20 per cent. If you are the local plasterer that is good news. But, over time, if every one else in the town wants a plastering job done the local plasterer does not have to be as efficient and the costs go up. That is the reason that tariffs always force up the cost of production.I am here representing the citrus industry, an industry which is directly threatened by the reality of Brazilian frozen orange juice concentrate floating into Australia at costs that Australian citrus growers cannot compete with. So what am I saying? Am I saying to the citrus industry, `You have no future. Sorry, pack up and go home. We will buy all our oranges from Brazil? Of course not. And let me remind the member for Port Adelaide that I am not saying that to the car industry either. What I am saying to the citrus industry is that it is madness for us as South Australians—A division having been called in the House of Representatives—Sitting suspended from 12.40 to 12.55 p.m.N/A

name: Mr ANDREW
content: —As I was saying prior to the interruption, it is too easy to misrepresent what those who are taking an anti‐tariff stance in Australia are about. It is too easy to misrepresent it simply because the superficial view must always be that to have a tariff in place makes life easier in Australia. The tragedy is that every tariff means that the cost of production goes up in Australia and Australia becomes less competitive on the world scene.The member for Lyons made so much of regional unemployment. The only way in which we can really solve the problem of unemployment in the regions, or in the urban areas, is obviously to have people employed in world competitive industries. We do that not by increasing tariffs but by ensuring that we are doing what we do better than the rest of the world. Do you want an illustration? Take a look at my state of South Australia where the wine industry is currently an export leader without any tariff protection at all. Why is it an export leader? It may not be the best illustration of a labour intensive industry, but it certainly is relatively labour intensive and it is a value added industry. Effectively, here we have a business in which the value‐adding is occurring in Australia and yet exports are opening up every day. It is an illustration of the fact that industries can be cultivated in Australia without specifically having tariff walls in place.I do not want to delay the chamber, but I do want to make the point that the World Trade Organisation obligations that the previous government entered into—obligations endorsed by this government—should not be questioned by members of the previous government now that they are in opposition. Those obligations, while they have brought with them a good deal of discomfort for some industries, have also given Australia enormous market access that would otherwise have been denied it. It is too easy to paint a picture of Australia as being the only country that adheres to the WTO guidelines. The facts are that every signatory to the WTO agreement is obliged to lower their tariffs and increase their market access.

name: Mr ANDREW
content: —The member for Port Adelaide is very anxious to enter into this debate and I hope he is listed on the speakers list a little later. He asks whether they are doing it. The facts remain that, for the first time in his life and mine, we sit around a common table with a common objective. I am not so gullible as to suggest that there will ever be such a thing as a level playing field. I know that world trade will always be a dirty game, but for the first time in our lifetimes everyone has a similar objective. Sure, the others have not adhered to the objective as closely as we have but I wish then that the member for Port Adelaide had been more outspoken in government about the adherence we presumed they were applying to the world trade objectives.Right now in 1997, with all that is wrong with world trade, what is distinctly and quantifiably true is this: the level playing field, myth though it is, is leveller—and I realise that as a school teacher you may question whether that is an appropriate term to be using—but it is leveller than it was in 1987 and leveller than it was in 1977. So some of the right things are happening. They are not happening fast enough, I agree, but to reverse what we have achieved would be a tragedy.Lest my remarks be misunderstood, Mr Deputy Speaker, let me add this, speaking as a South Australian: I am not saying that the car industry should be at 25 per cent, 15 per cent or five per cent. Frankly, I do not have all the information I need to make an informed decision about that. What I do know is that the Ford Falcon I drive in 1997 is a lot better car, in every sense of the word, than the Ford Falcon I might have driven in 1987 or in 1977.As those tariffs have come down, the standard of the Australian car industry has gone up and, astonishingly, to the great credit of the industry, it has an export focus that it never had before. That is not me saying, `The more you cut tariffs, the better the industry will be. But it is me saying, `It is in the national interest, and it is in the interests of every Australian, if we are to be export competitive, for us to be prepared to prune our tariff walls and to do all that we can to encourage industry efficiency. I want a car industry that is lean and mean and in Australia. I trust the member for Port Adelaide also wants that.Sitting suspended from 1.01 to 4.30 p.m.N/A

name: Mr MUTCH
content: —I refer to Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and in particular to appropriations under division 361 on the Immigration Review Tribunal. I would like to place on the public record a plea for clemency on behalf of my de facto constituents, Mr Charles and Mrs Doris Gibson. Recently, Mr and Mrs Gibson, who are aged 81 and 80 respectively, came to see me and told me an amazing story. Some 16 years ago they came to Australia on a visitors visa. Originally from the UK, they fell in love with this country and its people and decided to extend their stay. One thing led to another and, to cut a long story short, they are still here. In the meantime, they established a small business called `The Pet Shop in Caringbah, which has been quite successful, and recently they entered into a further three‐year lease on the premises.Mr and Mrs Gibson are the most unlikely pair of fugitives you could ever imagine. These illegal aliens have, indeed, become part of the furniture of Caringbah. I have been inundated with letters from friends and business associates who can vouch for their character, their consideration for others and their willingness to work at a senior age to support themselves. In every respect, under other circumstances they would be applauded as wonderful immigrants. The laws of Australia with respect to illegal immigrants are strict. I have been advised that the Gibsons are in a catch‐22 situation. The Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) has power to intervene only after a current application for residency or citizenship has been refused and reviewed. Unfortunately, because the Gibsons let their visas expire for longer than 12 months, it is difficult for us to find a way for them to be eligible to apply for consideration. However, I have written to the minister in an attempt to explore every option.In 1983‐84 there was an amnesty. The Gibsons might have applied at this time, but they did not. The Gibsons adviser is exploring avenues under the Migration Act 1958 and, for the moment, I am advised that their bridging visa is to be extended for another month. It is my hope that a way can be found to extend clemency to these old battlers. Surely we are big enough, generous enough and forgiving enough to find a way. They have been at home with us for too long to throw them out now.I now turn to the appropriation bills and, in particular, to appropriations under the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and Airservices Australia. In speaking to these appropriations, I think it very appropriate that I lament the lack of appropriations given to the people of Kurnell as recompense for the amount of aircraft noise they have been expected to endure since the opening of the third runway. I have written to my colleague the honourable member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) in his capacity as Chairman of the Sydney Airport Community Forum, and also to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp), following the release of the long‐term operating plan for Sydney airport, in order to raise with them the compelling case for recognising the unique exposure of Kurnell residents to aircraft noise, and to ask for special consideration for the Kurnell village.It should be noted that the Airservices Australia report contains recommendations only. However, it seems that all possibilities raised or canvassed for flight path modes of operation see the residents of Kurnell affected. Indeed, in the preferred mode of operation advanced by Airservices Australia, the residents of Kurnell will experience a minimum of 55 per cent of all non‐curfew flights. Kurnell residents already experience curfew flights and will be expected to continue to bear this burden. In this respect, Kurnell residents are in the unique position of being potentially exposed to aircraft noise at any time in a 24‐hour period.I refer to the Airservices report and, in particular, to recommendation 4. That states quite categorically that they advise that we should give preference to over the water operations—that is, mode 4—to minimise residential overflights. It is also stated that we should interchange use of the other modes to ensure a fair sharing of unavoidable aircraft noise subject to weather and traffic demands—a fair sharing. However, they say that at any time that weather conditions permit—thank heaven for the weather—and traffic levels can be sustained, mode 4 or runway 16L departures/runway 34L arrivals will be the nominated runway.It seems that the Kurnell residents will be subject to noise. They will be the preferred people to be subject to this noise if this report is adopted. Therefore I think that they do deserve special consideration. Despite the fact that Kurnell residents have been expected to bear this noise since the opening of the third runway, it seems that they have endured this very much with stoicism. However, enough is enough and it is time that the legitimate claims of the Kurnell community for special consideration are met.The unique and special claims of the village of Kurnell are only too apparent. The acceptance of its unique position is evidenced by the establishment of a committee purely to examine in detail the plight of Kurnell residents. In the past Kurnell has received no compensation apart from the insulation of Kurnell public school. This injustice has occurred because the official Australian noise exposure forecast contour maps preclude Kurnell from the compensation regime. Indeed, in the Airservices report it is noted that the Sutherland Shire Council said the Kurnell peninsula had been particularly heavily impacted by the third runway, which placed the centre line directly over the village.The council submitted that residents who lived west of Dampier Street, Kurnell, have borne the brunt of night time aircraft noise for many years, particularly from small aircraft, and that the provision of insulation should be considered for their sleeping areas to alleviate the disturbance created. The Kurnell situation clearly sets it apart from other claims for consideration. Apart from the unique impact of aircraft noise, Kurnell is an isolated community with one road access, sharing the peninsula with a major refinery. The re‐installation of the public wharf at Kurnell with an embarkation point at La Perouse is essential to provide alternative egress and access. In view of the looming Sydney Olympics and Kurnells status as the meeting place between Captain Cook and indigenous Australians, the potential for a ferry route across the heads is enormous.The special circumstances of Kurnell demand access to funds established from the noise tax. As the land values of Kurnell have dropped substantially following the opening of the third runway an ongoing program of community enhancement measures should be pursued to examine ways of improving land values and quality of life in Kurnell. There are a number of other things that could be done to enhance the community of Kurnell and I think that access should be provided to the noise fund to look at ways of improving this amenity to improve the quality of life of these people who have borne the brunt of this noise. We need to carefully consider the option of funding low interest relocation loans from the noise fund for those who cannot cope. I would like it to be properly examined.Finally, it is imperative that we conduct a study into the effects of airport associated pollution on this community, which is adjacent to the airport but for water. It is said that water acts more as a conduit than a barrier in those circumstances and I believe that such a study is warranted. Another matter that has been of considerable interest to me is the proposal for aircraft departing to the south to turn east out to sea over Bait Bay after passing to the west of the Kurnell village. I have been pushing for the consideration of this out to sea proposal ever since I was elected on 2 March last year. It has been the subject of numerous letters to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. Indeed, at times I think the ministers staff see me more in the line of a vexatious letter writer.I have also raised this matter with the Sydney Airport Community Forum, Airservices Australia and the Civil Aviation Safety Authority. At the public meeting held at the Cronulla Sutherland Leagues Club, I demanded and received an assurance that this matter would be included in the report to the minister, and this has happened. On page 54 of the report, Airservices Australia states:Consideration is being given to amending the flight path which is aligned, over water, just to the east of Cronulla.The Airservices Australia report then makes a proposal relating to this, and states:This proposal requires testing in aircraft simulators to assess the additional cockpit workload generated by requiring jet aircraft to execute a series of turns in quick succession, shortly after take‐off.The report goes on:Further assessment of these options is required to confirm the noise benefits perceived.Some time earlier—A division having been called in the House of Representatives—Sitting suspended from 4.41 to 4.55 p.m.N/A
