name: Mr MUTCH
content: —Before the suspension, I was referring to the out to sea proposal, which I have been fighting for assiduously for the people of Cronulla. On 4 July, the minister wrote to me in response to one of many representations I have made on behalf of constituents. He wrote:You will recall that the original proposal which was rejected involved aircraft making a 3 degree turn away from the coast, from the 163 degree to the 160 degree radial. CASA has now suggested a new option which increases the turn away from the coast from 3 degrees to 13 degrees (ie a turn from the 163 degree to the 150 degree radial).This turn would take aircraft approximately 3 kilometres further off the coast at Bundeena than is currently the case on the 163 degree radial. I am advised that this new proposal would lead to noticeable reductions in noise levels at both Cronulla and Bundeena.I would appreciate receiving your views on this new proposal.N/AOf course, my considered response to that was: Yes! Yes! Yes! We are still waiting for the out to sea proposal to be implemented. Although I would have liked earlier progress on this issue it was not, I was advised, possible to pre‐empt the deliberations of the task force.If the recommendations of the task force are accepted by the minister and, in particular, the rejection—touch wood—of mode 2, then there is no reason why the simulated testings required cannot proceed post haste. Although this is not soon enough for some, including myself, the progress made thus far is in the right direction.One of the positive aspects of the task force report is the rejection of mode 2. That mode would have seen jet and non‐jet departures cutting through the heart of my electorate and all landings on 34R directly over the Kurnell village. In the words of Airservices Australia:This would place aircraft very close to or over Cronulla and would negate any initiatives discussed above to move aircraft further to sea off Cronulla.They also say:It is not proposed that this mode be included in the plan due to the unique airspace arrangements that would need to be employed and to limit the number of runway modes to limit complexity of the airways system to maintain a safe operating regime.On an ominous note, they go on to say:However, this Mode could be the subject of further consideration if the noise sharing objectives of the plan cannot be achieved with the proposed modes. The need for this mode would be obviated if Mode 4 can be optimised to achieve similar traffic capacity.I read that very much as a rejection of that mode—and I hope and pray that is adhered to—because it would be a total disaster for the people of my electorate.A further matter that concerns me is the comment on page 46 of the Airservices Australia report. That says:The proposed operational modes for Sydney Airport will at least be valid until the second airport is ready, which will not be before the early years of the next century. When the second airport is ready it will be necessary to review the airspace management arrangements for the Sydney region and this may lead to changes to the flight paths for Sydney airport.Preliminary work on the airspace management arrangements for the second airport is being undertaken for the EIS by the Department of Transport and Regional Development, in conjunction with Airservices Australia.It seems to me that we need a second major airport to service the Sydney basin. Not least among my concerns is the increased use of Sydney airport and the additional pressure that this will place on surrounding suburbs. This does not mean that the hourly cap will not be able to be maintained, because additional aircraft may be accommodated by a pre‐arranged slot system.Nevertheless, without a second airport there will be greater pressure on KSA. I am concerned, however, that the Holsworthy options, particularly the northern Holsworthy option, are just too close to KSA. We have gone through considerable anguish already in trying to come to grips with modes of operation for KSA. When these are finally determined, I think it would be a shame to have to go through the process all over again, if that is indeed what the Holsworthy option would necessitate.I wanted to raise these matters today in speaking to this bill because they are of considerable interest to many of my constituents. Of course, the people of Kurnell, who have borne the brunt of aircraft noise and under this report would be expected to continue to bear the brunt of aircraft noise, need and deserve some consideration. It is interesting that if you look at runway movements in the past, also reported in the report, the modes that are nominated as being the actuals very much include the Kurnell Village. Mode 10, for instance, accounted for 65 per cent of actuals in 1995. That involves departure jet tracks around Kurnell Village. If you look at mode 9, that involves arrivals over the Kurnell Village.There has been a lot of criticism of Airservices Australia. I have not been indiscriminate in my criticism. I think that it has been a very difficult task to come up with the report they have come up with. In some instances I can see that they have tried to consider the individual case of Kurnell residents. For instance, if you look at mode 9 arrivals on 34 left and 34 right, you will note that the jets, instead of coming in on the third runway, are tracked to come in on the second runway. I think this has been done as a deliberate attempt to show some consideration for the sensitivities of the people of Kurnell. I know that the representative of the Kurnell community, the Kurnell Flight Path Action Committee, Kevin Hill, who is also my nominee on the community consultative forum, is working very closely with Airservices Australia to try to achieve the best result for the people of Kurnell.But that is around the edges. What we need is particular consideration for those people, and I think they deserve access to the noise fund that has been established for the very purpose of looking after people who are expected to bear more than their fair share of aircraft noise, and that certainly applies to the people of Kurnell. So I put it to the parliament and to the minister: it is about time the people of Kurnell received the consideration that they deserve, and I commend that to the House.

name: Mr WAKELIN
content: —Speaking on Appropriation Bill (No. 3), it is a pleasure to rise and make a few general comments. I guess over the last 12 months it has been a very active parliamentary year. The government inherited some well documented facts of life when it first came to office. I will mention basics: $100 billion of Commonwealth debt, with just under $10 billion of interest. Faced with that dilemma, as well as the $8 billion deficit, the efforts that have been made by the government are highly commendable. The budget of August last year focused on a whole range of issues. If I were to name three things, they would be a better balance in our overall economy, a stronger investment climate and a focus on stronger wealth creation, leading to attacking the whole issue of unemployment.The other subsidiary issues, if you like, are those issues like native title, tariffs, the funding of the ABC, and smaller issues like the earning credit scheme, education in regional areas, investment, telecommunications and the general direction of the government. These are some of the things that I will address in the time allocated today.The issue of native title, particularly with the Wik judgment is, I think, much underrated by too many Australians. It impacts on an electorate like Grey in a way that most urban Australians could not contemplate. For example, I have had a number of representations from people wanting to explore a small gems field and who can no longer do it. Things that people have been taking for granted for 100 years or more are now restricted, or just stopped. People are at a total loss to understand why.There are bigger implications. We have a hope of some expansion at Woomera with the use of the rocket range there. Yet, there is that doubt arising from native title. I hope that can be resolved before a decision has to be made within the next few weeks. In my electorate of Grey, which is 92 per cent of the area of South Australia and about 900,000 square kilometres, more of it is actually under native title claim than actually exists. People are bewildered about what it means. It is an issue that the Prime Minister and the parliamentary secretary Senator Minchin and many others have been attempting to wrestle with in these recent months.I believe that if native claims were put over the central business districts of Canberra, Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Adelaide, Hobart, and Perth, there would be a stronger national will to come to an arrangement which would recognise prior occupation in a much more expeditious manner. The fact that terra nullius has been pushed out into the regions and that the majority of Australians are able to escape the impact of native title—remembering that the tribunal has not yet had one successful resolution on mainland Australia—I think highlights the fact that there is subtle constant pressure on regional people which urban people do not appreciate.The next issue that I would like to touch on is the issue of tariffs. There is a very good little document called One shoe per person , which takes its name from the fact that we could, apparently, up until recent decades, import only one shoe per year per person. From the introduction of this very well written piece by David Pearce and Andrew Stoeckel I will quote the first paragraph which I think sums up the Australian context over a longer period of some decades. It says:Australias policy on protection for the manufacturing industry has had a long history of debate. It is undergoing another debate right now as a result of two things. One is the uncertain legality of some subsidies Australia uses to protect industry, which has been `solved by negotiation—the so‐called Howe Leather case. The other is the change of government in March this year. While the stated policy of the new government has been supportive of free trade, the media headlines have carried stories of finding alternative ways to compensate industry for the removal of subsidies and the need for `reciprocity—that we should not liberalise further unless our trade partners do. The charge has also been put that the benefits of free trade have not been fully explained to the wider community.The car and textiles, clothing and footwear industries are the most highly protected manufacturing industries in Australia and the current protection arrangements apply to the year 2000. What happens beyond that is up for review by the government.We go now to the 1981 issue of one shoe per person. At the same time we were limited to one imported car for every 190 people. Clearly, these limits were put there to offer protection to the manufacturer, although even in those days there were people questioning that policy.If we look at the export subsidy debate, and that includes Australias export facilitation, we have imports of something like $12 billion. Consumers then pay about $13.8 billion. The government tariff revenue is about $1.5 billion. The producer, that is, the exporter, has exports of $2.8 billion, which means an export subsidy of about $0.3 billion. Those old arguments on agriculture back in the 1970s are well gone and there is negligible subsidy for agriculture now. However, those debates of the 1970s are still very much there for our manufacturing industry in the 1990s.The real tragedy of this whole tariff debate is summed up in the epilogue by Pearce and Stoeckel where they say:Sadly, the benefits that the protected industries receive do not translate into more employment in those industries. The experiment of lifting protection in order to save jobs in those industries has been tried and the facts show that it has failed.That is the debate that we still have decades on.I do not pretend that it is ever easy to reduce tariffs or even to hold the line with tariffs when you have a very competitive world market. But those fundamental truths that are in this document prepared by the Centre for International Economics are still as true today as they were 30 years ago when people like Bert Kelly were advising us of the wrong-headedness of excess protection. I think that the government and the parliament will need to show great consideration in the interests of the overall community because we know at the end of the day that a tariff, by any other name, is a subsidy and a tax.I want to move on to another issue, the issue of local government and the financial assistance grants. In the budget there was a four per cent increase that brought the amount to about $1.2 billion. About 77 per cent of that went to regional and rural Australia, which meant about a $35 million increase in financial assistance grants to rural and regional councils.The point I want to highlight here is that there has been some criticism of the Commonwealth government for the withdrawal of REDOs, the Regional Economic Development Organisations. These organisations were funded by the previous government for only four years and then they were expected to go on their own way and be funded from within their own resources. There was a sum of $150 million over four years of which about 50 per cent was to go in administration and 50 per cent to projects.If you do your sums, you will find that the increase in the financial assistance grants to regional and rural councils is at least as much as what was being received in REDOs, which many councils felt were simply duplicating the role of organisations like local government and state based regional development organisations. So, in one stroke, the new government has been able to reduce duplication and offer more money to local government for specific purposes in their own local government areas.I have a university in the electorate at Whyalla. There has been some speculation which appears to be somewhat politically based. The percentages used in the debate on universities are somewhat specious when you realise there has been a five per cent cut over three years. The percentages being quoted are usually in excess of 10, 15 and 20 per cent. It might make good headlines but it does not actually fit the argument.The one comment that I would make on the universities is that there is about a 75 per cent taxpayer subsidy to university education. If you look at training, apprenticeships et cetera across the nation I doubt whether there is that sort of support and subsidy to the balance of those people seeking to get training to get into employment. I would say to the university that it is always regrettable that budgets need to be cut but I would also ask them to consider their fellow countrymen and their access to training and well paid employment. It is accepted that if you have a university degree you will go on and expect to do somewhat better in life than those of us who do not have that same privilege.I will touch on the ABC and the funding cuts. I would simply say to those in the ABC that they are part of a $700 million organisation of which $500 million is provided by the taxpayer. The one fundamental difference—although they may not agree with it—between them as paid employees of the ABC, not all of them but many of them, and me as an elected member is that I have a constitutional responsibility based on our democratic system. They are simply accountable to their employer. I would say to any person in the media—I have said it about our main chamber—that if there was a design fault it is that the media sit above us and not on the same terms as us and at the same level. I do say quite sincerely that we are constitutionally elected, we have the responsibility of government under a democracy and I would ask them always to remember that.One small issue that has been troubling some of my constituents is the earning credits scheme. In our great thrust for efficiency, this earning credits scheme was abolished in the August budget and perhaps for good reason. If you are on casual work regularly for 48 or whatever weeks of the year then that might be okay, but in my electorate where the only work available will be casual seasonal work it would appear to me that these people are unnecessarily disadvantaged.Finally, the good news in the electorate of Grey has been undoubtedly the remarkable investment by Western Mining in the Olympic Dam project. They announced it last June, $1¼ billion, and said `We will get going about June 1997. In actual fact, they are already going and they have put another $250 million on the table, so the investment is up to $1.5 billion and it is talking about 1,600 people being on site in future months.It is a great opportunity for my electorate, which has had too much bad news over many years. The opportunities that it presents to the region at large are very much to the forefront of peoples mind in a very positive sense. I understand that we might even have some better news towards the end of the week on other investment matters.Another good news story is the governments telecommunications infrastructure fund—$250 million throughout Australia and $26.5 million to South Australia. The electorate of Grey can expect to pick up a lot of that. The issue of mobile phones has always been contentious. Telstra has sadly fled to the cities to compete with Optus and others for the digital market and has overlooked many of my constituents. We hope that the new regime starting in July will give greater opportunities. We know that the $5 million per year over the next five years will provide opportunities for investment which will provide fairer access to telecommunications in the electorate of Grey.About a fortnight or three weeks ago a number of my constituents were badly affected by floods. They were 100‐year type floods. I am sure we all feel for them. They are still recovering. Something like 1,000 kilometres of fences went down and 500 kilometres of that was totally destroyed. Houses were inundated. In one instance, a helicopter crashed, but fortunately there was no loss of life. There is a lot of pressure on those people in this recovery period, and we offer our sympathy to them.I wish to acknowledge the state governments role in the Premiers announcement in the last week of the bringing forward of the natural disaster fund. Those people are very stoical and quite self‐reliant; nevertheless I am sure they will appreciate any support that the government is able to offer.

name: Mr TONY SMITH
content: —I want to touch on five matters in my speech on the appropriation bills. The matters are: first, the Americanisation of Australian culture; second, the legal aid system; third, the divide between the rich and the poor and the haves and the have‐nots; fourth, foreign policy; and, fifth, Aboriginal matters. I may not have the time, but I will attempt to touch on all of them.I raised the issue of Americanisation in my maiden speech. I am afraid that after a year the situation is not getting any better—if anything, it is getting worse. I believe the government has a role to play in reversing this trend.This problem starts in the schools. In my electorate there is very strong nationalism in primary schools. There are flag raising ceremonies and we will soon be celebrating Anzac Day and in the schools at the primary level children have a great commitment to the enduring symbols of our country.Unfortunately, as they move into the high schools they move further away from those concepts and they stray further away from what I believe are unique and essential elements in our culture. I fear that we are losing them. I direct my attention particularly to sport and, in particular, to cricket and rugby league.I have been involved in cricket as a player and spectator for 36 years. An ugliness began creeping into cricket with the Packer circus in 1977. Unfortunately, that ugliness has reached a stage where the Australian captain is saying that sledging is part of the game. I totally and utterly reject that notion.During the course of observing cricket matches in my electorate—and I am quite keen on such teams as the Pine Rivers cricket sides and the Lawnton Taverners—I have stressed wherever I have gone that sledging is not part of the game. In fact, I would use the old phrase, `It is simply not cricket. We must get back to that. The phrase seems to have slipped out of our culture because of the influx of commercialism.We have seen in people who have played sports such as tennis—John McEnroe, for example—the quintessential ugly sportsman who is there abusing and criticising every decision of the umpire. That is simply not on. As I said, I think it is deplorable to have that as part of our Australian macho style. It is not part of being Australian. I fear it is being combined with the commercialism that we are seeing in both cricket and rugby league and that, generally speaking, this show biz, this yankee style, is seen as the best way of looking at things.For example, I was at the Gabba late last year watching a day‐night game and I wondered what all these black boxes were around the ground. To my horror, I soon found that the cacophony of noise that was booming out of them, assaulting my ears, was little bits of theme music being played in between overs—extolling the theme songs of various players and so forth. To me, it was ruining the game as a spectacle. In other words, I felt I had to leave because I was being assaulted with these Americanisation symbols: that we have to have this show biz, this razzamatazz and this sort of cacophony being a part of our culture. Well, it simply is not, but it has crept into it. It is a very unfortunate part of cricket, along with the inane comments of the commentator. Once upon a time you could watch cricket; you could discuss it; and you could talk about the various scientific aspects of it. But now you cannot even hear yourself in between overs with the noise coming out of these black boxes, which I initially thought might have been some sort of black picket fence but, to my horror, they were not.As far as rugby league is concerned, probably one of the greatest commentators in rugby league was George Lovejoy and he coined the phrase `the greatest game of all. Likewise, having seen a little bit of the ugly super league spectacle, we are now seeing everything other than rugby league. What is wrong? Why do we have this cultural cringing towards America? Why do we say `broncos instead of `brumbies? The term `brumbies is Australian. Why do we say `cowboys instead of `farmers? There is something wrong with our view of ourselves if we have to pull in these American symbols. It is a great pity.
debateinfo: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1996‐97 Cognate bills: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1996‐97 APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1996‐97
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr Dondas
content: —They are brumbies in the Northern Territory.
debateinfo: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1996‐97 Cognate bills: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1996‐97 APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1996‐97
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr TONY SMITH
content: —They might be in the Northern Territory, and I wish they were in Brisbane. Anyway, I think the government does play a role in this. The government should take the lead in holding up our symbols and in supporting the traditional way of looking at the game.I now turn to the issue of legal aid. In my electorate of Dickson, over the years a great number of people have needed to access the legal system. Unfortunately, the fact is that legal aid has, over a number of years, particularly in the last decade, turned into almost a crisis. You see, as I did in my legal practice, numerous cases that cry out for attention but do not get it. There was an old saying that justice delayed was justice denied. What then is the concomitant of justice denied? That is what is happening now.The Law Council of Australia has estimated that the restoration of legal aid funding to the 1988 level would take an annual commitment of $55 million. The August budget announcement that legal aid funding would be reduced by $33.2 million a year for the next three years, in effect, signals the death knell of the current system, which had become unviable in any event.Under the current legal aid agreements, the states and territories are subsidised by the Commonwealth which provides 55 per cent of overall government funding. The 45 per cent provided by the states and territories includes the statutory interest on client funds held in solicitors trust accounts so that, in real terms, only 36 per cent comes from the funds of the states and territories. Further, a disproportionate amount of funds has been used on state and territory matters at the expense of Commonwealth matters. The Attorney‐General recently stated:The impact of this diversion of Commonwealth funds is severe. For example, data provided by legal aid commissions shows a drop of over 25 per cent in the number of grants for assistance and expenditure on family law matters by commissions over the five‐year period from 1991 to 1996.States and territories have traditionally shown a reluctance to pull their weight, so the erosion of legal aid facilities is set to continue. In Queensland, the legal aid office has been distributing letters to participating solicitors to the effect that funding from 1 July 1997 cannot be guaranteed, notwithstanding that a matter may still be current at that time.While the present system favours matters within the jurisdiction of the states and territories, the discrimination does not end there. There is also a definite bias against matters which, though meritorious, are considered by the various legal aid offices to be difficult. The classic example is the medical negligence claim. As a result, many deserving applicants fall through the safety net and thus are unable to pursue their claims unless their legal representatives are prepared to act for them on a speculative basis. In effect, the way the legal aid system is going, only criminals will get legal aid.A lawyers decision to conduct an action on a speculative basis raises two very important questions. Firstly, is it champertous? Champerty describes a proceeding which is conducted by a person who has no legitimate concern in the suit and who bargains to carry on its prosecution in consideration of receiving, in the event of success, a share in the matter of the suit. It is prohibited at common law. This is an issue which has largely been ignored by practitioners at their peril.Secondly, during the conduct of the action, will a situation arise where the duty of a lawyer to the client conflicts with the lawyers personal interest in receiving payment for the professional fees that have been generated to date? Many settlements are reached at the door of the court after years of delay. Legal representatives by that stage have made enormous investments in terms of fees and out‐of‐pocket expenses. An ordinary offer of settlement may suddenly appear very attractive—the chance of getting paid for years of work, as opposed to the uncertainty of trial followed by months of waiting for the judgment, taxation of costs and, finally, payment.It is manifestly unreasonable to expect lawyers to assume responsibility for conducting speculative actions on behalf of those people who are unable to access legal aid facilities, particularly when one considers the ethical dilemmas involved. There is an alternative. An organisation independent of the legal aid system could be established with the primary objective of providing assistance, subject to the satisfaction of merit and means tests, to two categories of applicants, namely: those who have been unable to secure legal aid through the normal channels and those who have been unable to secure legal representation on a speculative basis. For ease of reference, I will refer to this organisation as Equity.Equity would be established by a one‐off injection of funds from federal, state and territory governments. A modest filing fee on all process filed throughout all jurisdictions could assist to replenish Equity. To provide an ongoing source of funding, a percentage of the fruits of all successful actions would be deducted and reinvested in Equity. Legal fees would be paid upon settlement or finalisation of an action, regardless of the outcome. Fees would be assessed on a solicitor and client basis. Normal taxation of costs provisions would apply. Professional access to Equity would be limited to solicitors and barristers who had been appointed to a panel of approved lawyers, the criteria for which would involve a consideration of such factors as years of practice and areas of expertise.The management and administrative structure of Equity would be minimised in keeping with a general policy of cost‐effectiveness. An applicant for assistance from Equity would be required to pass a merit test involving satisfaction of either of the following criteria: is the issue one of importance—for example, in the public interest—or of particular precedent value; or are there reasonable prospects of success? Decisions with respect to merit would, in the first instance, be made by case officers, with avenues for appeal to an honorary committee of suitably qualified individuals.In addition to satisfactory passage through the merit test, an applicant would also be required to pass a means test. Hardship would be the basic criterion. Neither of the ethical problems which currently confront legal representatives undertaking speculative work, that is, champerty and potential conflicts of duty and interest, would arise—and, believe me, I am aware of those conflicts; I have encountered them many times. Because legal representatives would be guaranteed payment regardless of the outcome of the proceedings, potential conflicts of duty and interest would be eliminated.A dispute resolution procedure could be established to cope with disputes which may arise from time to time between litigant and legal representative. At the outset, applicants would be advised that, upon acceptance of Equitys assistance, they would have a concomitant obligation to accept the reasonable advice of their legal representatives. This would be a particularly important issue in the context of settlement offers because of Equitys financial interest in the fruits of the action. In the event of a dispute between a litigant and his or her legal representative, the matter would be referred to an independent arbiter for resolution and determination.There are so many cases that are slipping through the net; there are so many people who do not bother to contest matters because they cannot get legal aid that justice is being totally denied. That is an untenable situation in the Australian community. This program that I have suggested is one means of addressing it. It will not solve it but it will assist to address it and take the weight off applications for legal aid generally.In relation to foreign policy, I stress part of what I said earlier about promoting the Australian image. In my view this falls very much to the Australian government. It is important in my view to advocate a much more proactive foreign policy as part of that process. Australia must be seen to be a significant power in the region. For years, previous Labor governments presided over an innocuous foreign policy—indeed, one that became almost fossilised. Would, for example, Papua New Guinea have sought assistance from mercenaries had Australia been a much more proactive country? Would not Papua New Guinea have come to seek Australias assistance in relation to this particular matter if we had promoted ourselves as the significant power in the region? This is what I am saying.Why do our troops travel to far-flung outposts of conflict, yet we tolerate an eight‐year war, just 15 flying minutes from our shores, in Bougainville? There is an incongruity there in our policy. I also think there is a terrible incongruity in relation to the China‐Taiwan situation. Why do we think big is best? Since the December 1972 communique, much has happened in the Republic of China on Taiwan. There are 21.5 million people living there; it has been a democracy since 1996. Why do we not practise a similar philosophy to Taiwan that we do in other countries? Why do we say that because Taiwan is small we are intimidated by big brother on the mainland? I cannot accept it as a person with my political philosophy and I think it is about time we moved ahead with the changes.But again, it goes back to our responsibility for promoting ourselves in our region, to be more dynamic and to indicate to all parties in our region where there are problems, including in Sri Lanka, that this country has something to say, has direction to give and assistance to provide.Turning to Aboriginal matters, I have always regarded the comment by my jurisprudence lecturer that metaphysics does not boil cabbages as a very significant statement in relation to life generally. I have always had a concern about the notion of reconciliation. I have always questioned it. The notion implies a division; so you start with a division between people. You manufacture a concept that we need to reconcile because there is a division. There are many Australians who do not think there is a division and who are offended by the concept. I think since the concept has been floated, in 1991, I have never seen more division in this country between black and white. That is a tragedy because—getting back to the point that metaphysics does not boil cabbages—we are not helping the people at the coal face by floating these concepts, in my respectful view.There is going to be a reconciliation conference in a couple of months. I have seen some enormously expensive and glossy material about this. Why on earth are we doing this when we will not achieve anything in terms of helping people on the ground, which is what we should be doing? Rather, it will be a feelgood talkfest where a lot of money will be spent flying people from all over the countryside. What will it achieve? I suspect little, if anything. When you ask yourself what is reconciliation—what do they define it as—you start seeing the holes in this particular proposal.For example, it is said that it provides five so‐called steps for reconciliation and, worryingly, it speaks of arriving at some sort of settlement. What form this might take is part of the charter of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. It proposes such things as national agreements or a series of agreements, whatever this really means. I am afraid it is the language of division which will promote even more division.For example, I do not think anybody really considered the words `indigenous and `non‐indigenous. Now we have indigenous Australians and non‐indigenous Australians. We are all Australians, yet we have this division since the reconciliation concept. I think it is absurd, and it promotes division. I have people saying to me, `Im indigenous. I was born here. Look up the dictionary meaning of the word: it means people who are born here. It is causing friction in the community, when we should be identifying the real needs of Aboriginal people. My work in the Aboriginal area, particularly at Cherbourg, identifies those needs, but these sorts of glossy concepts do not help.For example, one of the five elements says this about reconciliation: `Identifying what more needs to be done and making changes within Australian society. How will that promote a settlement of things? That could go on forever. So forever we have got this notion of reconciliation, forever we have got people looking sideways at each other over a non‐achievable goal. It is not going to help the people on the ground, or at the coalface. That is what it is all about—helping those people in health, housing, education and employment. Get those basic things right and we can do all the feel good things we like; but if we do the feel good things and do not solve the basic things, we are going to have problems. We see that all the time.Lastly, I am going to talk very briefly about the notion of haves and have‐nots. I think it is something that we have to be very careful of in this society, that we are developing a society where a large number of people are unemployed and on the other side of the coin we have people who are doing very well from the system. I had a very interesting letter sent to me by Bishop Wicks recently about this concept, how we are promoting this situation where there are a large group of unemployed who are very much at the margins, but on the other side of the coin people who are very well off. I do not think that that situation can continue without our suffering as a nation, and suffering very much in the eyes of the international community.We have to try and devise programs of capital works that will get people into jobs. We have to ensure that we bear in mind that people who are unemployed and have been for some time are not forgotten. The Labor Party and particularly the union movement have never been interested in the unemployed. I have found from my experience that they are only interested in union dues. We have got to change it.
debateinfo: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1996‐97 Cognate bills: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1996‐97 APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1996‐97
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr DONDAS
content: —I rise to support Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4). These bills are to appropriate funds to increase spending on defence, medical and pharmaceutical services for veterans, residential facilities for older people, higher costs associated with child‐care rebates and debt repayments to the Australian National Railway Commission. There are minor variations included in Appropriation Bill (No. 3) for variations across a range of programs in various government departments.In terms of the budget itself, it was described as a strong but fair budget, in view of the fact that it was at this time last year, after the coalition was successful at the 2 March election, that it became known that, instead of having a surplus of funds, we were looking at a deficit; in fact, an $8 billion black hole deficit.In the last 12 months I believe the coalition has been able to drive our economy in the right direction. When one looks at interest rates, the average home mortgage payer is now $246 per month better off under the coalition governments direction. In terms of a small business variable loan, the small business person would be $4,000 a year better off. In fact, the Treasurer said the other day in the parliament that the variable loan rates were the lowest since 1974 and, when one considers the no frill rates, at their lowest since the 1960s. Also, there has been a billion dollar a year family tax cut, and something like 70 per cent of the Australian families should benefit from that tax cut.In talking about defence, I am very pleased to see that the coalition government continues to support defence infrastructure and facilities within my electorate in the Northern Territory. When one does an analysis, so far the indications are that some $97 million is going to be spent on capital works in the Northern Territory and an additional $100 million on administration. That is almost $2 million a week on administration, which obviously would pick up payrolls, salaries and incidental expenses. That $2 million going into the Darwin economy is very important. Part of the $97 million is the upgrade of RAAF Base Darwin, and I understand that some $59.5 million will be spent on RAAF Base Darwin over the next couple of years. An additional $31.4 million has been allocated for RAAF Tindal—A division having been called in the House of Representatives—Sitting suspended from 5.46 to 6.03 p.m.N/A
debateinfo: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1996‐97 Cognate bills: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1996‐97 APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1996‐97
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr DONDAS
content: —Before the suspension, I was saying that I was very pleased that the parliamentary public works committee recommended the $59.5 million upgrade to RAAF Base Darwin. Also for further consideration is another $31.4 million for capital works for RAAF Base Tindal. The Larrakeyah Coonawarra facility is earmarked to have further extensions done into the harbour and they are estimated at anywhere between $25 million and $30 million, with work commencing later this year.Another very interesting facet to the Defence portfolio is Pine Gap. We do not hear very much about Pine Gap in a general sense in the portfolio because it is an American installation. But additional housing is being provided for the Pine Gap facility in Alice Springs and that work is under way. About 160 extra homes are being built in Alice Springs to cater for families. When that infrastructure is complete and people are living in those homes, that is going to be a boon to the economy of the Alice Springs region.Bradshaw Station is another property that is earmarked for development by the Defence Department for a training centre. Bradshaw Station is in the northern part of the Northern Territory, not very far from the Western Australian border and near a place called Timber Creek. Once that facility has been completed, at a cost of about $50 million, it will provide full tropical training facilities for our armed forces. There has been quite a lot of money spent on Robertson Barracks in the last few years. That is certainly looking good and I understand that there will be some minor capital works available in the 1997‐98 budget for Robertson Barracks.On another topic, the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Dr Kemp) has announced that he is providing additional funds to the Australian community for funding for literacy and numeracy programs. I am very pleased that, in that allocation, he has given the Northern Territory an additional $12 million for the years 1997 to 2000. That is very important, because levels of funding should be maintained and increased if we are going to be true in our nature in trying to provide a higher level of education for our indigenous community.The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Amanda Vanstone, provided in the 1996‐97 budget additional funds for indigenous education. In fact, there was an indigenous education supplementary bill which provided financial resources to those communities in remote areas of Australia. The Northern Territory, in some instances, was able to receive additional funding from that earlier budget.We must take into consideration the high cost of education in remote areas. It is a fact of life. Darwin, obviously, is not considered to be a remote area but, nevertheless, Alice Springs is, and so are the other territory centres where there are education facilities. The provision of educational services throughout the whole of the Northern Territory is very expensive and, obviously, will require higher levels of funding to maintain reasonable education outcomes and results.Industrial relations is another very important part of the process of the year. I pick up one particular point, the unfair dismissal clause that was in the earlier legislation. That has now been abolished. It is interesting to note that between January 1996 and January 1997 the unfair dismissal claims have been reduced by over 60 per cent. It will be very interesting to see what the percentage will be in January 1998.That is good news for employers because prior to the abolition of that particular unfair dismissal clause territory employers were very reluctant to take on staff. They are a little different from their southern counterparts because the territory has a floating population and sometimes the people will tell an employer that they are going to stay for five years and they are really going to be there for only five months or even less. There were some problems posed when some of the employees were not doing the right thing and it made it very difficult for employers to take them on. But now that we have the new legislation in place it is certainly going to be a boon for small business in the Northern Territory. We have always said that the small business community in Australia is really the engine room for creating employment. I support that particular comment.Road funding is another very interesting topic that I would like to speak about today. Just recently, I was appointed chairman of the Black Spots Road Funding Committee by the Parliamentary Secretary for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Ronaldson). I am pleased to advise the committee that over the next four years some $2.24 million is going to be made available for black spot funding. That, obviously, will be very good in terms of identifying road safety elements and dangerous roads. The committee has met already and has put a proposition to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp). We are hoping to get an answer from him in the next couple of weeks because the funds we have put a bid in for this year must be expended this financial year—that is, additional funding for roads that have particular problems in terms of the safety component.One part of the budget that I was disappointed in was a reduction of about $10 million in the budget for rural roads in isolated communities. I made a representation to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development and other ministers because, whilst $10 million might not seem a very large amount in the overall scheme of things, in some of those communities it is a large amount. Over the years those people have accumulated equipment for repairing and maintaining roads. If those funds are not available through the local government association or through direct funding for roads, the equipment that they have invested quite a bit of money in is going to become useless.

debateinfo: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1996‐97 Cognate bills: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1996‐97 APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1996‐97
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr DONDAS
content: —I have not mentioned the railways yet, but I will later. On roads, I understand that representation has been made by the local government association and also by the Minister for Transport and Works in the Northern Territory to the relevant ministers here. I mentioned that we inherited a black hole of some $8 billion and that communities have to tighten their belts. However, while this $10 million reduction is not a large amount of money in the overall scheme of things, it is certainly a great deal of money for the small communities who rely on it.The diesel fuel rebate has been maintained. That is very important for rural communities. The coalition has put in place policies for major reform to reduce the gap between rural and city pricing of fuel. It is of great concern to me that I must stand here today and talk about the price of unleaded fuel. Unleaded fuel in Port Augusta and South Australia is 77.9c per litre. In Kimba, which is 171 kilometres up the road, it is 89.2c per litre. In Alice Springs it is 88.4c per litre. Super is 90c per litre and diesel is 89.5c per litre in Alice Springs. The price varies between Alice Springs and Darwin.Last year I tabled a petition with over 15,000 signatures. It said:The petition of the undersigned citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia draws to the attention of the House of Representatives the extremely high Road Funding and Petrol Products Excise Tax imposed by the Commonwealth Government which rose from 6.1 cents per litre in 1982 to 35.6 cents per litre, for leaded fuel, in 1995. In addition, the attention of the House of Representatives is drawn to the current tax of 34.18 cents per litre on diesel and that the percentage of excise tax utilised for road funding is now less than 10% of that collected as compared to a maximum of 70% in 1981‐82.Your petitioners therefore request the House to urge the Government to reduce the tax on fuel in order that:1. The cost of living of ordinary Australians is improved; and2. Australias overall international competitiveness is enhanced.Federal excise on unleaded fuel is 36c a litre. Bush people are certainly disadvantaged. We cannot blame the coalition government, because these taxes were imposed by the former Labor Party government. I believe it is time for the coalition to look at the excise tax. People might say, `The retailer is putting a very high profit margin on fuel. For most of the retailers that I have talked to around the country, especially in the Northern Territory, their profit margin is about 10 per cent. I do not believe that 10 per cent is excessive in terms of their operations.The coalition is framing the 1997‐98 budget now. I understand that we are looking at various regimes to accommodate budgetary savings. We know that there are going to be savings in various departments, especially in the areas of social security now that we have put in place the work for the dole scheme. I am told that that will save many millions of dollars throughout the year.I urge the coalition, if it is really going to look after rural Australia, which comprises 88 per cent of the continent, to evaluate where we are going with the excise on fuel. I would hate to see any increase in this next budget as I do not believe it is necessary. I do not believe that I could vote for an increase in the fuel excise in the next budget, especially in rural areas. I would have to consider it.If they were to offer some kind of—

name: Mr Sawford
content: —Fascinating!
debateinfo: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 3) 1996‐97 Cognate bills: APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 4) 1996‐97 APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1996‐97
Speaker: N/A

name: Mr DONDAS
content: —I said I would have to consider it. If they were going to offer some kind of tax rebate on the cost of freight for fuel into regional Australia then I may consider it. But the fuel excise at the moment is far too high.In terms of telecommunications, it is important to know that $250 million has been provided to improve regional telecommunications. I was pleased to see that in making these funds available from the Telstra sale that $16 million is going to the Northern Territory. That will help upgrade the telephone exchanges. We will see something like 85 per cent of regional exchanges converted to digital by the end of 1997. This will mean faster faxes, better mobile phone reception, call waiting and call diversion in more areas, faster EFTPOS services, and faster access to the Internet.On 1 July this year the telecommunications industry is certainly going to be open to more competition leading to better services and, obviously, to lower costs. I understand that price caps will be put in place and that Australians living in rural areas will benefit from cross‐subsidies.The other item that I wanted to speak about this afternoon concerns Aboriginals in the Northern Territory. Of course, I am very pleased that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Herron) has in the last 12 months placed his portfolio to the forefront in this parliament. Most members of parliament are now aware of the problems that exist in the remote parts of Australia in terms of the living conditions, the health services, and education facilities for our indigenous community.The government has focused on providing health and housing services. As you would be aware, in the 1996-97 budget the funds to ATSIC for these particular programs—health and housing—were quarantined by the Commonwealth government. Also, as you heard me say earlier today, Senator Vanstone did provide additional funds for indigenous education by presenting this parliament with a supplementary education bill.The important thing to note is that there are many communities that are in desperate need of services. In fact, I had occasion to bring to the ministers attention something that concerns me greatly. Given that ATSIC makes funds available to regional communities and that there are also housing authorities—both Northern Territory and Commonwealth housing authorities—handling funds for communities, I find it quite difficult to understand how we can go into a community and construct 15 new homes and yet not provide power. There are these beautiful houses constructed. They have got all the light fittings, the light switches, electric terminals, and yet there is no power within the community.As I said to the minister and to other members who were there, it would be better if the housing authorities built one fewer house. They could build 14 houses and give them the funds to put in a 38 kVA, wind‐driven generator which could provide some electrification to that community. It is not just one community, it is in a lot of communities. Funds have been made available for housing but there are no back‐up services.In fact, there is one particular community that I am going to be visiting next week, a place called Aileron, and that is exactly the problem that they have got. There are 12 houses there. The funny part about it is that they have additional funding in the 1997‐98 budget for another six houses. They are also going to get a mobile health clinic. What is the good of having a mobile health clinic and what is the good of giving them additional funds for another six houses if there is no electricity there to give them power, to keep their food in the refrigerators and, obviously, to give them a better standard of living?The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has said that he would take on board my comments about housing and that he would speak to the relevant department and ATSIC to make sure that where funds were going into communities they should make sure the provision of services is there before any other infrastructure is put in, otherwise the infrastructure is not going to be used and will certainly be a waste as far as the Australian taxpayer is concerned.

I inadvertently forgot to table that particular document and I now seek leave to do so.Leave granted.

Speaker: N/A

name: Mr HAWKER
content: —In speaking to the appropriation bill, I think that it is timely to look at the achievements of the Howard government in its first 12 months. There has been universal approval throughout the community for the way the government has tackled some of the difficult jobs that it has had in the first 12 months and for the fact that it has kept the confidence of people in Australia at the same time. While you can look at the opinion columns in certain newspapers, most of those are fairly predictable and come from people who have great difficulty in covering up their personal prejudices rather than looking objectively at what the government has done.There is no doubt that many building blocks have been put in place for a sustained recovery. We are building on the opportunities that the government has given us to repair some of the problems that were handed on from the Labor Party, particularly some of the budgetary problems in the black hole that has been referred to on many occasions. It is worth reminding all honourable members that it was a massive problem of at least $8 billion. The galling thing about it all was the way that even today the current Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) cannot stand up and say, `Yes, I did not tell the whole truth prior to the election. I did not admit what I really knew, that in fact it was there. Instead, he and the former Prime Minister continued to pretend right throughout the election campaign that it was not so. Yet it was pretty obvious there was something amiss, and certainly, when the change of government came, it became blindingly obvious.Today I would like to talk a little about some of the situations that we now confront in regional and rural Australia, particularly as we look, one year on, at some of the changes that have occurred and that will be occurring under this government. I want to put this up against the backdrop of a report that I was involved with. Striking a balance was put together by the Liberal Partys regional and rural committee, and it highlighted in many different areas just how much the Labor Party had neglected regional and rural Australia when it was in office—and, as my colleague reminds me, yes, it was very much so. I think it was a shameful situation that we inherited from Labor. After 13 years, the neglect of the country had really got to the stage that it was nothing short of a national scandal.What this report, Striking a balance , showed was that Labor had effectively left out of the policy process many parts of the services to regional and rural Australia. I guess this shows why, in the last election, there was such an enormous swing in the country areas. There was a significantly bigger swing there than in the city areas because the Labor Party had neglected them so much.I will just quickly touch on a number of those areas. Unemployment was certainly number one on the list. People in the country were very much more aware than those in the city of just how much it was affecting their local communities, particularly amongst the young. We saw that while national youth unemployment exceeded one in four in some parts it was as high as one in three. But in parts of country Victoria, for example, it was even higher. In Western Victoria, youth unemployment hit 36 per cent and at one stage in the Mallee it hit a staggering 66 per cent. While these are the official figures, I think we all know that probably behind them the story is even more grim than those official figures show.One of the first things that the Howard government has set about to do is to put in place the building blocks for not only jobs but sustained growth in jobs. So we have seen a number of very positive moves. We have got the work for the dole scheme that has been announced and has been so well received right throughout the community. It has been so well received by everyone but the Labor Party. The Labor Party just does not like it because it shows them up for their inadequacies while they were in government.The second thing was the change to industrial relations. The changes to the unfair dismissal laws have certainly started to give small business in particular, but other businesses as well, a bit of confidence in starting to employ more people. That, as much as anything, will start the change for some new growth. Small business has also been given a number of incentives. In country areas we can identify more than 100,000 small businesses and they are starting to see some of the benefits not only from the industrial relations changes, but also from the rollover relief from capital gains tax, which has just gone through the House, from the cuts to the provisional tax uplift factor and—as we are going to hear later this month—from the way we are going to reduce the burden of red tape and paperwork on small business. Talk to anyone in small business and they will tell you what a problem that is.

content: —As my colleague points out, there has also been the big one—lower interest rates. name: Mr HAWKER
content: —Before the interruption, I was talking about some of the moves the government was making to increase employment opportunities, as well as the training aspects of the Green Corps. I would also like to mention the upgrading of the apprenticeship system, something that had sadly been run down under Labor to a 30‐year low. Not only are we going to make it quicker and less complex for all those involved, we are going to be establishing one‐stop apprenticeship shops which we believe will certainly make a positive contribution to assisting young people to get into trades. All of us recognise the value of that.Another aspect I would like to touch on quickly is the provision of health services in country areas. Unfortunately, contrary to what many think, while the country may have many attractions, the statistics show that in many cases the health of people in the country is not as great we would like it to be. Without going into too much detail on that, I think part of the problem, as we all recognise, is the difficulty of providing services in the country and, in many cases, just attracting doctors to some of the country centres.Again, this is an area where the previous Labor government certainly neglected the country. While one could not say that they actually did nothing, we did see during the last four years of the Labor government the most amazing thing: every time there was a problem, we would have a conference. Or we would set up the National Rural Health Alliance, or we would have the National Rural Health Strategy, and then we had the Australian Rural Health Institution. It made everyone feel good but, unfortunately, it did not really tackle the major problem. As the Department of Human Services and Health told the previous government, the problem was quite simply that we needed at least another 300 GPs in country areas.Contrast this with what the coalition government is doing. The Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) has been quick to act, setting up a number of private health initiatives. Firstly, he is researching and monitoring the profile of the rural medical work force to find ways and means of trying to get young doctors to take up some of these places in the country. Secondly, there are scholarships for medical students to work in country areas. Thirdly, there is the creation of university departments of rural health—there will be one in each state. I am looking forward to the announcement of what is going to be occurring in my state of Victoria, particularly some of the positive aspects for my electorate of Wannon. And the new Medicare agencies will make access to Medicare much easier.Looking at education, it is most disturbing to see the difference between the participation rate and the retention rate for year 12 students in the country and the city. We find that year 12 country students have fallen behind their city cousins, 52 per cent compared with 66 per cent. In tertiary education, the really disturbing thing is to find that, between 1989 and 1995, the number of country students fell from 25 per cent to 16 per cent. Sadly, country students are 60 per cent less likely than city students to take up tertiary education. Despite all this, Labor refused to face the major cause of this problem. Basically, it boils down to one simple thing: that it costs more to get education for country students than it does for city students. That is one of the major problems we are facing. Already, we are seeing that the coalition has increased access to tertiary and vocational education for thousands of country students. We have seen $2.3 billion in extra funding for government schools—many of them are small schools in country areas.We are also seeing $187 million allocated to strengthen the ties between schools and business. We have seen an increase in the basic boarding allowance for isolated children. We have another 4,000 undergraduate scholarships to be provided for disadvantaged students. There are also some changes that have occurred to the actual means test. I believe that will see a better targeting of that assistance.I will touch quickly on a couple of other transport issues. Roads in the country have been sadly neglected. This is being addressed by the government to some extent through the black spots program. It will take some time to turn around the neglect that occurred under the previous government, but there is an increase in funding. A number of projects in my electorate, as well in other parts of Australia, are attacking the problem.We have also tackled some of the difficulties facing people who have been affected by severe droughts. I would like to talk more about what is happening in rural Australia, but I will just touch on the issue of the speeding up of the modernisation of country telephone exchanges—something that was long overdue. We are very pleased that, by the end of this year, 97 per cent of telephone exchanges will have been modernised, which is bringing forward the previous governments program. That recognises that people in the country deserve access to services similar to those in the city.In conclusion, this government has tackled some of the major problems facing country areas in terms of massive budgetary problems and the neglect of regional and rural Australia. There are also a number of very exciting programs coming on, such as the Natural Heritage Trust, the national landcare program and the Prime Ministers initiative on the supermarket to Asia.This is something that my colleague the member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson) has a very direct involvement in. We are delighted to see this occurring. This initiative of the government is going to bring tremendous benefits to regional Australia and bring some lasting benefits to agriculture.I am pleased to have been able to speak in this debate. It was great to have the opportunity to talk about the benefits of the first year of the Howard‐Fischer government and to highlight the achievements made and the achievements that will come from the measures that have been put in train. I am pleased to have been able to support this debate.

name: Mr RONALDSON
role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)
content: —We are towards the tail end of the appropriation bills debate and it is a great pleasure for me to speak tonight. I want to talk about some good news. I much prefer good news to bad news. It is a shame that the member for Batman (Mr Martin Ferguson), the member for Hotham (Mr Crean) and others are about spreading bad news. I want to talk about good news. I want to talk about jobs. I want to talk about what is happening in my electorate of Ballarat. I want to talk about how we are creating jobs and creating the confidence that underpins the recovery that this government is now driving so hard.Last Friday we had great news in Ballarat. I am sure the member for Lyne (Mr Vaile) shared my enthusiasm for the announcement about the Department of Social Security telecentres. We were in our electorates for that announcement last Friday, and I was at home on the weekend between the sitting weeks. That initiative was about confidence, about a government getting in and making positive announcements.It was about 100 new jobs in Ballarat. It was great news. I have not heard anything from the member for Batman regarding this. I am sure he will find some problems with it somewhere, like Senator Carr found problems with the one‐stop apprenticeship shop. He had the gall, as I quoted from the AAP wire, to allege that Ballarat was not an area of high unemployment. I can assure him that it is and, as I quoted from the AAP wire the other day, that is what was said and that is what I quoted, and that is what I believe he said.Let us have a look at this DSS telecentre. It is about providing opportunities for local people to make the contribution that they want. I get a bit concerned when I see quotes such as that from the member from Batman when he was talking about the work for the dole scheme. I was very disappointed, and I believe people around Australia will be too, to hear the opposition spokesman talking in these terms. When he was talking about opposing work for the dole, he said:They—in other words, unemployed people—go home and go back to bed or watch TV for the rest of the week.That is a very clear message from the member for Batman as to what the Australian people can expect of him from now on.I think it is pretty disappointing that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) also seems to have been trying to score a political point. I hope that is not the reason for his saying this, but you have to suspect that maybe it is. He said that Labors billion dollar training programs were successful not because they led to jobs but because the unemployed `werent around the streets bothering everybody else. I cannot for one minute believe that my honourable colleague opposite would condone those sorts of comments, because I think that denigrates the very people that we should all be working to support. The member for Lyons (Mr Adams) and myself know that the 100 jobs that will be created in places like Ballarat and in his electorate are absolutely critical to the ongoing success of those regions.I spoke about the pilot program one‐stop apprenticeship shop for Ballarat. Members may have heard me speaking, Mr Deputy Speaker—

name: Mr RONALDSON
role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)
content: —Thank you very much. I have been talking about where Ballarat is and where it is going. Again, I would like to tell the chamber that the Minister for Veterans Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) announced two weeks ago that ISSC, which is very actively involved in information technology in Ballarat, won a contract for the Department of Veterans Affairs.This is great news for regional Australia because it shows that the government is committed to putting those government services into regional centres. It is great news indeed. And we won it on our merits. We won it because we have taken the hard steps: we have gone out and sold Ballarat as a centre for information technology; we have sold our advantages; and we have sold that stable, skilled work force, people wanting to get in and have a go, that are prepared to train. We have been able to sell the fact that we have two universities in Ballarat; good, proactive universities with strong private sector links.The simple fact is we have heard a lot of talk recently, and we heard a bit downstairs today from the member for Hotham and the member for Batman, who have suddenly had this huge wave, I suspect, of guilt. I think they know that they did everything wrong, ripped the heart out of this country but did absolutely nothing at all about putting in place some mechanisms to support people that were going to be affected.I find it absolutely incredible to hear this talk about tariff reductions. Where was the member for Batman—when he was president of the ACTU—when, for example, tariffs dropped in TCF apparel from 55 to 37 per cent—

name: Mr RONALDSON
role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)
content: —He was telling them; he did not bother writing. He just rang them and told them, `This is what youre going to do. TCF footwear, 45 to 27 per cent; motor cars, 40 to 25 per cent. Where was the member for Hotham, this new‐found tariff man? He was actually the great tariff slasher in government, but all of a sudden he thinks there might be a few brownie points made out of this and he has done a complete reversal.The problem is that they went ahead and did it and did absolutely nothing about addressing the fundamentals, the budget, micro‐economic reform, IR, you name it. These are the sorts of benefits that the people of Ballarat will get from this government.Ballarat is a community of decent, hard‐working people, or people who are desperately trying to get a job, who are doing their bit for the community. The effect of low interest rates alone has been of enormous benefit to the people of Ballarat, the people of Avoca, the people of Ballan, the people of Stawell and towns and cities right throughout my electorate. The small business people, farmers, you name it, have directly benefited from a low interest rate regime. They are reaping the rewards and the rewards are that they have actually got some money in their pockets now to help pay their mortgage or pay it off a bit quicker. Small business people can start investing and employing and that is what it is about. That is what this budget was all about. It was about giving people the opportunity to do what they do best and the Australian people and the people of Ballarat are no different—they simply want to have a chance. They have got some very basic needs that every member of parliament has. They are about raising a family, about having a decent, honest society, about being able to raise their children, about having a set of values that they can adhere to. Part of that is to have the finances to support the family, to create employment and small business. That is what it is all about.Mr Deputy Speaker, I do not think the Australian people want to be millionaires. I just think they want to get on and do those very basic things that I am sure you and everyone in the chamber today is about—putting a roof over your head, providing for your family, making sure your kids get a good education to get a chance to make their contribution.Time is running out and I know that my colleague would like to say a few words before this debate is closed. Work for the dole, the DSS telecentre, the one‐stop apprenticeship shop, the Department of Veterans Affairs out‐sourcing is all great news for the people of the Ballarat electorate.
