name: Mr ENTSCH
content: —I rise here this evening to speak on Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and to bring to the attention of the House a recent event that in my view again throws into question the integrity, competence and even‐handedness of our federal Civil Aviation Safety Authority.At 4.12 p.m. on Wednesday, 19 February a small aviation company by the name of Wingz North Aviation was thrown into total turmoil when it was advised, via the fax, that its charter licence had been suspended immediately for alleged breaches of safety regulations.Wingz North is a small family company with an excellent reputation and this has been confirmed by the overwhelming community support that I have received in the past two weeks. I have received petitions containing over 500 signatures of citizens of the Torres Strait. Add to this numerous letters of support from other small businesses and you can see clearly that Wingz North enjoys unprecedented support from the community it serves.Wingz North was established in February 1991 and is still operated and owned by its original founders, Gary and Tamara Maile. From what started as a three aircraft operation, it has grown to 12 aircraft based in both Cairns and Horn Island in the Torres Strait. The company employs 12 full‐time pilots, between them totalling 22,000 flying hours, and eight full‐time support staff. They have a wage bill of some $500,000 a year, a maintenance bill of over $900,000 a year and their annual turnover is in excess of $4 million.Mr Deputy Speaker, this is not a little backyard operation, but an efficient, successful family business. In the past six months they have carried approximately 2,000 passengers per month and made over 2,000 take‐offs and landings per month without any serious incident.Of the 33 non‐compliance notices served on Wingz North, some dating back to October 1995, 22 were of a minor administrative nature. They included, for example, incomplete signatures on the rear of forms, all of which were rectified immediately on advice; three minor maintenance breaches when 50‐hour visual inspections were less than two hours late; a further maintenance breach when a 100‐hour service was overdue by approximately one hour—it should be noted that the service fell due during a four‐hour flight to Cairns for that maintenance—an overload problem in October 1995, for which the pilot was suspended and CASA expressed satisfaction with the outcome; and one case of unrestrained luggage involving two pillows and a bag of disposable nappies.All the breaches that I have mentioned here are over an 18‐month period and all were rectified immediately when they were brought to the attention of the company. Of the other five breaches, there were three overload allegations of which two are being strenuously denied by Wingz North. The other two, a dangerous goods breach and a roster discrepancy, were based on allegations by a disgruntled ex‐pilot and were made months after the termination of his employment. I might add that this pilot is currently pursuing an unfair dismissal claim against the company while defending legal action by Wingz North for fraud allegations. Based on these breaches, CASA has embarked on a heavy‐fisted and bloody‐minded campaign to totally destroy this business, and I have been advised late this evening that an appeal by Wingz North against the decision has been overturned. There is every possibility that this business will close down permanently on Friday because of CASAs actions.We can never compromise on air safety, but it is important that air safety authorities remain ever diligent. What I cannot accept is a bureaucratic, authoritarian regime that, from evidence I have received, is prepared at worst to overlook and at best to offer wrist slaps to very serious breaches of safety by other operators, while at the same time targeting an individual in what would appear to be an over‐reaction in a very heavy‐handed attempt to make a statement. I do not make these allegations lightly, but I have been made aware of serious and dangerous breaches to air safety by other operators which have been brought to the attention of CASA, but which, for whatever reason, they have decided to either ignore or wrist slap.Just to make you aware of the seriousness of the issue: as recently as 18 February this year, an aircraft taxiing at Badu Island for take‐off hit some fibre board markers which were thrown through the propeller and smashed to pieces. The pilot did not stop to check the damage but continued to take off. This airline is still flying. Another charter operator, on 30 January 1997, ran off the end of the airstrip at Kubin Village on Moa Island causing damage to the propeller. This aircraft was then flown back to Horn Island before any maintenance was attempted.I have what is called a SNAG in the industry, a defect report on a particular aircraft showing some 25 defects, some of which are quite serious. Yet that aircraft from another airline was still allowed to continue to fly. I have many more examples of serious inconsistencies with regard to CASAs operation in Far North Queensland, many of them equally as serious as those that I have already mentioned. But I guess one of the classics was an aircraft bound for Horn Island broadcasting through a radio on the wrong frequency, creating a potential near‐miss situation. This aircraft, I have been reliably informed, was flown by none other than CASA flight operations inspectors. It certainly raises the question of competence.Light aircraft travel in the Torres Strait region is a lifeline for the Torres Strait people. It is an essential service, not unlike the buses and taxi services of our metropolitan cities. It is a very difficult area to fly in and a hazardous one, given that some of the airstrips are the shortest in Australia and there is very little room for pilot error. On the island of Mer, the airstrip length is only 525 metres; on Darnley, it is 440 metres, and on Mabuiag, it is 420 metres. You can see that there is real skill required to negotiate these strips. I guess what is most important is that the local residents need to have total confidence in their airline and the pilots, and it is patently obvious from the petitions and signatures that I have received to date that Wingz North enjoys that support.Torres Strait, and for that matter, most remote air charter services, are very different from the metropolitan commuter services, as are the people with their special needs that access this service. And those needs should be taken into consideration by any safety authority.Many of the breaches I mentioned before, while not of a serious technical nature likely to cause disaster, certainly need to be brought to the attention of the operator. Given the nature of the work that the operators do and the areas in which they operate, I have no doubt that they were genuine oversights, or in some cases, misjudgments by pilots working under difficult circumstances and certainly not deliberate attempts to flout regulations. I think that it is certainly evident by the fast and positive response by Wingz North in dealing with and rectifying these problems.I see nothing in the evidence presented to me that could in any way be interpreted as a hanging offence and, make no bones about it, this is exactly what CASA is trying to do with Wingz North. The final word should go to Martin Keating, the operations manager for Wingz North, who said in a recent letter to me:At Wingz North I have discovered an operator/owner, Mr Gary Maile, who was strictly by the book. The difference at Wingz North is that Gary owns or is paying off all the aircraft. Any defect reported on any aircraft is attended to immediately. No mean feat when you consider half the fleet is based 800 kilometres from any spare parts department in Cairns.Gary is the fairest businessman I have ever come across, to his staff and his customers. Gary has a great empathy and understanding of the Torres Strait people. It is a difficult place to live and work in by virtue of its remoteness. It is unlike the mainland as far as the services are concerned and the service that Gary provides is a vital link to the population.By their actions, it is little wonder that CASA and many of its representatives are currently held in contempt by a large section of the aviation industry. I can certainly see why there is such a strong call for CASA to be purged of all its incompetent representation and to have them replaced by capable professionals with working knowledge of an industry that they are engaged to administer. I call on CASA to let common sense prevail, get Wingz North into operation and not destroy it in an effort to try to justify their own existence.

name: Mr ANDREW THOMSON
role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs)
content: —It is my task, in the absence of the Minister for Finance, Mr Fahey, to make a few remarks to sum up what has obviously been a very long and wide‐ranging debate. I am sure it has given many members traditionally the opportunity to make remarks and air their views on the general state of the economy, the prospects for our future, the administration of a large number of government programs, as well as on specific appropriations for various organs of the government. One of these is for the Civil Aviation Safety Authority about which my friend and colleague the member for Leichhardt (Mr Entsch) has just made some very pertinent remarks.That said, we have before us Appropriation Bills Nos. 2, 3 and 4 and these together comprise the additional estimates for this financial year, 1996‐97. These additional appropriations total some $1,402 million. However, they are partly offset by savings made in Appropriation Acts Nos. 1 and 2 last year reflecting the governments determination to improve the efficiency of continuing programs. These savings amount to $343 million and, after allowing for these, the total appropriations sought represent a net increase of $1,059 million for appropriations in this financial year, an increase of about three per cent on the amounts that were made available through the annual appropriations at the time of the budget last year.Obviously, the debate has given many new members a second chance to comment on the governments management of the economy since the election in March last year. I am sure it has given members of the opposition the chance to reflect on the enormous folly of some of the things that were done under the previous government. Indeed, it has perhaps given them the chance to bathe in the crystal clear waters of honesty and forthrightness which they were not allowed to do when members of a government. I hope this has given them a refreshing opportunity, such as the one experienced by members of the government.Question resolved in the affirmative.Bill read a second time.Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.
